DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-86. - Village Officers. 
    Village Officers shall consist of a Village Manager, Village Clerk, Village Attorney, Village Prosecutor, Treasurer, and such other officers as are provided by law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-87. - Appointment of Village Officers; term; removal. 
    Officers of the Village shall be appointed by the Village President with a majority vote of the Board of Trustees. Such appointments shall be made at the first regular meeting of the Board of Trustees in the month after a vacancy or as soon as practicable. The appointment is indefinite and the term of the employment relationship remains at will. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-88-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VILLAGE MANAGER 

Sec. 2-101. - Office created. 
    The Office of the Village Manager is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-102. - Qualifications and Appointment. 
    The Village Manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications without regard to his political beliefs. The President and the Board of Trustees may, at their discretion, from time to time by resolution, require the Village Manager to be an actual full-time permanent resident of and maintain domicile within the corporate limits of the Village. 
    Appointment of Village Manager. The Village Manager shall be appointed by the President and Board of Trustees for an indefinite term. The Village Manager shall be appointed solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-103. - Removal of the Village Manager. 
    The Board of Trustees may remove the Village Manager at any time by a majority vote of its members. If requested, a public hearing shall be granted by the Board of Trustees within 30 days following notice of removal. During the interim, the Board of Trustees may suspend the Village Manager from duty, but shall continue the Village Manager's salary and, if the removal becomes final, as provided by any contractual agreement that the Village Manager may have with the Village. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-104. - Powers and duties. 
    The Village Manager shall be the chief executive officer of the Village. As such executive officer, the Village Manager shall have the management and control of all Village affairs placed in the Village Manager's charge by or under this article, and things pertaining to the operation and maintenance of the properties of the Village and of all of the departments of the Village, including the Public Works Department, the Fire Department, the Police Department, the Community Development Department, the Finance Department and all other Village Departments. The Village Manager shall be responsible to the Board for the proper administration of all the affairs of the Village. To that end, he or she shall have power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Hire, appoint, suspend or remove any existing budgeted employee of the Village or otherwise stated herein exclusive of employees and officers of the Police Department and exclusive of regular Firefighters employed on a full-time basis, and as to said excluded employees, the Village Manager shall abide by the provisions of the Rules and Regulations of the Fire and Police Commission. Unless otherwise provided herein, upon discharging any Director, the Village Manager shall submit to the Board of Trustees at the next meeting following such removal a statement concerning said removal and the reasons therefor. The Village Manager shall appoint, suspend or remove any appointive administrative officers, with the consent of the Board, provided for by or under this chapter, except when the appointment power is vested in the elected officials of the Village under this Code of Ordinances or under the State of Illinois. The Village Manager may authorize any administrative officer subject to the manager's direction and supervision to exercise these powers with respect to subordinates in that officer's department, office or agency. 
(2)  Direct and supervise the administration of all departments, personnel, offices and agencies of the Village, except as otherwise provided by this charter or by law. 
(3)  Attend all Board meetings. The Village Manager shall have the right to take part in discussion but shall not vote. 
(4)  See that all laws, provisions of this chapter and acts of the Board of Trustees, subject to enforcement by the Village Manager or by officers subject to the Village Manager's direction and supervision, are faithfully executed. 
(5)  Prepare and submit the annual budget and capital program as needed to the Board of Trustees, and implement the final budget approved by Board of Trustees to achieve the goals of the Village. 
(6)  Submit to the Board of Trustees and make available to the public a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the Village as of the end of each fiscal year. 
(7)  Make such other reports as the Board of Trustees may require concerning operations. 
(8)  Keep the Board of Trustees fully advised as to the financial condition and future needs of the Village. 
(9)  Make recommendations to the Board of Trustees concerning the affairs of the Village and facilitate the work of the Board of Trustees in developing policy. 
(10)  Provide staff support services for the President and Board of Trustees. 
(11)  Assist the Board of Trustees to develop long term goals for the Village and strategies to implement these goals. 
(12)  Encourage and provide staff support for regional and intergovernmental cooperation. 
(13)  Promote partnerships among Board of Trustees, staff, and citizens in developing public policy and building a sense of community. 
(14)  Perform such other duties as are specified in this chapter or may be required by the Board of Trustees. 
(15)  Where required, recommend appointments to Director positions using the most recent Human Resources policies in effect. 
(16)  Where practical and reasonable, the Village Manager shall notify the President and Board of Trustees of any non-routine communications by an elected official. The following are examples of non-routine requests: 
a)  Any request which may interfere with the performance of the normal duties of the Village employee. 
b)  Any request for action that deviates from policy, code, ordinance, or law. 
c)  Any request that creates a new commitment of resources (people, money, or equipment). 
d)  Any request that will have either an immediate or delayed affect on another department or another governmental entity. 
e)  Any request to have fees waived or reduced for permits or licenses or for the use of municipal facilities or resources. 
f)  Any request that will divert resources from an assigned task. 
g)  Any request that will require governing board action. 
h)  Any request for a personnel action to include hiring, termination, transfer, promotion or disciplinary action for any employee or employment candidate. 
i)  Any request which may change or deviate from priorities established for use of resources whether they are personnel, equipment, facilities, or money. 
j)  Any request for information or service that is not considered a routine activity. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-105. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-106. - Emergencies. 
    In case of accident, disaster, or other circumstance creating a public emergency, the Village Manager may award contracts and make purchases for the purpose of meeting said emergency; but the Manager shall file promptly with Board of Trustees a certificate showing such emergency and the necessity for such action, together with an itemized account of all expenditures. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-107. - Bond. 
    The Village Manager shall furnish a surety bond, in an amount set by the Board of Trustees, to be approved by the Board of Trustees, said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of all the Village Manager's duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the Village. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-108. - Compensation. 
    The Village Manager shall receive such compensation as the Board of Trustees shall fix from time to time by ordinance or resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-109. - Vacancy. 
    Any vacancy in the office of the Village Manager shall be filled within 60 days after the effective date of such vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-110. - Saving Clause. 
    If any section, sub-section, or sentence, clause, or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held invalid, such decision or decisions shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. All ordinances of the Village prescribing the duties of Directors shall remain in full force and effect except in so far as they conflict with the provisions of this ordinance in which case the provisions of this ordinance shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-111-2-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE CLERK 

Sec. 2-116. - Bond. 
    The Village Clerk shall, before entering upon the duties of the office, execute to the Village a bond in the sum fixed by the President and Board of Trustees with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees, conditioned as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-117. - Appointment and General duties. 
    The Village Clerk shall be appointed by the President and majority of the Board of Trustees. The Village Clerk shall report to the Village Manager and submit to the Village Manager or the Board of Trustees such reports as the law requires. The Village Clerk shall perform all duties prescribed by law. The Village Clerk may be removed from office by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-118. - Duty to sign licenses. 
    The Village Clerk shall sign licenses that are not otherwise provided for in the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-119. - Duty to receive communications. 
    All petitions or other communications, addressed to the President and Board of Trustees, shall be received by the Village Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-120. - Duty to issue notices. 
    The Village Clerk shall issue notices of all regular and special meetings to all persons whose attendance may be required before the Board of Trustees, or any committee thereof, in accordance with the Open Meetings Law (5 ILCS 120/1.01 et seq.), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-121. - Custodian of seal and records. 
    The Village Clerk shall be the custodian and keeper of the corporate seal and of all the books, records, ordinances and papers of the Village, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-122. - Additional Duties. 
    In addition to the duties herein provided, the Village Clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by this Code or by the Statutes of the State of Illinois, including all duties imposed upon the Village Clerk in connection with elections conducted in the Village of Niles, pursuant to the Election Code. The Village Clerk shall also perform such other duties and functions as may be delegated by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-123. - Deputy Village Clerk. 
    The Village Manager, upon recommendation of the Village Clerk may designate one Deputy Village Clerk who shall, during the disability or absence of the Village Clerk, have and exercise all powers and duties imposed by law upon the Village Clerk. Notwithstanding any provisions of this Article, the Village Manager may designate additional personnel to assist the Village Clerk in the performance of the duties herein provided or imposed upon the Village Clerk by the laws of the State of Illinois. The Deputy Village Clerk may also be the Executive Assistant to the Village President and Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 20-124-2-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-136. - Office of Village Attorney. 
    There is hereby created the office of Village Attorney to sue or defend from suit actions at law or in equity to which the Village may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer of the Village on behalf of the Village or in the capacity of such person as an Officer of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-137. - Appointment; Tenure; Compensation; Removal. 
    The Office of the Village Attorney shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. The appointment shall be for an indefinite term and at such compensation as may be fixed by the President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The Village Attorney may be removed from Office by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-138. - Duties. 
    The Village Attorney shall see to the full enforcement of all judgments or decrees entered in favor of the Village and of all similar interlocutory orders. The Village Attorney shall on behalf of the Village of Niles superintend and conduct all of the legal business of the Village. He or she shall be the legal adviser of the Village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting it, whenever requested to do so by any Village official. Upon request by the President or the Board, he or she shall reduce any opinion to writing. The Village Attorney shall supervise the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings. The Village attorney may retain outside counsel to assist and carry out the functions and duties of the office of the Village Attorney. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-139. - Duty to prosecute and defend. 
    The Village Attorney shall institute and defend any civil proceeding which may be brought by or against the Village. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-140. - Employment of special counsel. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the Board of Trustees from employing special counsel to represent the Village from time to time, and to pay such compensation to such special counsel as the Board of Trustees may from time to time determine. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-141. - Village Attorney as compliance officer. 
    As provided in Village of Niles Code of Ordinances Sec. 2-402, the Village Attorney shall function as compliance officer in the event that the President and Board of Trustees do not appoint a compliance officer. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-142-2-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VILLAGE PROSECUTOR 

Sec. 2-145. - Office of Village Prosecutor. 
    There is hereby created the Office of the Village Prosecutor who shall represent the Village in all cases that involve prosecutions for any violation of any of the provisions of this Code, or on any appeal therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-146. - Appointment; Tenure; Salary; Removal. 
    The Office of Village Prosecutor shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. The appointment shall be for an indefinite term and at such salary as may be fixed by the President and Board of Trustees. The Village Prosecutor may be removed from office by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-147. - Duties. 
    The Village Prosecutor may prosecute violations of any provision of this Code on behalf of the Village and advise and assist all Village officers or employees on questions of law involved in filing complaints, making arrests, and preparing for prosecutions for violations of this Code. The Village Prosecutor may also serve as the Village Attorney. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-148. - Employment of Special Prosecutors. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as prohibiting the Board of Trustees from employing special prosecutors to represent the Village from time to time, and to pay such compensation to such special prosecutors as the Board of Trustees may from time to time determine. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-149. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - VILLAGE TREASURER 

Sec. 2-150. - Duty to make disbursements. 
    The Treasurer shall keep a true and accurate account of all moneys paid into the treasury, showing from whom and on what account received; pay out all such sums of money as may be ordered by the President and Board of Trustees, and only on warrants therefor signed by the President of the Village and Finance Director; and in all such cases such warrants must state upon what particular fund they are drawn. Any bond or interest coupon issued by the Village and due and payable shall be considered as a warrant duly authorized for payment by the Treasurer; provided, however, that should there not be sufficient funds to pay the bonds and interest coupons in full, payments thereon shall be made pro rata. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-151. - Books required. 
    The books which must be kept by the Treasurer shall at all times show the exact condition of the moneys under the Treasurer's control, of each account and appropriation, and of all receipts and disbursements, and such books, together with all others belonging to the Village, and in the Treasurer's custody, shall be by the Treasurer handed over to the Treasurer's successor. The Treasurer shall, upon receipt of all moneys, enter and apportion the moneys to the credit of the several accounts upon which such moneys were paid, stating from whom they were received. The Treasurer shall keep a separate account with each fund or appropriation, stating at the head of each account the amount so appropriated, and giving the several debits and credits belonging thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-152. - Payments to be from proper funds. 
    No money shall be paid by the Village Treasurer upon any warrant, bond or coupon, except from the moneys belonging to the particular fund or appropriation upon which such warrant shall have been drawn, nor shall money be transferred by the Treasurer from one fund to another after it has been received by the Treasurer, nor appropriated to any other purpose other than that for which it has been collected or paid, without the vote of a majority of the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-153. - Duty to cancel paid warrants; documents to accompany reports. 
    The Treasurer shall cancel all warrants paid out and redeemed upon the rendering of any monthly report and shall cause the report to be accompanied by all warrants, duplicate receipts in detail for all moneys received, and such other vouchers as will fully and entirely cover all transactions for the month of such report. Upon examination and approval of the Finance Committee, the Village Clerk shall take charge of the Treasurer's report, warrants and vouchers, and keep the same on file. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-154. - Performance of other duties imposed by law or ordinance. 
    The Village Treasurer shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the laws of the state and the ordinances of the Village or found in the job description as updated by the Village Manager's Office. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
DIVISION 7. - FINANCE DIRECTOR 

Sec. 2-155. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the Office of the Finance Director, to administer the Finance Department under the supervision of the Village Manager. The Village Finance Director shall also serve as the Village Treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-156. - Appointment; Tenure; Compensation; Removal. 
    The Office of the Finance Director shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the recommendation of the Village Manager and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. The appointment is for an indefinite term and the term of such employment remains at will. Such appointment shall be based upon the demonstrated ability, knowledge and experience in the management of government affairs effectively in local finance. The Finance Director shall be responsible to the Village Manager for the effective management and control of the financial activities of the Village. The Finance Director shall report to the Village Manager and submit to the Village Manager or the Board of Trustees such reports as the law requires. Compensation may be set by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The Finance Director may be removed by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-157. - Duties. 
    The Finance Director shall have the authority to approve for payment invoices of less than $10,000.00 for any one purchase. All invoices of $10,000.00 or more shall be presented to the Village Manager for approval, requiring approvals from the Purchasing Manager, Finance Director and Village President. No invoices for $10,000.00 or more shall be paid until such written approval have been obtained. 
    For a purchase of more than $20,000.00 for any one item, the item must be competitively bid and approved by the Village President and Board of Trustees, unless such requirement shall be waived by the Board. Any purchase that exceeds a Department budgeted account must be approved by signature of both the Finance Director and Village Manager. 
    The Finance Director shall perform such other duties as may be delegated to him/her by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-158, 2-159. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR 

Sec. 2-160. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the Office of the Public Works Director, to administer the Public Works Department under the supervision of the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-161. - Appointment; Tenure; Compensation; Removal. 
    The Office of the Public Works Director shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the recommendation of the Village Manager and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. The appointment is for an indefinite term and the term of such employment remains at will. Such appointment shall be based upon the demonstrated ability, knowledge and experience in the management of government affairs effectively in local public works. The Public Works Director shall be responsible to the Village Manager for the effective management and control of the public works system of the Village. Compensation may be set by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The Public Works Director may be removed by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-162. - Duties. 
    The duties of the Public Works Director are as follows: 
(1)  To manage and supervise the Public Works Department; 
(2)  To implement the annual budget for the Public Works Department; 
(3)  To maintain professional comprehensive programs for the Public Works Department; and 
(4)  To perform such other duties as may be delegated to him/her by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-163, 2-164. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR 

Sec. 2-165. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the Office of the Community Development Director, to administer the Community Development Department under the supervision of the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-166. - Appointment; Tenure; Compensation; Removal. 
    The Office of the Community Development Director shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the recommendation of the Village Manager and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. The appointment is for an indefinite term and the term of such employment remains at will. Such appointment shall be based upon the demonstrated ability, knowledge and experience in the management of government affairs effectively in local community development. The Community Development Director shall be responsible to the Village Manager for the effective management and control of the community development activities of the Village. Compensation may be set by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The Community Development Director may be removed by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. Wherever the terms "Building Official" or "Building Commissioner" are used in the Code of Ordinances, amendments thereto, or in any publications incorporated by reference into the Code, such terms shall be construed to mean the Community Development Director. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-167. - Duties. 
    The duties of the Community Development Director are as follows: 
(1)  To manage and supervise the Community Development Department; 
(2)  To implement the annual budget for the Community Development Department and Economic Development; 
(3)  To maintain professional comprehensive programs for the Community Development Department which includes Fire Bureau, Economic Development, and Marketing; 
(4)  To administer and enforce the Zoning Ordinance; 
(5)  To serve as the Official Custodian of the Planning and Zoning Board, and he/she shall: 
a.  Maintain the current zoning district map; and 
b.  Maintain permanent and current records of the zoning ordinance including, but not limited to, official actions on all amendments, special uses, variations, appeals and applications therefor. 
(6)  To perform such other duties as may be delegated to him/her by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-168, 2-169. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - FAMILY SERVICES DIRECTOR 

Sec. 2-170. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the Office of the Family Services Director, to administer the Family Services Department under the supervision of the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-171. - Appointment; Tenure; Compensation; Removal. 
    The Office of the Family Services Director shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the recommendation of the Village Manager and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. The appointment is for an indefinite term and the term of such employment remains at will. Such appointment shall be based upon the demonstrated ability, knowledge and experience in the management of government affairs effectively in family and social service. The Family Services Director shall be responsible to the Village Manager for the effective management and control of the family and social services of the Village. Compensation may be set by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The Family Services Director may be removed by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-172. - Duties. 
    The duties of the Family Services Director are as follows: 
(1)  To manage and supervise the Family Services Department; 
(2)  To implement the annual budget for the Family Services Department; 
(3)  To maintain professional comprehensive counseling services and related support and wellness services to Village residents; and 
(4)  To perform such other duties as may be delegated to him/her by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Secs. 2-173, 2-174. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Senior housing commission, § 22-404. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-281. - Boards, committees and commissions; membership. 
    Village Boards, Committees and Commissions may be created or established by the majority of the Board of Trustees, except those Boards and Commissions established by the State of Illinois. The appointment of persons to serve as members of Village Boards, Committees and Commissions shall be made annually by the majority of the Board of Trustees, except where Statutory Authority requires the President to make such appointments. Each board, committee and commission member shall be entitled to receive a Niles Family Fitness Center Membership during the course of their active term, unless that person resigns or is otherwise removed from his or her position. This membership shall not be construed as compensation under the Niles Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 2-4; Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, 8-22-17; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-49, § 1, adopted Aug. 22, 2017, changed the title of § 2-281 from "Boards and commissions; membership" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 2-282. - Compensation of members of commissions; generally. 
    Chairperson of the Planning and Zoning Board of the Village shall receive as compensation for the faithful discharge of their duties the sum of $200.00 per month. 
    Each member of the Planning and Zoning Board of the Village whose compensation is not otherwise provided for shall receive as compensation for the faithful discharge of their duties the sum of $150.00 per month. 
(Ord. No. 2010-19, § 1, 3-24-10; Ord. No. 2018-18, § 1, 4-24-18) 
Secs. 2-283-2-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Fire and police commissions generally, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-296. - Created; membership; qualifications; oath; removal; Chairman; Secretary. 
    There is hereby created a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners to consist of three persons, one of whom shall be a representative citizen of the employer class, one, a representative citizen of the employee class and one a representative citizen of neither class. Each shall possess the qualifications required of other officers of the municipality and shall take the oath of office and shall be subject to removal from office in the same manner as other appointive officers of the municipality. Such members shall choose a Chairman of the commission whose term shall expire on April 30 next after his appointment, and the Board shall choose a Secretary from among its members. 
(Code 1965, § 2-173) 
Sec. 2-297. - Rules and regulations. 
    The commission is authorized to grant preference points to applicants who have completed college courses in subjects relevant to the position for which they are applying. The total educational points and veterans preference points when added together shall not exceed the maximum of veterans preference points as authorized by state statute. 
(Code 1965, § 2-175; Ord. No. 1995-29, § 1, 5-23-95) 
Sec. 2-298. - Jurisdiction over department; appointment of chiefs. 
    As soon as the fire and police commission has been appointed and qualified, it shall take complete jurisdiction of all members of the fire and police departments to such extent as provided by law; excepting, however, that the chief of the fire department and the chief of the police department shall come under the direct jurisdiction of the President and Board of Trustees. The chiefs of the departments shall be appointed, when feasible, from the high ranks attained by competitive promotion in the classified services of the department concerned, existing, at the time of appointment, by the President and Board of Trustees and be directly responsible thereto. The term "high ranks" shall include only sergeants, lieutenants and captains. 
(Code 1965, § 2-176) 
Sec. 2-299. - Accelerated hire process, lateral transfer policy. 
    The police department and the fire and police commission shall work jointly to implement accelerated lateral transfer/certified officer hiring rules. Approval by the fire and police commission must be given before hiring in this manner can begin. 
(Ord. No. 2002-39, § 1, 7-23-02) 
Sec. 2-300. - Authority to utilize cooperative testing of fire and police recruits. 
(a)  The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners be and is hereby authorized to utilize the Northwest Municipal Conference Area Fire and Police Recruitment and Testing Consortium to administer such segments of recruit testing as the fire and Police Commissioners shall determine to be in the best interests of the village from time to time. 
(b)  The Board of Fire and Police Commissioner be and it is hereby authorized to utilize the results of such testing in establishing its list of eligibles for service in the fire and police departments. 
(c)  The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners be and it is hereby authorized to utilize eligibility lists complied by utilization of test results reported by the Northwest Municipal Area Fire and Police Recruitment Testing Consortium in making appointments to positions in the fire and police departments. 
(d)  The Northwest Municipal Area Fire and Police Recruitment Testing Consortium be and is hereby authorized to act as an agency of the police and fire commission for the purpose of administering tests as herein before authorized. 
(e)  The Village of Niles hereby approves the bylaws of the Northwest Municipal Area Fire and Police Recruitment Testing Consortium, a copy of which is attached to Ordinance No. 2002-64, expressly incorporated by reference in this section and made a part of this section as though fully set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2002-64, §§ 1-5, 11-26-02) 
Secs. 2-301-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Human relations, ch. 58. 

Sec. 2-311. - Commission created, membership, term. 
(a)  There is hereby established and created a Community Relations Commission for the village. The commission shall be composed of five members who shall be residents of the village and who shall reflect, so far as possible, the various neighborhoods, ethnic and racial groups, and various business interests of the village, and whose training, interests, background and experience will aid the commission in its work. The Director of Human Services and the Chief of Police or their designated representatives shall serve the commission as ex officio members. One Village Trustee shall be appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees who shall also serve the commission as an ex officio member. 
(b)  The Village President, by and with the consent of the Board of Trustees, shall appoint or reappoint all citizen members or shall fill vacancies in membership of the commission, as may be required from time to time. All appointees shall hold their office for the term of one year and thereafter until their successors shall have been duly appointed and qualified. If a commission member is not present for three consecutive regular meetings, or four regular meetings in any one calendar year, the Village President may terminate the appointment by written notice given to the terminated member and to the Village Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 1, 5-24-94; Ord. No. 2016-27, § 1, 5-24-16) 
Sec. 2-312. - Officers, meetings and procedures. 
(a)  The Village President, by and with the consent of the Board of Trustees, shall appoint a chairperson of the commission from its members, who shall serve for a term of one year, or until his successor shall be appointed and shall qualify. 
(b)  The commission may elect from its members a Secretary and such other officers as may be necessary and shall adopt such rules of order concerning meetings, public hearings and rules of procedure, as to them shall seem advisable. 
(c)  Regular meetings of the commission shall be held at least one time during each calendar quarter, the dates and times of which shall be decided by the commission. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson at the chair's initiative, or upon the written request of three members of the commission. The commission may meet from time to time to work on projects or problems of commission concern and the commission members may also meet in subcommittees as the needs of the commission shall warrant. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 2, 5-24-94; Ord. No. 2016-27, § 1, 5-24-16) 
Sec. 2-313. - Compensation. 
    The members of the commission shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the operation and conduct of affairs of the commission which expenses have been approved in advance by the Village Manager. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 3, 5-24-94) 
Sec. 2-314. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the Community Relations Commission shall be to foster, encourage and stimulate the improvement of relations among and between citizens of all races, creeds, national origins and economic and educational levels; and to provide all individuals with an equal opportunity to grow and participate to the best of their ability in the economic, educational, social and cultural activities available in the community. The commission will also assist in the development of public information and related communication programs to enhance the quality of life for all village residents. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 4(A), 5-24-94) 
Sec. 2-315. - Responsibilities. 
    The Community Relations Commission shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Receive and investigate complaints, and initiate its own investigation of tensions, practices of discrimination, or acts of prejudice or discrimination against any person or group which has occurred, or is alleged to have occurred, within the village. 
(2)  Provide a forum for community or neighborhood issues which relate to human relations issues and concerns. 
(3)  Invite and enlist the cooperation of racial, religious and ethnic groups, community organizations, professional and technical organizations, as well as real estate sales and management groups in the village to carry out community relations activities. 
(4)  Assist residents in contacting appropriate federal, state, county or other local agencies to provide assistance in handling complaints regarding discrimination, civil rights and community relations issues. 
(5)  Act as the hearing and conciliation mechanism for the village's fair housing ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 4(B), 5-24-94) 
Sec. 2-316. - Functions. 
(a)  The commission may hold public hearings, as deemed necessary, and under the general guidelines as further stipulated in section 2-317 of this article and shall report the findings and results of all such hearings along with appropriate recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees. 
(b)  All activities of the commission whether investigating complaints of discrimination or pursuing programs and activities to enhance and improve community and human relations within the village, shall be deemed advisory in nature and the results of all such investigations and all program or policy initiatives shall be reported to the Village President and Board of Trustees for final consideration and action. 
(c)  The commission shall issue a written report to the Village Board of Trustees each year during the month of May. The report shall include all programs, investigations and activities of the commission for the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 4(C)-(E), 5-24-94) 
Sec. 2-317. - Investigations and hearings. 
(a)  For the purpose of carrying out the functions here and above provided, the Community Relations Commission may conduct investigations and hold public hearings when deemed necessary to obtain facts and testimony required to formulate recommendations for the Village Board of Trustees. When previously authorized by the Village Board of Trustees, the commission may require, by subpoena, the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of documentary evidence relating to any matter under investigation and hearing. The attendance of witnesses or the production of documentary evidence may be required in any designated place of the hearing within the village and before the commission as a whole, or before a duly constituted subcommittee of the commission. Witnesses summoned before the commission, or a subcommittee of the commission, shall be paid the same fees and mileage that are paid witnesses in the circuit court of this state. 
(b)  In case of disobedience to the subpoena, the commission may petition the circuit court of the county for an order requiring the attendance and testimony of witnesses, for the production of documentary evidence, or both. The chairperson of the commission or the chairperson of a subcommittee of the commission conducting a public hearing is hereby authorized to administer an oath and provide for the transcription of all testimony taken. 
(Ord. No. 1994-31, § 5, 5-24-94) 
Sec. 2-318. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-27, § 1, May 24, 2016 repealed § 2-318, which pertained to fair housing subcommittee. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-319. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FINANCE COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-320. - Creation; purpose. 
    In that it is useful to the economic welfare of the Village, there is hereby created a Finance Committee of the Village. The Finance Committee shall advise and assist the Village President and Board of Trustees in the maintenance of a sound tax structure and overall fiscal policy for the Village. The Finance Committee of the Village of Niles shall make suggestions for the amendment of Village Code of Ordinances and to advise the Finance Department. 
(Ord. No. 2013-30, § 1, 5-28-13; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-321. - Finance Committee membership and procedures. 
(a)  Appointment; compensation; term. The committee shall consist of five voting members appointed by the majority of the Board of Trustees. The members shall be a Trustee, who will serve as Chair and four appointees. Each member shall serve without compensation. The term of the appointment shall be one year. 
(b)  Regular Meetings; minutes and records; rules. Regular Meetings of the Finance Committee shall be held at the call of the Chair with no less than one meeting a quarter and no more than one a month unless requested by committee staff liaison and approved by the Chair. The committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings, records and other official actions. It may establish its own rules and procedures necessary or convenient for the conduct of its business. 
(c)  Quorum. A majority of the voting members of the Finance Committee shall constitute a quorum. An affirmative vote of not less than three voting members shall be necessary for any action by the committee. The Chair shall have the power to vote. 
(Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13; Ord. No. 2014-35, § 1, 6-24-14; Ord. No. 2015-30, § 1, 5-26-15; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-322. - Committee jurisdiction and power. 
    The committee shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)  Review and modify, if necessary, the Village of Niles Code of Ordinances for final approval by the Village Board of Trustees; 
(2)  Give advice to the Finance Director when asked; and 
(3)  Perform other functions as related to department Performance Goals created by the Village Manager and Finance Director as set forth in the Performance Based Program. 
(Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13) 
Secs. 2-323, 2-324. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FIRE DEPARTMENT FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 

Sec. 2-325. - Board created/purpose. 
    There is hereby established a Foreign Fire Insurance Board of the Village of Niles. The members of the Board shall consist of seven trustees; the Fire Chief, who shall hold office by virtue of rank, and six members, who shall be elected at large by the sworn members of the department. If there is an insufficient number of candidates to fill all these positions, the number of board members may be reduced, but not to fewer than three trustees. 
    The members of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2003-49, § 1, 9-23-03; Ord. No. 2010-11, § 1, 2-23-10) 
Sec. 2-326. - Powers and duties and procedures. 
(a)  The board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to the Foreign Fire Insurance Board and/or the management of monies appropriated to the Board. 
(b)  The board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that the Board feels are appropriate expenditures under state statute. 
(c)  All expenditures by the Board shall be in accordance with all village ordinances, rules, procedures and policies concerning the expenditure of municipal funds. 
(d)  The funds of the Board shall be annually reviewed as part of the village audit. The audit shall verify that purchases by the Board are for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department. 
(e)  The Treasurer of the Board shall give a sufficient bond to the village. This bond shall be approved by the Mayor. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the Treasurer of his or her duties under the state statute, ordinance, and the rules and regulations adopted by the Board. 
(f)  All of the money paid to the Secretary of the Niles Fire Department under Section 11-10-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-10-1) shall be set apart and shall be appropriated annually by the Village Board of Trustees to the Niles Fire Department Foreign Fire Insurance Board. 
(g)  The Treasurer of the department Foreign Fire Insurance Board shall receive the appropriated money and shall pay out the money upon the order of the Board for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the department. As part of the Niles Fire Department annual audit, these funds shall be audited to verify that the funds have been expended by the Board only for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the department. 
(Ord. No. 2003-49, § 1, 9-23-03; Ord. No. 2010-11, § 1, 2-23-10) 
Sec. 2-327. - Quorum, special meetings. 
    The board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings, and publish notice of same. The board shall be subject to the provisions of the Illinois Open Meeting Act. The Chairman shall preside at board meetings, the Secretary shall keep a record of the proceedings and actions of the Board and may certify the same. Six members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The Chairman may call a special meeting at any time. A special meeting may also be called upon the written notice of six members of the Board. Such notice shall be in writing, duly signed by the Board members. Such notice shall describe in brief, the nature or object of the special meeting. Any person shall be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter before the Board. Minutes of board meetings shall be filed with the Village Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2003-49, § 1, 9-23-03) 
Sec. 2-328. - Restrictions on use of fund. 
    Money from the foreign fire insurance fund may be used for the following purposes and no others: 
(1)  Maintenance of existing village fire department firefighting, emergency medical treatment, and department facilities and equipment; 
(2)  Purchase of equipment for firefighting, emergency medical purposes, and training purposes. All such equipment shall be purchased in the name of the village fire department and shall become the property of the village; and 
(3)  Expenses related to operating the fund. 
    No such money shall be used for the personal benefit of any person; for any person, use, or function not directly related to the village fire department; for food or beverages; or for any recreational or entertainment activity. 
(Ord. No. 2003-49, § 1, 9-23-03) 
DIVISION 6. - BUILDING AND ZONING COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-329. - Building and Zoning Committee creation; purpose. 
(a)  Responsibilities. There is hereby created the Building and Zoning Committee of the Village of Niles. The Building and Zoning Committee shall be charged with reviewing and modifying, if necessary, the Village of Niles Comprehensive Plan to be approved by the Village Board of Trustees. The Building and Zoning Committee shall oversee the Planning and Zoning Board to insure that the Village of Niles Comprehensive Plan is followed. 
(b)  Other duties. The Building and Zoning Committee of the Village of Niles shall make suggestions for the amendment of Chapter 78 Signs, and to advise the Director of Community Development. 
(c)  Appointment; compensation; term. The Committee shall consist of seven voting members. The members shall be a Trustee appointed by the majority of the Board of Trustees, Deputy Village Manager, Village Attorney, Community Development Director, Assistant Community Development Director, Chairman of the Planning and Zoning Board and one appointee. Each member shall serve without compensation. The term of the appointment shall be one year. 
(d)  Chair. The Chair of the Building and Zoning Committee shall be a Trustee. 
(e)  Regular Meetings; minutes and records; rules. Regular Meetings of the Building and Zoning Committee shall be held at the call of the Chair with no less than one meeting a quarter and no more than one a month. The committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings, records and other official actions. It may establish its own rules and procedures necessary or convenient for the conduct of its business. 
(f)  Quorum. A majority of the voting members of the Building and Zoning Committee shall constitute a quorum. An affirmative vote of not less than four voting members shall be necessary for any action by the committee. The Chair shall have the power to vote. 
(Ord. 2009-22, § 1, 6-24-09; Ord. No. 2011-48, § 1, 8-23-11; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13; Ord. No. 2015-30, § 1, 5-26-15; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-330. - Committee jurisdiction and power. 
    The committee shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)  Review, suggest and modify, if necessary, the Village of Niles Comprehensive Plan and the Village of Niles Code of Ordinances for final approval by the Village Board of Trustees; 
(2)  To oversee the Plan Commission and the Zoning Board of Appeals to insure that the Village of Niles Comprehensive Plan is followed. 
(3)  Give advice to the Director of Community Development when asked; and 
(4)  Perform other functions related to goals found in the Performance Based Program. 
(Ord. No. 2009-22, § 1, 6-24-09; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13) 
DIVISION 7. - GENERAL GOVERNMENT AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY COMMITTEE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-30, § 1, adopted May 28, 2013, set out provisions intended for use as § 2-340. For purposes of clarity, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 2-330.1. Subsequently, Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, adopted June 25, 2013 set out provisions intended for use as §§ 2-340-2-342. For purposes of clarity and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 2-330.1-2-330.3. 

Sec. 2-330.1. - Creation; purpose. 
    There is hereby created a General Government and Information Technology Committee of the Village to provide support to the works of the ongoing projects of the General Government and Information Technology Departments. The General Government and Information Technology Committee of the Village of Niles shall make suggestions for the amendment of the Village Code of Ordinances and to advise the General Government and Information Technology Departments. 
(Ord. No. 2013-30, § 1, 5-28-13; Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-330.2. - General Government and Information Technology Committee membership and procedures. 
(a)  Appointment; compensation; term. The committee shall consist of four voting members appointed by the majority of the Board of Trustees. The members shall be a Trustee, who will serve as Chair, the Village Manager, Information Technology Director and one appointee. Each member shall serve without compensation. The term of the appointment shall be one year. 
(b)  Regular Meetings; minutes and records; rules. Regular Meetings of the General Government and Information Technology Committee shall be held at the call of the Chair with no less than one meeting a quarter and no more than one a month. The committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings, records and other official actions. It may establish its own rules and procedures necessary or convenient for the conduct of its business. 
(c)  Quorum. A majority of the voting members of the General Government and Information Technology Committee shall constitute a quorum. An affirmative vote of not less than three voting members shall be necessary for any action by the committee. The Chair shall have the power to vote. 
(Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-330.3. - Committee jurisdiction and power. 
    The committee shall have the power and duty to: 
(1)  Review and modify, if necessary, the Village of Niles Code of Ordinances for final approval by the Village Board of Trustees; 
(2)  Give advice to the Village Manager and/or the Information Technology Director when asked; and 
(3)  Perform other functions as related to department Performance Goals created by the Village Manager and Mayor as set forth in the Performance Based Program. 
(Ord. No. 2013-39, § 1, 6-25-13)

ARTICLE VI. - RECYCLING PRODUCT PROCUREMENT POLICY 

Sec. 2-331. - Review of product and service specifications. 
    Within 12 months subsequent to the effective date of this section, all village departments, agencies, offices, boards and commissions must conduct a review of existing product and service specifications to determine whether existing specifications either require the use of products manufactured from virgin materials or exclude the use of recycled products, reusable products or products designed to be recycled. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-210, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-332. - Exclusions of requirements. 
    In the event that such specifications do exclude the use of recycled products or require the use of virgin materials, then such exclusions of requirements must be eliminated, unless the pertinent department or entity can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Village Manager that these recycled products would not achieve a necessary performance standard. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-211, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-333. - Recommended changes. 
    Within the same 12-month period, all village departments and agencies must recommend changes to the Village Manager to ensure that performance standards for particular products can be met and that specifications are not overly stringent, and to recommend that changes to ensure that specifications will incorporate a requirement for the use of recycled materials, reusable products, and products designed to be recycled to the maximum extent practicable, subject to an alternative showing that either the performance of the product will be jeopardized or that the product will negatively impact health, safety or operational efficiency. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-212, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-334. - Outside contractors. 
    Outside contractors bidding products or services to the village, including printing services, must demonstrate that they will comply with the specifications described in section 2-333 to the greatest extent feasible. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-213, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-335. - Copiers to accept recycled paper. 
    Village staff will work to encourage the copies industry to develop high-speed copiers that will accept recycled paper. In addition, recycled paper shall be used in all copy machines that will accept it. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-214, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-336. - Recycled material label. 
    When recycled products are used, reasonable efforts shall be undertaken to label the products to indicate that they contain recycled materials. To the extent possible, village departments and agencies shall use for their mast-head stationery and envelopes recycled paper that includes postconsumer recycled content and indicate on the paper and envelopes that they contain recycled material. Other recycled products used by the village shall also indicate that they contain recycled material to the extent practicable. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-215, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-337. - Price preference for recycled products. 
    A (ten percent or greater) price preference may be given for recycled products, reusable products offered as alternative to disposable products, and products designed to be recycled where they are offered as alternatives to nonrecyclable products. The preference percentage shall be based on the lowest bid quoted by the suppliers offering nonrecycled products. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-216, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-338. - Cooperation with neighboring governments. 
    The village will cooperate to the greatest extent feasible with neighboring city and county governments in an effort to develop a comprehensive, consistent and effective procurement effort intended to stimulate the market for recycled products, reusable products and products designed to be recycled. 
(Ord. No. 1991-15, § 2-217, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 2-339. - Stimulate market for recycled material. 
    All related village departments and agencies shall work cooperatively to further the purpose of this article. The village's economic development process shall incorporate the goal of stimulating the market for recycled material. 
(1991-15, § 2-218, 4-23-91) 
Secs. 2-340-2-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-351. - Establishment and composition. 
(a)  There is hereby established an office of the municipal government to be known as the office of administrative adjudication which shall be authorized to conduct administrative adjudication proceedings for departments and agencies of the village. 
(b)  The office shall provide for the prompt disposition of alleged infractions of the Code of Ordinances of the Village and to afford such other adjudications as provided by law. When a hearing is set by the administrative law officer, it must be set no sooner than two weeks from the date of the issuance of the violation unless an emergency involving public health and safety or the general welfare of the community is involved in which instance a hearing could be set immediately. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-352. - Administrative law officer-Powers and duties. 
(a)  An administrative law officer shall be appointed by the President and majority of the Board of Trustees. The term of the administrative law officer shall be one year at such compensation as established from time to time by the President and Board of Trustees. The administrative law officer shall be an attorney admitted to the practice of law in the state for at least three years. 
(b)  The administrative law officer shall have all powers necessary to conduct fair and impartial hearings including, but not limited to, the power to: 
(1)  Hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of the issues; 
(2)  Administer oaths and affirmations; 
(3)  Hear testimony; 
(4)  Rule upon motions, objections and the admissibility of evidence; 
(5)  At the request of any party or on the administrative law officer's own motion, subpoena the attendance of relevant witnesses and the production of relevant books, records or other information; 
(6)  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
(7)  Regulate the course of the hearing in accordance with this article, or other applicable law; 
(8)  Issue a final order which includes findings of fact and conclusions of law; and 
(9)  Impose penalties and fines, and issue orders that are consistent with applicable code provisions and assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation; an order may include the suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of a business license, or, in the case of a building code violation, denial of the issuance of transfer stamps. Provided, however, that in no event shall an administrative law officer have the authority to impose a penalty of imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96; Ord. No. 2019-14, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 2-353. - Rules and regulations-Available for public inspection. 
    The rules and regulations promulgated for the conduct of administrative adjudication proceedings shall be published and kept on file in the office of the Village Clerk where they shall be available to the public for inspection and copying at nominal rates during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-354. - Enforcement of judgments. 
    The provisions of 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., are hereby adopted and incorporated into this section. 
(Ord. No. 1998-31, § 1, 8-25-98) 
Secs. 2-355-2-360. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURES 

Sec. 2-361. - Instituting administrative adjudication proceedings. 
    Any authorized department or agency of the village may institute an administrative adjudication proceeding with the office of administrative adjudication by forwarding a copy of a notice of violation or a notice of hearing, which has been properly served, to the office of administrative adjudication, which office shall coordinate hearing dates from the various departments and agencies. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-362. - Subpoenas. 
(a)  An administrative law officer may issue a subpoena only if he or she determines that the testimony of the witnesses or the documents or items sought by the subpoena are necessary to present evidence that it: 
(1)  Is relevant to the case; and 
(2)  Relates to a contested issue in the case. 
(b)  A subpoena issued under this article shall identify: 
(1)  The person to whom it is directed; 
(2)  The documents or other items sought by the subpoena, if any; 
(3)  The date for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena; 
(4)  The time for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena; and 
(5)  The place for the appearance of the witnesses and the production of the documents or other items described in the subpoena. 
(c)  In no event shall the date identified for the appearance of the witnesses or the production of the documents or other items be less than seven days after service of the subpoena. 
(d)  Within three business days of being served with a subpoena issued in accordance with this article, the recipient of the subpoena may contest the order authorizing the issuance of the subpoena to the administrative law officer, setting forth in detail the recipient's objections to the subpoena. Upon receipt of the contest to the subpoena, the administrative law officer shall review the objections and, upon review, enter the appropriate order. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-363. - Representation at hearings. 
(a)  The case for the village may be presented by any village employee or by an attorney designated by the village. 
(b)  The case for the respondent may be presented by the respondent, any agent of the respondent or an attorney. An agent shall present a written authorization signed by the respondent giving the agent power to act and to bind the respondent to any orders entered by the administrative law officer. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-364. - Conduct of hearings. 
    The administrative law officer shall conduct the hearings in an orderly manner and insist upon proper decorum by all persons present at the hearings. The intent of the hearings is to provide the village and the respondent full and fair presentation of the issues. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-365. - Hearing testimony. 
    The strict laws of evidence shall not apply. Hearsay testimony may be admitted and relied upon by the administrative law officer in making his determination. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-366. - Documentary evidence. 
    Relevant documents may be received into evidence without formal proof of authenticity. The administrative law officer shall determine the weight, if any, to be afforded documents received into evidence. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-367. - Transcript of proceedings. 
    Either party may request that the proceedings be taken and transcribed by a certified court reporter. The cost of the reporter shall be borne by the party requesting the reporter. The village may, at its cost, tape record the proceedings. If a tape recording is made, a respondent may obtain a transcript at respondent's cost. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-368. - Continuances. 
    All administrative law proceedings shall be conducted on the date set for hearing. For good cause shown, a postponement may be granted in the discretion of the administrative law officer. The purpose of administrative law proceedings is to provide a prompt resolution of alleged code violations and, accordingly, the request for and the grant of, continuances shall be curtailed to the extent fairness permits. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-369. - Orders. 
    The administrative law officer shall issue such orders, including a final order, in accordance with section 2-352(b) of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-370. - Compliance bond. 
    In order to ensure that code violations are remedied or fines are paid in a timely manner, an administrative law officer, upon issuing a final determination of liability, may require a code violator to post with the village a compliance bond or, as appropriate, to consent to the granting and recording of a lien against titled property. Bonds and liens shall be approved by the Village Treasurer as to form and amount. Whenever it is necessary for the village to make repairs or otherwise expend funds relating to a code violation for which a bond was posted, or whenever fines or costs remain unpaid after a code violator has exhausted or failed to exhaust judicial review procedures, the administrative law officer may, after giving the parties notice and opportunity to be heard, issue an order permitting the village to draw against the bond in an appropriate amount, or to foreclose on the lien. The administrative law officer shall order the bond or the titled property or proceeds from the titled property, less the costs incurred by the village, returned to the code violator upon proof of compliance with the applicable code provisions and the payment of applicable fines or costs. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-371. - Violations of orders. 
    Any person, having received notice and an opportunity for a hearing as provided in this Code, who knowingly fails to comply with an order issued by an administrative law officer under this article, including the issuance of a subpoena, shall, if the order is not stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction prior to its effective date, be guilty of contempt. Contempt shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $200.00 and not more than $500.00 for each offense. Each day that the violation continues shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. In a prosecution under this section, it shall not be a defense that a person came into compliance with an order, sought judicial review of it, or made efforts to comply with an order, subsequent to its effective date. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-372. - Fines payable to the finance department. 
    All fines and other monies paid to the village in accordance with this article shall be remitted to the finance department. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-373. - Election of remedies. 
    In no case may the office of administrative adjudication conduct an administrative adjudication proceeding for an alleged violation of the Code of Ordinances where the requested remedy is a punishment of imprisonment. Nothing in this article, however, shall preclude the village from seeking the remedy of imprisonment in a court of law, including imprisonment for failure to comply with the order of an administrative law officer, pursuant to section 2-371. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-374. - Administrative adjudications procedures not exclusive. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, neither the authority of the office of administrative adjudication to conduct administrative adjudication procedures nor the institution of such procedures under this article shall preclude the village from seeking any remedies for code violations through the use of any other administrative procedure or court proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-375. - Other provisions not limiting. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code of Ordinances, all provisions of the Code, except for those specified in subsection (c) hereof, may be enforced by instituting an administrative adjudication proceeding with the office of administration adjudication as provided in this article. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code of Ordinances, any enforcement action, including but not limited to, license suspension or revocation, which may be exercised by another department or agency of the village may also be exercised by the office of administrative adjudication. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall affect the jurisdiction of the Mayor's Liquor License commission, community relations committee, nursing home hearing board, firefighters pension fund, police pension fund, sign board of appeals, bicycle safety compliance board, the Zoning Board of Appeals, or the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Sec. 2-376. - Appeal. 
    Any party to an administrative adjudication hearing may appeal from an adverse ruling to the circuit court of the county within 30 days of the administrative ruling. 
(Ord. No. 1996-41, § 1, 9-24-96) 
Secs. 2-377-2-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-05, § 1, adopted January 25, 2011, amended Article VIII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article VIII, §§ 2-401-2-406, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2004-18, § 2, 4-27-04; Ord. No. 2009-29, § 1, 7-29-09. 

Sec. 2-401. - Purpose. 
    It is the policy of the Village of Niles that its elected officials, appointed officials and employees shall, in all cases, exercise good judgment and perform their duties for the sole benefit of the residents of the village. To this end, except as is expressly permitted by this Code of Ethics, each village employee, each elected official and each appointed official is prohibited from soliciting, accepting or retaining any personal economic benefit or opportunity as this may impair or present the appearance of impairing the ability to fulfill their duties solely for the benefit of the residents of Niles. It is further the policy of the village that all appearances of impropriety shall be avoided. The Board of Ethics hereby determines that a policy setting forth ethical principles and regulations applicable to all village elected officials, appointed officials and employees is in the best interests of the Village of Niles and its residents. Such a policy will contribute to the public confidence in the integrity and honesty of employees, elected officials and appointed officials and in their ability to perform their duties solely for the public good. To that end this Code of Ethics is adopted. 
(Ord. No. 2011-05, § 1, 1-25-11; Ord. No. 2011-08, § 1, 2-22-11) 
Sec. 2-402. - Definitions. 
    Affirmation: Telling a truthful statement. 
    Appointed official: The Village Manager; assistant Village Manager; Village Clerk; deputy Village Clerk; Village Attorney; police chief; Fire Chief; directors; superintendents; members of the Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals, Board of Ethics, Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, police pension board and fire pension board; whether compensated or not. 
    Board of Ethics: See section 2-425 of the Niles Code of Ordinances for the definition. 
    Change in status: Any change of any kind or nature in the information required to be filed or disclosed pursuant to this Code of Ethics. 
    Compensated time: With respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment. For purposes of this Code, compensated time shall not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. For employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensated time" includes any period of time when the employee is on premises under the control of the village and any other time when the employee is executing his or her village duties, regardless of location. 
    Compensatory time: Authorized and documented time off from work earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of employment with the village. 
    Compliance officer: That person appointed by the President and Board of Trustees whose duty it shall be to assure compliance with this Code of Ethics. In the absence of such an appointment by the President and Board of Trustees, the Village Attorney shall function as the Compliance Officer. 
    Coordinator: Any employee designated as a coordinator by the Village Manager or by the Niles Village Code. 
    Covered person: Unless otherwise stated or expressly limited, this shall mean every elected official, appointed official or employee of the village. 
    Director: Each village department head. 
    Elected official: The President and any member of the Board of Trustees chosen by the village electorate and any duly appointed member of the Board of Trustees. 
    Employee: Any person employed by the village (whether part-time or full time and whether or not pursuant to a contract) whose duties are subject to the direction and control of the Village Board or a village supervisor with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed. Employee does not include an independent contractor. 
    Ethics: Matters of right and wrong behavior. 
    Gift: Any money, fee, commission, credit, gratuity, thing of value including a discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, other tangible or intangible item having monetary value. This includes compensation of any kind including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, or honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of a covered person. 
    Indirect or indirectly: When used in the phrase "directly or indirectly," "indirectly" shall mean a connection to a decision, transaction or property, through another person , entity or remote document that, while the connection is not direct, enables the covered person to accrue some benefit from the decision, transaction or property. 
    Inspector General: Chief investigative officer for all alleged violations of the Village of Niles Public Employees Ethics Act. 
    Interest in real property: This shall include, but is not limited to any legal or beneficial interest whatsoever in real property through (i) a trust; or (ii) contract to purchase where title may not have been yet conveyed; or (iii) a corporation, an investment group or limited liability company or partnership; or (iv) leasehold or rental agreement. 
    Intra-governmental and inter-governmental gifts: Intra-governmental gift means any gift given to a covered person from another covered person. Inter-governmental gift means any gift given to a covered person by an elected official, appointed official or employee of another public body. 
    Other members of a person's household: A person who is not a spouse or minor child a of covered person who resides at the same residence of the covered person at least 180 days per year and does not pay fair market value rent. 
    Political activity: Any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, including but not limited to the following: 
(a)  Preparing for, organizing or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration or other political event; 
(b)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase, selling, distributing or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting or other political event; 
(c)  Soliciting or planning the solicitation of (by preparing any document or report regarding) anything of value intended as a campaign contribution; 
(d)  Planning, conducting or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question; 
(e)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question; 
(f)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question; 
(g)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls; 
(h)  Initiating for circulation, preparation, circulating, reviewing or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question; 
(i)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office; 
(j)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires; 
(k)  Distributing, preparing for distribution or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question; 
(l)  Campaigning for an elective office or for or against any referendum question;
