(g)  No fence, shrubbery or hedging shall be permitted on any portion of any public right-of-way, nor shall same be placed or maintained so as to obstruct a clear view of private driveways, sidewalks or pedestrian walks. No fence, shrubbery, hedging or planting which interferes with clear vision shall be permitted within the traffic sight line. 
(h)  No fence shall impede or divert the flow of water through any property unless by proper investigation it can be shown to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works that the fence will not adversely impact any adjoining property owner and will contribute to an improvement in the overall drainage system. 
(i)  All fences heretofore lawfully constructed and not in conformity herewith shall be deemed nonconforming uses and may exist but may not be reconstructed, altered or extended. Except any existing fence located in a corner side yard may be replaced in the same location with the same amount of openness as the existing fence but shall be limited to a height of five feet from grade. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 18-172. - Requests for variances. 
    Requests for variances in the M and P zoning districts of the requirements of this section shall be directed to the Zoning Board of Appeals. Applications for appeals or variances shall be made in writing on forms provided by the Village. A uniform filing fee as set in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances shall be paid to the Village upon filing of each application for appeal or variance for the purpose of defraying expenses resulting from the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-173. - Use of metal or barbed wire. 
    On metal fences, any exposed ends, whether along the top or bottom rails, should be rounded or capped so as to avoid creating sharp or pointed ends. Barbed wire along the top of fences or screening is prohibited, except that barbed wire strands may be erected in areas deemed to be in hazardous usage, such determination to be made by the Director of Community Development. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-174. - Fences prohibited, which are potential hazards; right of review. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, no fence otherwise permitted under this article shall be permitted if the construction of such fence would create or add to a potential hazard to life, property or traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-175. - Temporary fences. 
    At the time of the issuance of the building permit for general construction projects and before the construction activity commences on all commercial general construction sites and residential general construction sites, a minimum of a five-foot high chain link type temporary fence shall be erected and shall be maintained and remain on site until the approval by the building code official. Gates on said fence shall be locked and secured when no construction work is taking place. 
    Any vacant parcel approved for and utilized for construction equipment, staging and or material shall erect a minimum five-foot high chain link type temporary fence and shall be maintained and remain on site until the approval by the Director of Community Development. Gates on said fence shall be locked and secured when no construction activity is taking place. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 18-176-18-179. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - GRADES 

Sec. 18-180. - Grading requirements. 
(a)  A grading plan is required for all land improvements. This would consist of existing and proposed contours for grading and drainage facilities within 100 feet of the site in all directions in USGS datum. All existing and proposed conditions must also be shown. Grading plans and erosion control plans shall be on separate sheets. 
(b)  No proposed grade shall impede or divert the flow of water through any property unless by proper investigation it can be shown to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works that the grade will not adversely impact any adjoining property owner and will contribute to an improvement in the overall drainage system. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 18-181. - General lot grade maximums. 
    No lot shall be graded in such a manner as to raise the grade of such lot to any point higher than a continuous grade level between the grade of the lots on either side abutting such lot. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-182. - Foundation grades and rules. 
(a)  All foundation grades shall be established in such a manner as to achieve the free, natural and unobstructed flow of surface water. 
(b)  The Director of Public Works shall from time to time promulgate detailed rules, not inconsistent with this article, for the purpose of determining foundation grades. 
(c)  Every application for a building permit shall show the foundation grade and set forth a grading plan for the proposed construction, determined in accordance with this article and rules established pursuant thereto. No building permit shall be issued unless such foundation grade and grading plan is in accordance with the provisions of this article and rules issued under this article. 
(d)  The foundation height at the 25-foot building line is 18 inches above the sidewalk. Use the middle of a lot for measurement. The top of a foundation should be four inches above the finished grade. Side service walks and drives are to be a minimum of four inches below the top of the foundation. 
(e)  Below grade openings to attached garages are prohibited unless approved by the engineering department. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 18-183. - Subdivision grade plans. 
    The provisions of sections 18-181 and 18-182 shall be supplemental to the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the Village respecting any subdivision approved pursuant to the provisions of such ordinance. No building permit shall be issued by the Director of Community Development unless he has on file an approved lot grading plan for such subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-184. - Altering grade levels. 
    Building permits which include any excavation work must file a grading plan with the Director of Public Works. No grades within the Village shall be disturbed or otherwise altered except as allowed pursuant to a permit issued by the Director of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 18-185. - Final grading inspection. 
(a)  Procedures. 
(1)  Prior to the issuance of any certificate of occupancy, a final grading inspection must be conducted by the engineering division. The developer/contractor is responsible for scheduling the inspection at least 24 hours in advance of the desired inspection time. Developer/contractor must be present at inspection. 
(2)  The final grading inspection shall identify whether all grading requirements set forth in these specifications have been met. 
(3)  No permanent certificate of occupancy shall be issued until the final grading inspection has been approved. 
(4)  A temporary certificate of occupancy will be authorized only if, because of winter weather, the final grading of the lot cannot be completed. 
(5)  For any temporary certificate of occupancy issued between November 1 and April 1, the developer/contractor shall have until June 1 to complete the work unless, in the opinion of the Village of Niles Engineer, weather is prohibiting work from being accomplished. 
(6)  Prior to permanent occupancy of any structure, a final plat of survey must be submitted at least ten days prior to the final grading inspection, in which it is shown that the as-built grading is in conformance with the approved grading plan. 
(7)  The Village of Niles Engineer may approve minor deviations from the grading plan provided that the changes do not adversely affect the drainage characteristics of the property in question or surrounding properties. 
(8)  The developer/general contractor shall bear full responsibility of correcting all deficiencies revealed in the as-built survey as directed by the Village of Niles Engineer. 
(b)  As-built survey requirements. 
(1)  As-built top of foundation elevation, including any step down. 
(2)  Garage floor elevation. 
(3)  Driveway slope. 
(4)  Location and extent of any foundation exposure greater than six inches. 
(5)  Spot grades at all lot corners, drainage breakpoints, every 25 feet and any other locations needed to adequately show drainage paths. 
(6)  Any existing trees that are on site or nearby, require spot elevation. 
(7)  Existing rim elevations of drainage structures. 
(8)  As-built contours at one-inch intervals. 
(9)  Location of structure with offsets from front and side property lines. 
(10)  Any miscellaneous features influencing grading, such as the top and bottom of retaining walls, all break points, private walks, patios, etc. 
(11)  Location and elevation of utility structures. 
(12)  Address, lot number and permit number. 
(13)  An original stamp or seal of a professional engineer or registered land surveyor. 
(c)  Areas to be graded and sodded. All improved areas within the dedicated street area or private lot shall be graded with six inches of topsoil and sodded. Other public use areas such as outlots, detention basins or parks shall be graded and seeded or sodded in an approved manner. Core samples of soil from the private lots will be taken randomly to ensure six inches of topsoil. Restoration work shall be performed to the satisfaction of the Village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-186. - Top of foundation approval. 
(a)  Procedures. 
(1)  The elevation of the top of foundation of any structure constructed shall be in conformance with the approved grading plan. If the constructed top of foundation differs by 0.2 feet from the approved grading plans, then design changes shall be submitted for approval by the Village engineer prior to constructing beyond the foundation walls. 
(2)  Within 14 days after the foundation is constructed, the owner/developer shall furnish to the Village of Niles two copies of the plat of survey prepared by a registered land surveyor attesting to the top of the foundation elevation, together with a true United States Geological Survey elevation of the top of foundation. 
No construction shall be permitted above the foundation, except for water, sewer and appurtenances thereto, unless the aforesaid survey has been approved by the Community Development Department. 
(b)  Top of foundation survey requirements. 
(1)  Proposed and as-built foundation elevations, including location and elevation for any step downs for walkouts or English basement units. 
(2)  Foundation location on property with offsets from front and side property lines. 
(3)  Driveway location. 
(4)  Location of all easements and setback lines on property. 
(5)  Permit number and address of each lot/unit. 
(6)  Stamp and signature of a registered land surveyor. 
(c)  Top of foundation survey approval. 
(1)  The as-built foundation elevation must be within 0.2 feet of the elevation as approved on the grading plan. Any differences greater than 0.2 feet will be subject to review by the Village of Niles Engineer. 
(2)  The structure must meet all setback requirements. 
(3)  The structure must not be located within an easement. 
(d)  Review the survey. The Village will review the survey within two business days of submittal. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-187. - Design. 
(a)  Engineering requirements. 
(1)  Grass slopes shall be a two percent minimum. Thirty-three percent maximum grass slope for non-residential and 25 percent maximum grass slope for residential. 
(2)  Driveway slope shall be between two percent and eight percent. 
(3)  Minimum top of foundation grade or lowest unprotected structure opening not less than one and one-half feet higher than the overland flow crest elevation. 
(4)  Minimum exposed foundation at the grass grade or protective side slope vertical rise at the foundation is six inches. 
(b)  Grading plan requirements are listed below and are not limited to: 
(1)  Elevations at property corners, ROW line, top of curb grades at extended property line, high points, and swale breakpoints and any locations needed to define a drainage pattern. Proposed contours are required on all grading plans. 
(2)  Building pad locations. 
(3)  A note is required on the plans stating that all stockpiles and basins must be seeded immediately for erosion control. This is in addition to silt fencing or hay bales used in the interim until the seeding is established. Any fast growing grass would be acceptable. 
(4)  Top of foundation elevations with designations for any walkout, English basements, drop siding, or exposed foundation. 
(5)  Existing ground elevations near the tree which will be saved. 
(6)  Driveway location and slope. 
(7)  Required and provided storage volumes for detention as well as normal water line and high water line. 
(8)  Garage floor elevations if not on typical lot cross-section. 
(9)  Drainage arrows with slope shall be shown in parking lots or where needed to define the drainage pattern. 
(10)  Location and rim elevations of all drainage structures. 
(11)  Overland flow paths shall be indicated by large arrows. 
(12)  Proposed street centerline elevations indicated every 100 feet and at high and low points. 
(13)  Channel or swale flow elevations shall be indicated every 50 feet. Cross-sections may be required. 
(14)  Grading legend. 
(15)  Floodplain boundaries. 
(16)  Retaining wall elevations and locations at top of and bottom of wall at all break points. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 18-188-18-189. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - CONTRACTORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-190. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractor means any person engaged in the business of constructing, altering, or repairing buildings or other structures or sidewalk or street pavements, including, but not limited to, general building contractors, cement or concrete contractors, masonry contractors, carpentry contractors, and subcontractors. 
    General contractor means a contractor that uses one or more trades or subcontractors to perform the required construction to complete a project for which a building permit is required. 
    Subcontractor means a contractor that performs only that type of work that is classified as a trade. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Sec. 18-191. - Presumption that one is a contractor; exception for homeowners. 
(a)  Any person who engages in the construction, repair or alteration of any building, structure, street or sidewalk pavement within the municipality, for which a building permit is required, is presumed to be a contractor and must be registered under this article unless such presumption is rebutted. 
(b)  The exception to this rule is the homeowner. The homeowner may apply for a building permit if it is for his domicile, without a contractor's registration, if he first satisfies the building official that he is capable of making the installation properly. If not, the homeowner must have the application taken out and the installation done by a registered contractor. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Sec. 18-192. - Violations; penalty; revocation of registration. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(b)  Any registration issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the president for any violation of any provision in this article, and such revocation shall be in addition to any fine or penalty imposed. No person whose registration has been revoked as provided in this section shall be eligible for a new registration during the registration period. The president may for good cause shown reinstate a revoked registration during the registration period without payment of an additional fee. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, adopted July 10, 2018, changed the title of § 18-192 from "Violations; penalty; revocation of licenses" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-193. - Hours for construction work. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to engage in or conduct any activity in the construction of any building or structure, including but not limited to the making of an excavation, and loading or unloading material, equipment or supplies, anywhere in the Village except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:30 p.m. on weekdays, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. on Saturday, and it shall be unlawful to engage in any such work or activity on a Sunday. 
(b)  Permission may be granted with Village Board approval for relief of subsection (a) provided a written request is submitted to the appropriate Department Director and shall state the name of the applicant, and the location of the proposed work, and the reason for seeking an approval to do such work, as well as the estimated time of the proposed operations. The appropriate Department Director shall make a recommendation to the Village Board for approval or denial of such relief. In the event of an emergency, permission may be granted by the Village Manager without the required Village Board approval. No such special approval shall be issued, excepting where the public welfare will be enhanced by such issuance, or will be harmed by failure to perform the work at the time indicated. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent any work necessary to prevent injury to persons or property at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2017-31, § 1, 5-23-2017) 
Sec. 18-194. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, adopted July 10, 2018, changed the title of div. 2 from "License" to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 18-195. - Required. 
    No person shall be a contractor within the Village without first becoming registered as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-196. - License required. 
(a)  All plumbing contractors doing work in the Village of Niles shall be licensed and bonded with the State of Illinois and shall provide a copy of their license. 
(b)  All roofing contractors doing work in the Village of Niles shall be licensed with the State of Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation Division of Professional Regulation and provide a copy of their license. 
(c)  All alarm contractors doing work in the Village of Niles shall be licensed and bonded with the State of Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation Division of Professional Regulation and provide a copy of their license. 
(d)  All sprinkler contractors doing work in the Village of Niles shall be licensed with the State Fire Marshall and shall provide a copy of their license. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, adopted July 10, 2018, changed the title of § 18-196 from "Bond required" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-197. - Duration. 
(a)  The Department of Community Development shall register the contractor upon compliance with this article and payment of the fee set out in Appendix D Fee Schedule. All registrations shall expire on a fiscal year basis. 
(b)  If the permitted work is not completed and approved by the Village of Niles and a required occupancy permit is not issued the registered contractor shall renew the registration until all required work is completed and if required an occupancy permit is issued. The renewed registration shall be considered a continuation of the original registration. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Sec. 18-198. - Scope of general contractor's registration. 
    Any person registered as a general contractor shall not be required to secure an additional registration for the performance of carpentry, masonry, cement or concrete contracting. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, adopted July 10, 2018, changed the title of § 18-198 from "Scope of general contractor's license" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-199. - General duties of registers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all contractors registered under this article to comply with this Code and all ordinances relating to or regulating the activities engaged in to remove or cause to be removed from the site of contractor's activities all trash, refuse and waste materials at least once each week. 
(b)  Contractors shall at all times keep the site of activities in an orderly condition, free from standing water, accumulated rubbish, weeds, unguarded dangerous implements and health and safety hazards, and contractors shall not obstruct traffic on streets or sidewalks or permit dirt or waste materials to fall or be carried onto such public ways. Debris, rubbish, equipment and other materials shall not encroach on a neighboring property. 
(c)  Persons, firm or corporation using public property when approved for construction shall provide suitable barricades and shall place and maintain proper barricades and sufficient warning lights to guard and protect all traffic and passerby. 
(d)  Contractors shall be responsible for the erection of construction fences. The construction fence shall be a minimum of five feet tall. Fences shall be constructed and maintained to keep the construction site safe and secure at all times. Fence poles utilizing portable bases shall be properly secured together and sand bags placed at the bottom of all bases. Rolled cyclone fence post shall be spaced no more than six feet apart. There shall be an access gate that can be securely locked during non-work hours. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-40, § 1, adopted July 10, 2018, changed the title of § 18-199 from "General duties of licensees" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 18-200. - Inspection and enforcement. 
(a)  The provisions of this article are declared to be of a regulatory nature, and the departments of Community Development, Fire, Police and Public Works may inspect the sites of contractors' activities at reasonable times, to see that such sites are being conducted and operated in accordance with the requirements of all laws and ordinances applicable thereto and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  An additional charge will be applied for inspections that are after normal business hours. Please refer to Appendix D Fee Schedule for all related fees. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Secs. 18-201-18-209. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - MAINTENANCE OF BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-210. - Vacant building. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Vacant building. A dwelling, dwelling unit, efficiency dwelling unit, habitable space, residential building, or structure lacking the continuous habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises for a period of 90 days or longer but excluding property under a listing agreement with a real estate agent licensed in Illinois and currently listed in a newspaper of general circulation or a multiple listing service. 
(b)  Vacant building maintenance. 
(1)  The owner of a vacant building shall apply to the Village of Niles Community Development Department for and obtain a vacant building maintenance permit 15 days prior to vacating the premises. The vacant building permit shall be renewed annually. The owner shall pay an annual fee for the vacant building maintenance permit. Refer to Appendix D Fee Schedule for all related fees. 
(2)  Application for a vacant building maintenance permit shall be made on a form provided by the Community Development Department. The application shall disclose all measures to be taken to ensure that the vacant building will be kept weather tight and secure from trespassers, safe for entry by police officers and firefighters in times of emergency, and, together with its premises, free from nuisances and in good order. 
(3)  At the time of application, the owner shall arrange for inspection of the vacant building by the Community Development Department. 
(4)  The Community Development Department shall inspect the vacant building for the purpose of determining the structural integrity of the vacant building; the repairs necessary to ensure its structural integrity; that it will be safe for entry by fire fighters and police officers in time of emergency; that the vacant building and its contents do not present a hazard to the public during the time that the building remains vacant; and that the building and exterior premises meet the requirements of the property maintenance code. 
(5)  The Community Development Department shall issue any orders for work needed to: 
a.  Adequately protect the vacant building from intrusion by trespassers and from deterioration by the weather; and 
b.  Insure that allowing the vacant building to remain will not be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare, will not unreasonably interfere with the reasonable and lawful use and enjoyment of other premises within the neighborhood, and will not pose any extraordinary hazard to police officers or fire fighters entering the vacant building in times of emergency. 
(6)  Within 30 days of the issuance of any orders, the owner shall bring the vacant building into compliance with any orders that may have been issued as conditions for the issuance of the license. 
(7)  The Community Development Department shall issue a vacant building permit only after inspecting the building and concluding that the building complies with applicable Village codes and ordinances. 
The Village of Niles Community Development Department shall have the authority to inspect the vacant building at any time. 
(8)  The owner shall notify the Community Development Department 15 days before a vacant building becomes inhabited so that the Community Development Department can inspect the vacant building prior to occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-211. - Vacant commercial storefront. 
    For vacant commercial property, all ground floor windows facing street frontage, including, but not limited to, all display windows in unoccupied or vacant commercial buildings shall be kept in a well maintained and clean condition and the space visible from the windows shall be a clean white box, or the windows on the interior side shall be covered in a professionally finished manner with an opaque window covering material manufactured for that purpose located (2 foot to 6 foot from the ground). A suitable alternative would be to install horizontal pleated or vertical shades approved by the Director of Community Development. In the case of display windows, such windows shall be kept in a well maintained and clean condition and the display area shall be enclosed with a professionally finished backdrop, floor, side walls and ceiling all of which shall be kept in a well maintained and clean condition. Photographs, paintings and other works of art or other tasteful forms of decoration may be professionally displayed in these properly enclosed clear glass display windows. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-212. - Occupancy when residential property transferred. 
(a)  Notice of transfer required. Any person owning real estate improved with a building or structure within the Village, or any attorney, agent or real estate broker acting on behalf of any person owning improved real estate within the Village, shall notify the Department of Community Development upon a form provided by the Department of Community Development of any proposed sale, lease, sublease, assignment, renewal of lease, or other transfer of the legal or beneficial interest of such improved estate. 
(b)  Inspection. Upon receipt of the notice provided for in subsection (a) of this section, the Department of Community Development shall cause an inspection to be made of the structure located on the real estate, and the Department of Community Development shall, if the premises are found to be in compliance with the ordinances of this Village relating to buildings and other structures, issue an occupancy permit to the purchaser of the real estate. 
(c)  Notice; correction of defects. Upon making the inspection required under subsection (b) of this section, the Department of Community Development shall, if defects are found in the building or structure, notify the owner thereof of such defects. No occupancy permit shall be issued until all such defects are corrected. 
(d)  Violations. It shall be unlawful for any person owning any improved real estate within the Village to offer such improved real estate for sale, lease, renewal of lease or other transfer without complying with the provisions of this section. It shall be unlawful for any agent, attorney or real estate broker to offer any improved real estate for sale, lease, renewal of lease or other transfer within the Village without complying with the provisions of this section. It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, lease, renew a lease or take possession of any improved real estate within the Village without complying with the provisions of this section. No person shall be permitted to take possession of any improved real estate within the Village without complying with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 18-213-18-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - DANGEROUS BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-220. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dangerous buildings means any buildings or structures which have any or all of the following defects shall be deemed dangerous buildings: 
(1)  Those whose interior walls or other vertical structural members list, lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity falls outside of the middle third of its base. 
(2)  Those which, exclusive of the foundation, show 33 percent or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting member or 50 percent of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering. 
(3)  Those which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs or in which the floors or roofs are overloaded, or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used. 
(4)  Those which have been damaged by fire, wind or other causes so as to have become dangerous to life, safety, morals, or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the Village. 
(5)  Those which have become or are so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe, unsanitary or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities essential to decent living that they are unfit for human habitation, or are likely to cause sickness or disease, so as to work injury to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of those living therein. 
(6)  Those having light, air, and sanitation facilities which are inadequate to protect the health, morals, safety, or general welfare of human beings who live or may live therein. 
(7)  Those having inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic or those having insufficient stairways, elevators, fire escapes, or other means of evacuation. 
(8)  Those, which have parts, which are so attached that they may fall and injure members of the public or property. 
(9)  Those, which because of their condition are unsafe, unsanitary, or dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the people of the Village. 
(10)  Those buildings existing in violation of any provision of the building code of the Village, or any provision of the fire prevention code, or other ordinances of this Village. 
    Uncompleted buildings means if all work required to be done under the plans and specifications submitted to the Community Development Department for the purpose of securing the issuance of a building permit under article II of this chapter has not been fully performed, and no substantial progress in the completion of the work has been made for a period of 60 days. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-221. - Standards for repair; vacation; demolition. 
    The following standards shall be followed in substance by the Department of Community Development in ordering repair, vacation, or demolition: 
(1)  If the dangerous building can reasonably be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article, then it shall be ordered repaired. 
(2)  If the dangerous building is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health, morals, safety, or general welfare of its occupants, then it shall be ordered to be vacated. 
(3)  In any case where a dangerous building is 50 percent damaged or decayed, or deteriorated from its original value or structure, then it shall be demolished, and in all cases where a building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article, then it shall be demolished. In all cases where a dangerous building is a fire hazard existing or erected in violation of the terms of this article or any ordinance of the Village or statute of the state, then it shall be demolished. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-222. - Declared nuisances. 
    All dangerous buildings within the terms of section 18-136 are hereby declared to be public nuisances, and shall be repaired, vacated, or demolished as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-223. - Duties of Director of Community Development. 
    The Director of Community Development shall: 
(1)  Inspect or cause to be inspected semiannually all public buildings, schools, halls, churches, theaters, hotels, tenements, commercial, manufacturing, or loft buildings for the purpose of determining whether any conditions exist which render such places dangerous or uncompleted, or abandoned buildings within the terms of this article. 
(2)  Inspect any building, wall or structure about which complaints are filed by any person to the effect that a building wall or structure is or may be existing in violation of this article. 
(3)  Inspect any building, wall or structure reported by the fire or police departments of this Village as probably existing in violation of the terms of this article. 
(4)  Notify in writing the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, agent and all other persons having an interest in the building as shown by the land records of the recorder of deeds of the county, of any building found by him to be a dangerous, or uncompleted building within the standards set forth in this article that: 
a.  The owner must vacate, repair, or demolish the building in accordance with the terms of the notice and this article. 
b.  The occupant or lessee must vacate the building, or may have it repaired in accordance with the notice and remain in possession. 
c.  The mortgagee, agent or other person having an interest in the building, as shown by the land records of the county recorder of deeds, may at his own risk repair, vacate, or demolish the building or have such work or act done, provided that any person notified under this subsection to repair, vacate, or demolish any building shall be given such reasonable time, not exceeding 30 days, as may be necessary to do, or have done, the work or act required by the notice. 
(5)  Set forth in the notice provided for in subsection (4) of this section, a description of the building or structure deemed unsafe, a statement of the particulars which make the building or structure a dangerous or uncompleted building, and an order requiring the dangerous or uncompleted buildings to be put in such condition as to comply with the terms of this article within such length of time, not exceeding 30 days, as is reasonable. 
(6)  Appear at all hearings conducted by the Director of Community Development, and testify as to the condition of dangerous or uncompleted buildings. 
(7)  Place a notice on all dangerous or uncompleted buildings reading as follows: "This building has been found to be a dangerous building by the Director of Community Development. This notice is to remain on this building until it is repaired, vacated, or demolished in accordance with the notice which has been given the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, or agent of this building, and all other persons having an interest in the building, as shown by the land records of the recorder of deeds of Cook County. It is unlawful to remove this notice." 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-224. - Boarding up buildings. 
    No building may be boarded up or otherwise enclosed, except as an emergency measure due to fire, explosion, vandalism or other casualty, or as an incident to the construction or repair of a building or structure pursuant to a permit issued for such construction or repair. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-225. - Penalty for disregarding notices or orders. 
(a)  The owner of any dangerous, uncompleted, or other building who shall fail to comply with any notice or order to repair, vacate or demolish such building given by any person authorized by this article to give such notice or order, or any person who violates any provision of this article, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(b)  The occupant or lessee in possession who fails to comply with any notice to vacate and who fails to repair the building in accordance with any notice given as provided for in this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(c)  Any person removing the notice provided for in section 18-223 shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-226. - Emergency cases. 
    In cases where it reasonably appears that there is immediate danger to the life or safety of any person unless a dangerous building is immediately repaired, vacated, or demolished, the Director of Community Development shall cause the immediate repair, vacation, or demolition of such dangerous building. The costs of such emergency repair, vacation or demolition of such dangerous building shall be borne by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-227. - Absence of owner; occupant; lessee; mortgagee from village. 
    In cases, except emergency cases, where the owner, occupant, lessee, or mortgagee is absent from the Village, all notices or orders provided for in this article shall be sent by registered mail to the owner, occupant, mortgagee, lessee and all other persons having an interest in the building as shown by the land records of the county recorder of deeds to the last known address of each, and a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the dangerous or uncompleted building to which it relates. Such mailing and posting shall be deemed adequate service. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-228. - Administrative liability. 
    No officer, agent, or employee of the Village shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-229. - Demolition; permit required. 
(a)  A permit is required to demolish any building or structure within the Village. Application for a demolition permit shall be made by the owner of such building or structure to the Director of Community Development. The fee for the issuance of a demolition permit as set forth in section 18-1 shall be paid at the time the permit is issued. 
(b)  No permit for demolition of a building or structure may be issued until rodents and vermin in the building or structure have been exterminated. All extermination shall be done by a licensed exterminator who shall file with the Director of Community Development a certificate evidencing compliance with this section. 
(c)  The Director of Community Development may waive the requirement for extermination if, upon inspection of the building or structure to be demolished, the Director finds that there is no evidence of rodents or vermin being present. Such waiver shall be noted on the face of the permit by the Director of Community Development. 
(d)  All water lines and sewer lines shall be terminated and approved by the Village Engineer. 
(e)  All demolition applications shall require a final grading plan to be submitted and approved by the Village Engineer before any permits can be issued. Final grading shall be completed and approved within 30 days of the structure being demolished. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-230. - Warning devices required during wrecking. 
    Any person in the process of wrecking buildings shall be responsible for the proper placing of warning signs, lights or other signals to denote all danger spots in and about the building being wrecked. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-231. - Wreckers to remove foundation; remove debris. 
    Wreckers shall make certain that the foundation remaining is removed and leveled to grade within 24 hours. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-232. - Width of moved building. 
    It shall be unlawful to move onto or along any street or alley in the Village any house, building or other structure or thing of a width which does not permit of a minimum clearance of 21/2 feet from the gutter face of the curb on each side of the street or alley; provided, however, that no building or other structure or thing of a width greater than 25 feet shall be so moved. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 18-233-18-239. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XX. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-240. - License required. 
    No person except a licensed housemover shall move any building within the limits of the Village, and every such person shall, before engaging in such occupation obtain a license therefore from the Community Development Department. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-241. - Bond and deposit required. 
(a)  Bond. Before any permit is granted to move a building or structure for which a permit is required, the person engaged in the work of wrecking or of moving the building or structure shall file with the Community Development Department a bond in the penal sum of $25,000.00 with sureties to indemnify, keep, and save harmless the Village against any loss, cost, damage, expense, judgment, or liability of any kind whatsoever the Village may suffer, or which may accrue against, be charged or be recovered from the Village, or any of its officials from or by reason or on account of accidents to persons or property during any such moving operations and from or by reason or on account of anything done under or by virtue of any permit granted for any moving operation. Such bond in each case shall extend over the period of and cover all such moving operation. 
(b)  Deposit. In addition to such bond, a cash deposit in the sum established by the Village of Niles shall be paid to the Community Development Department, to insure the safety of the Village streets, sidewalks and their complete restoration in the event of damages thereto, and to ensure the payment of any damages to private property. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-242. - Issuance of permit; moving route to be designated. 
    Upon execution of the bond and deposit and the payment of the permit fee the Director of Community Development shall issue a permit and in the case of house moving shall state specifically thereon the route to be taken. No variation from such route shall be permitted, except in cases of extreme emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-243. - Delays in moving. 
    No building in the process of being moved shall be allowed to stand in any street for more than four hours at any time, except in cases of accident to equipment or property which, in the judgment of the Director of Community Development, will necessitate repair or correction before the operation can safely proceed, or because of unavoidable delay due to outside causes, certified by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-244. - Warning lights required. 
    Red lights or flares shall be so displayed at night as to warn passersby and motorists of all danger spots in and about the building being moved. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 18-245-18-249. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXI. - VACANT LOTS 

Sec. 18-250. - Maintenance standards. 
    All vacant lots, unless a permit has been issued for new construction or off site construction use, must be maintained in the following manner: 
(1)  All spoil, and debris is to be removed. 
(2)  Grading plans must be approved and must not divert runoff onto neighboring sites. 
(3)  Any existing drainage structures are to be modified to match the new grade of the property. 
(4)  Erosion control is to be provided around all drainage structures. 
(5)  The property must be maintained in conformance with all other codes of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-251. - Escrow requirements. 
    Any vacant lot approved for off-site construction use shall deposit a restoration escrow amount as indicated in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 18-252. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 2, 1-24-17) 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; kennels and pet stores, § 14-61 et seq.; building contractors, § 18-51 et seq.; restaurants and food stores, § 54-26 et seq.; human relations, ch. 58; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 70; secondhand goods, ch. 74; vehicles for hire, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means all kinds of vocations, occupations, professions, enterprises, establishments, and all other kinds of activities and matters, together with all devices, machines, vehicles and appurtenances used therein, any of which are conducted for private profit, or benefit, either directly or indirectly, on any premises in this Village, or anywhere else within its jurisdiction. 
    Insignia or its singular number " insigne " means any tag, plate, badge, emblem, sticker, or other kind of device which may be required for any use in connection with any license. 
    License or licensee means, respectively, the words "permit," or "permittee," or the holder for any use or period of time of any similar privilege, wherever relevant to any provision of this article or other law or ordinance. 
    Premises means all lands, structures, places, and also the equipment and appurtenances connected or used therewith in any business, and also any personal property which is either affixed to, or is otherwise used in connection with any such business conducted on such premises. 
    Village License Officer or License Officer means Director of Community Development, or such other person as may be designated as Village License Officer or License Officer by act of the President and the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 19-3; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-27. - Compliance required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, either directly or indirectly, to conduct any business or nonprofit enterprise, or to use in connection therewith any vehicle, premises, machine or device, in whole or in part for which a license, or permit, is required by any law or ordinance of this village without a license or permit therefore being first procured and kept in effect at all such times as required by this article or other law or ordinances of this village. 
(b)  All persons engaged in businesses or occupations operating within the village for which a license is not specifically required by this Code, shall register with the Community Development Department, upon forms provided for that purpose. For the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the community, registration of businesses and/or occupations is hereby required in order to assist the village in determining the name of the owner and/or operator of such business and/or occupation, the address and telephone number of the person in charge of conducting such business and/or occupation, the type of business being conducted and whether the business is in compliance with the Zoning Ordinance and other ordinances of the village and state statutes. Such information is required for reasons, including, but not limited to: (1) providing the ability of the Police, Fire and other village departments to give notice in the event of emergencies; (2) permitting the Fire Department to better plan fire suppression and emergency medical response strategies and tactics; (3) planning periodic fire prevention, life/safety and other inspections; and (4) business sign inspections if applicable. For the clerical cost of maintaining a list of businesses and/or occupations within the village, a nominal fee, as required in the Appendix D Fee Schedule, shall be charged to the applicant at the time of registration and annually thereafter. Governmental bodies shall be exempt from such fees. 
(c)  Suspension or revocation of a license: Any license issued by the Village of Niles other than liquor licenses may be suspended or revocation recommended by the Village Manager or designee if: 
(1)  The applicant fails to provide all the necessary information required; 
(2)  The applicant provides false information; 
(3)  The applicant or the business is not in compliance with any provision of this code, state or federal laws, rules or regulations; 
(4)  The applicant has a background or history of violating local ordinance, state or federal law, rule or regulation; 
(5)  The public health, welfare or safety would be adversely affected by the continuation of the license; 
(6)  The license was issued in error; 
(7)  The applicant has outstanding fines, fees or monies due the village and has failed to pay them. 
(d)  Appeal: Any applicant or license holder may appeal a denial, suspension or recommendation of revocation of a license to Niles Adjudication. The appeal shall be in writing and submitted to the Village Adjudication Court Clerk within 15 days of denial, suspension or recommendation of revocation. 
(e)  Hearing appeal procedure: Niles Administrative Adjudication shall conduct the hearing regarding all appeals of a denial, suspension or revocation recommendation of any license pursuant to Chapter 2 Administration, Article VII Office of Administrative Adjudication, Division 2 Procedures. 
(Code 1965, § 19-4; Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 2-28-12; Ord. No. 2013-31, § 1, 5-28-13) 
Sec. 22-28. - Applicability to special sales. 
    This article shall apply to all business in the nature of special sales for which a license is required by any law or ordinance of this village and it shall be unlawful for any person, either directly or indirectly, to conduct any such sale except in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-5) 
Sec. 22-29. - One act constitutes doing business. 
    For the purpose of this article any person shall be deemed to be in business or engaging in nonprofit enterprises, and thus subject to the requirements of this article, when he does one act of: 
(1)  Selling any goods or service; 
(2)  Soliciting business or offering goods or services for sale or hire; 
(3)  Acquiring or using any vehicle or any premises in the village for business purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 19-6) 
Sec. 22-30. - Agents responsible for compliance. 
    The agents or other representatives of nonresidents who are doing business in this village shall be personally responsible for the compliance of their principals and of the businesses they represent within the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-7) 
Sec. 22-31. - Separate license for branch establishments. 
    A license shall be obtained in the manner prescribed in this article for each branch establishment or location of the business engaged in, as if each such branch establishment or location were a separate business. 
(Code 1965, § 19-8) 
Sec. 22-32. - Separate licenses for different businesses. 
    A person engaged in two or more businesses, occupations, or uses at the same location shall be required to obtain separate licenses for conducting each of such businesses, occupations or uses, as set forth in section 22-66. 
(Code 1965, § 19-9) 
Sec. 22-33. - No license required for mere delivery. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, no license shall be required of any person for any mere delivery in the village of any property purchased or acquired in good faith from such person at his regular place of business outside the village where no intent by such person is shown to exist to evade the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-10) 
Sec. 22-34. - Special permits for nonprofit enterprises. 
(a)  Issuance. The Community Development Department shall issue special permits, without the payment of any license fees, inspection fees, or other charges therefor, to any person or organization for the conduct or operation of a nonprofit enterprise, either regularly or temporarily, when he finds that the applicant operated without private profit for a public charitable, educational, literary, fraternal or religious purpose. 
(b)  Application for special permit. An applicant for a special permit shall submit an application therefor to the Community Development Department upon forms prescribed by the License Officer and shall furnish such additional information and make such affidavits as required. The applicant must furnish proof that the premises for which a waiver of business license fees or inspection fees is sought is exempt from real estate taxes pursuant to 35 ILCS 200/15-65, as amended. 
(c)  Special permittees must conform. A person or organization operating under a special permit shall operate his nonprofit enterprise in compliance with this article and all other applicable rules and regulations except as provided in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 19-11; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-35. - General powers; duties of License Officer. 
    Upon payment of the applicable license fee, the License Officer shall issue a license in the name of the village to any person qualified under the provisions of this article and shall: 
(1)  Make rules. Promulgate and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations necessary to the operation and enforcement of this article. 
(2)  Adopt forms. Adopt all forms and prescribe the information to be given therein as to character and other relevant matter for all necessary papers. 
(3)  Require affidavits. Require applicants to submit all affidavits and oaths necessary to the administration of this article. 
(4)  Obtain endorsement. Submit all applications, in a proper case, to interested village officials for their endorsements thereon as to compliance by the applicant with all village regulations which they have the duty of enforcing. 
(5)  Investigate. Investigate and determine the eligibility of any applicant for a license as prescribed in this article. 
(6)  Examine records. Examine the books and records of any applicant or licensee when reasonably necessary to the administration and enforcement of this article. 
(7)  Give notice. Notify any applicant of the acceptance or rejection of his application and shall, upon his refusal of any license or permit, at the applicant's request, state in writing the reasons therefor and deliver them to the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 19-12) 
Sec. 22-36. - Information declared confidential. 
    All information presented, by an applicant under this article, to the village shall be viewed by the village as public information unless, that information is deemed confidential by the applicant and that the information qualifies as an exception as defined by the 5 ILCS 140/7, Section 7 of the Freedom of Information Act. 
(Code 1965, § 19-13; Ord. No. 2001-19, § 2, 3-27-01) 
Sec. 22-37. - Qualifications of applicants. 
(a)  The provisions of this section apply to all business licenses of the village, except where a provision concerning a particular business contains a specific provision to the contrary; in which case, the specific provision shall apply. Applications for licenses shall be made to the Community Development Department containing, in part, the following: 
(1)  Citizenship. Citizenship shall be determined according to the following: 
a.  If the applicant is an individual, the applicant must furnish either proof of United States citizenship or status as a permanent resident alien. 
b.  If the applicant is a corporation, it must furnish a certificate of good standing, issued by the state secretary of state. 
c.  If the applicant is another form of business entity, e.g., partnership, joint venture, trust, etc., it must furnish documents establishing its status. 
(2)  Penal history. A statement of all felony convictions and misdemeanor convictions other than traffic offenses shall be given. 
(3)  License history. The applicant shall furnish the license history of the applicant, i.e., whether such person, in previously operating in this or another state under a license, has had such license revoked or suspended and the reasons therefor. 
(4)  Indebtedness to village. No license shall be issued to any person who is indebted to the village for any sum of money, is delinquent in the payment of sales taxes to the state, or who has outstanding parking violations or complaints; provided, however, that the village may issue the license if the person is contesting liability for or the amount of such debt or parking violations in a pending administrative or judicial proceeding. 
(5)  Compliance with zoning regulations. The applicant shall furnish such proof, as may be required, to the effect that the proposed use of any premises is not a violation of village zoning regulations. 
(b)  Any person convicted of an offense relative to the business or occupation for which they are seeking a business license or permit or who shows a history of moral turpitude, shall be disqualified from receiving such license of permit. 
(c)  Any applicant that misleads or is not truthful when applying for a business permit or license shall be disqualified from receiving such license or permit. 
(Code 1965, § 19-14; Ord. No. 1998-3, § 1, 1-27-98; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-38. - Application required; form; contents. 
    Every person required to procure a business license under any provision of this Code or any ordinance or law of the Village shall submit an application for such license to the Community Development Department. The application shall include the following features: 
(1)  Form. Be a written statement upon forms provided by the Community Development Department. 
(2)  Contents. Require the disclosure of all information necessary to compliance with section 22-37 and of any other information which the Community Development Department shall find to be reasonably necessary to the fair administration of this article. 
(3)  Payment of fees. Be accompanied by the full amount of the fees chargeable for such license. 
(4)  Prorating of fees. The fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the license. 
(5)  Application fee. Be accompanied by the payment of an application fee. Please refer to Appendix D for all related fees. 
(6)  Any business license application submitted after May 1 is subject to a late payment fee. Please refer to Appendix D for all related fees. 
(Code 1965, § 19-15; Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 2-28-12; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17; Ord. No. 2018-41, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Sec. 22-39. - Issuance of receipts. 
    Whenever a license cannot be issued at the time the application for the license is made, the Community Development Department shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the money paid in advance. Such receipt shall not be construed as the approval of the Community Development Department for the issuance of a license; nor shall it entitle or authorize the applicant to open or maintain any business contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-16; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-40. - Renewal and penalty. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be automatically renewed annually. A renewal license shall be mailed to the licensee and shall become effective upon payment of the applicable fee. The licensee shall inform the Village of any changes of ownership, location or operation of his business. A penalty for late payment, in the amount provided in Appendix E Penalties, is applicable for fees paid on or after May 1 of the annual license period or more than 30 days. 
(Code 1965, § 19-17; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-41. - Duplicate licenses. 
    A duplicate license or special permit shall be issued by the Community Development Department to replace any license previously issued, which was lost, stolen, defaced or destroyed without any willful conduct on the part of the licensee, attesting to such fact and the paying to the License Officer of a fee of $10.00. 
(Code 1965, § 19-18; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-42. - Supplemental licenses. 
    When a licensee places himself in a new status, the Community Development Department shall issue a supplemental license and such additional insignia as may be required. 
(Code 1965, § 19-19; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-43. - Denial. 
    The Community Development Department shall, upon denying any application submitted under the provisions of this article, refund to the applicant all fees paid in advance, provided the applicant is not otherwise indebted to the Village. When the issuance of a license is denied and any action is instituted by the applicant to compel its issuance, such applicant shall not engage in the business for which the license was denied unless a license is issued to him pursuant to a judgment ordering engagement in such business. 
(Code 1965, § 19-20; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-44. - Contents. 
    Each license issued under this article shall state upon its face the following: 
(1)  The name of the licensee and any other name under which such business is to be conducted. 
(2)  The kind and address of each business so licensed. 
(3)  The amount of license fee therefor. 
(4)  The dates of issuance and expiration thereof. 
(5)  Such other information as the Community Development Department shall determine. 
(Code 1965, § 19-22; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-45. - Conduct of licensee generally. 
    Every licensee under this article shall: 
(1)  Permit all reasonable inspections of his business and examinations of his books by public authorities so authorized by law. 
(2)  Ascertain and at all times comply with the laws of the United States, the laws of the state, and the ordinances of this village, as well as with any applicable rules and regulations of these units of government. 
(3)  At all times operate property in a manner consistent with the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of this village. 
(4)  Refrain from operating the licensed businesses on the premises after expiration of his license and during the period his license is revoked or suspended. 
(5)  Furnish to the Village on forms supplied by it the current names, home addresses and phone numbers of those persons to be notified in case of any emergency involving his premises or property. Notification of change of such names shall be in advance, if possible. 
(Code 1965, § 19-23; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-46. - Display of license and insignia. 
(a)  On premises. The license and insignia shall be displayed as follows: 
(1)  Licenses. Post and maintain such license upon the licensed premises in a place where it may be seen at all times. 
(2)  Insignia. Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection with the business premises on the inside glass part of the window of the establishment, facing the public way or on the inside glass part of the door opening on the public way. Such insignia shall be placed and maintained so as to be plainly visible from the public way. Where the licensed premises does not have a window facing a public way at street level, or a glass opening upon the public way, such insignia shall be affixed to the glass in the door, window, or other prominent place in the nearest proximity to the principal public entrance to such establishment and shall be placed and maintained so as to be plainly visible from such public entrance. 
(b)  On vehicles. The license and insignia shall be displayed according to the following provisions: 
(1)  Effect of this article. Any general or special license fees required by statute or ordinance for any kind of vehicle for the privilege of being operated upon the public highways shall not abrogate, limit or affect any further requirements of this article, or of other ordinances or laws, for additional and separate licenses, permits and insignia and fees for such vehicles, or other uses, for and relating to the privilege of using the same in the business so licensed. 
(2)  Motor vehicles. Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection with a licensed motor vehicle on the inside of the windshield of the vehicle or as may be otherwise prescribed by the License Officer or by law. 
(3)  Motorless vehicles. Affix any metal or other durable type of insignia delivered for use in connection with a wagon or other vehicle not operated by motor power securely on the outside of such vehicle. 
(c)  On persons. The license shall be carried on the licensee's person when he has no licensed business premises. 
(d)  On machines. Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection therewith upon any coin, vending, or other business machine or device, so that it may be seen at all times. 
(e)  Inoperative licenses, special permits and insignia. Do not allow any license, special permit or insignia to remain posted, displayed or used after the period for which it was issued has expired; or when it has been suspended or revoked, or for any other reason become ineffective. The licensee shall promptly return such inoperative license, special permit or insignia to the Community Development Department. 
(f)  Unlawful possession. Do not loan, sell, give or assign to any other person, or allow any other person to use or display, or to destroy, damage or remove, or to have in his possession, except as authorized by the Community Development Department or by law, any license or insignia which has been issued to the licensee. 
(Code 1965, § 19-24; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-47. - Change of location. 
    A licensee shall have the right to change the location of the licensed business, provided he shall: 
(1)  Obtain written permission from the License Officer for such change of location; and 
(2)  Refer to Appendix D for all related fees. 
(Code 1965, § 19-25; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-48. - Duty to keep records. 
    A licensee shall keep all records and books necessary for the computation of his license fee and for the enforcement of this article. The Community Development Department shall make its own determination as to the financial status of any business where the licensee has failed to keep books and records as required in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 19-26; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-49. - Transfer. 
(a)  Authorized. A licensee under this article shall have the right to transfer his license to another person, provided he shall: 
(1)  Obtain written permission from the Director of Community Development for such transfer; 
(2)  Execute the transfer in the form and under the conditions required by law and as prescribed by the Community Development Department; 
(3)  Promptly report the completed act of transfer to the Community Development Department; and 
(4)  Promptly surrender any license certificate and, when required by the Community Development Department, all licensing insignia. 
(b)  Issuance of new license. Upon the completion of a transfer of a license in compliance with subsection (a) of this section, the Community Development Department shall issue a new license and insignia to the transferee for the unexpired term of the old license. 
(c)  Effect of new license. The new license issued under this article's provisions shall authorize the transferee to engage in the same business at the same location or such other place as shall be approved by the Community Development Department and named in the new license. 
(d)  Transfer fee. The Community Development Department shall collect a transfer fee from the transferee prior to the issuance of the new license. Refer to Appendix D for all related fees. 
(Code 1965, § 19-27; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-50. - Authorized inspectors. 
    The following persons are authorized to conduct inspections in the manner prescribed in this section: 
(1)  License officer. The License Officer shall make all investigations reasonably necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(2)  Officials having duties. The Community Development Department shall have the authority to order the inspection of licensees, their businesses and premises, by all Village officials having duties to perform with reference to licensees or businesses. 
(3)  Police officers. All police officers shall inspect and examine businesses located within their respective jurisdictions or beats to enforce compliance with this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-28; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-51. - Right of entry. 
    All persons authorized to inspect licensees and businesses shall have the authority to enter, with or without a search warrant, at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1965, § 19-29) 
Sec. 22-52. - Duty of License Officer upon determination of violation. 
(a)  When an inspector shall determine that a violation of this article or of any law or ordinance of the village has been committed, it shall be the duty of such officer to issue a citation to the violator. 
(b)  The citation issued to the violator shall state the section of the ordinance that was not complied with. Further, the citation shall state the place, date and time that the violator shall appear in court. 
(c)  It shall be the further duty of the License Officer to appear in court on the date and time stated in the citation. 
(Code 1965, § 19-31) 
Sec. 22-53. - Procedure for revocation or suspension; generally. 
(a)  The president shall have the power to suspend or revoke any license other than a retail liquor license issued under the provisions of this Code for good and sufficient cause or if he determines that the licensee shall have violated any of the provisions of this Code or any of the statutes of this state, or laws of the United States. In the alternative, where the president deems it appropriate under the circumstances, he may assess a fine in lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, said fine not to exceed $500.00 for each violation. However, no such license shall be so revoked or suspended except after a public hearing first having given five days' written notice of the hearing to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. The public hearing shall be held before a hearing officer who shall be appointed by the president and who shall report his findings to the president. If the president shall determine after such hearing that a fine should be assessed or the license should be revoked or suspended, he shall, within a reasonable time, state the reasons for such determination in a written order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a copy of such order upon the licensee. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, when the conduct of any licensee, agent or employee is so inimical to the public health, safety and general welfare as to constitute a nuisance and thus give rise to an emergency, the president shall have the authority to summarily order the cessation of the business and the closing of the premises or to suspend or revoke the license. Unless the licensee waives the right in writing, within five days after he has acted summarily, the president or an appointed hearing officer shall conduct a special hearing for such action in respect to the summary order as may be therein determined. Notice of such hearing shall be given the affected person in the manner prescribed in this section. 
(c)  Costs of any such hearings shall be charged to the licensee in all cases resulting in assessment of a fine in suspension or revocation of a license. 
(d)  Review of final decisions of assessment of fines, revocation or suspension of licenses may be had as provided by law. 
(e)  This procedure shall be followed in all cases unless otherwise specified in this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 19-34; Ord. No. 1994-60, § 1, 10-25-94) 
Sec. 22-54. - Collection of unpaid fees. 
(a)  The amount of any unpaid fee, the payment of which is required under this article, shall constitute a debt due the village. 
(b)  The Village Attorney shall, at the direction of the Community Development Department, institute a civil suit in the name of the Village to recover any such unpaid fee. 
(c)  No civil judgment, or any act by the Village Attorney, the Community Development Department or the violator shall bar or prevent a criminal prosecution for each and every violation of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-36; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-55. - Duration. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall commence on May 1 of the year for which such license is issued and shall expire on April 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1965, § 19-37) 
Sec. 22-56. - Authority to require bond. 
    The Board of Trustees may from time to time designate businesses, occupations and uses that shall be required to furnish a surety bond in favor of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 19-38) 
Secs. 22-57-22-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEE SCHEDULE 

Sec. 22-66. - Fee schedule. 
    License fees for businesses, occupations, or other uses are referenced in Appendix D for all related fees. Other provisions affecting such businesses, occupations, or other uses shall remain in full force and effect without regard to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1965, §§ 8-61, 12-31, 19-39, 19-70; Ord. No. 1994-1, § 1, 1-25-94; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 1, 9-27-94; Ord. No. 1995-35, § 1, 6-27-95; Ord. No. 1995-53, § 1, 11-28-95; Ord. No. 1996-1, § 4, 1-23-96; Ord. No. 1996-29, § 4, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 4, 4-28-98; Ord. No. 2000-62, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 2006-08, § 2, 1-24-06; Ord. No. 2008-30, § 1, 6-25-08; Ord. No. 2008-49, § 1, 10-29-08; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 1, 5-27-09; Ord. No. 2010-23, § 2, 4-9-10; Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 2-28-12) 
Cross reference- Amusements and entertainments, ch. 10. 
Sec. 22-67. - Licensee user charges. 
(a)  Imposition of charges. In addition to the license fees set forth in section 22-66, the licensee shall be charged, and by the acceptance of the license agrees to pay, the cost of village personnel who are required to perform additional duties as a result of any event, promotion, feature presentation, etc. of a business to which a business license has been issued. Additional duties include, but are not limited to, crowd control, traffic control, code enforcement or work required to be done outside of regular shift hours of village personnel. The user charge shall be paid in advance wherever practicable. 
(b)  Contest of amount charged. In the event a licensee wants to contest the amount charged, the licensee must notify in writing the Village Manager within seven working days from the date of the village invoice for such additional services. The letter of contest must set forth with specificity the basis for the contest. Upon receipt of the notice of contest, the Village Manager shall set the contest for hearing not more than 14 days after receipt of such notice and shall notify the licensee in writing of the time and date of the hearing. After holding a hearing, the Village Manager may confirm, modify or nullify the amount of the licensee user charge. 
(Ord. No. 1994-63, § 1, 11-22-94) 
Sec. 22-68. - Exemption from business license fee. 
    The following Niles Park District facilities are exempt from paying the Niles Business License Fees for Signs and Food Vending Machines: 
Iceland Skate & Swim. 
Niles Teen Center. 
Tam Tennis & Fitness Center. 
Golf View Recreation Center. 
Pioneer Park. 
Niles Park District Leisure Center. 
Niles Park District Offices. 
Niles Park District Facilities (excluding Howard Street Inn and Fairway Banquets). 
    All business licenses that are exempt from fees under this section must register with the Village of Niles. Please refer to Appendix D for all related fees. 
(Ord. No. 2007-29, § 1, 6-26-07; Ord. No. 2012-10, § 1, 2-28-12) 
Secs. 22-69-22-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BARBERS, BARBERSHOPS, COSMETOLOGISTS, BEAUTY SHOPS 

Sec. 22-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Barber means any person engaging in the practice of barbering. 
    Barber school means any building, room, place or establishment where the art of barbering is taught, for a consideration. 
    Barbering means the practice of shaving or trimming the beard or cutting and/or dressing the hair of patrons for a consideration. 
    Barbershop means any building, room, place or establishment wherein barbering is practiced or performed. 
    Beauty school means any building, room, place or establishment for the teaching of the art of cosmetology. 
    Beauty shop or beauty salon means any business establishment devoted to the cutting, washing, dyeing and/or styling of hair, and also including the cosmetic treatment of skin and of fingernails and toenails.
