(Code 1965, § 7-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-87. - License required. 
    No person shall establish, maintain or operate a barbershop or a barber school, or a beauty shop or salon or a beauty school, without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 7-2) 
Sec. 22-88. - Application for license; investigation. 
    The application for a license required by this article shall be made to the Community Development Department. The applicant shall state the location of the proposed premises, the number of barber or beauty shop chairs installed, and the space to be occupied for barbering, beauty shop services, washrooms and office. Such application shall be investigated by the Director of Community Development to determine whether the provisions of this article have been met. 
(Code 1965, § 7-3; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-89. - License fee. 
    The annual license fee shall be the amount prescribed for barbershops and beauty shops as contained in section 22-66. 
(Code 1965, § 7-4) 
Sec. 22-90. - Sanitary regulations. 
    The owner or manager and all employees of any barbershop or beauty shop shall conform strictly to the following sanitary regulations: 
(1)  Every barbershop and beauty shop shall be located in a building or room which is well ventilated, and well lighted, and of such construction that it may be easily cleaned. 
(2)  Every barbershop and beauty shop, together with the furniture, fixtures, instruments, and linen therein, shall be kept in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all times. 
(3)  Every barbershop and beauty shop shall be at all times supplied with hot and cold running water. All bowls, basins, jars and similar receptacles shall be antiseptically cleansed immediately after use. 
(4)  The use of lump alum, styptic pencils, sponges or powderpuffs is prohibited. The use of styptic, alum in powder or liquid form and individual applicators is permitted. 
(5)  All jars and bottles shall be securely closed and labeled. 
(6)  All creams, lotions, and other cosmetics used for patrons shall be kept in clean, closed containers. 
(7)  Creams and other semisolid substances shall be dipped from the container with a sterile article or spatula, or other automatic dispensing device. Removing such substances with the fingers is prohibited. 
(8)  Combs and hair brushes shall be kept in a sanitary condition at all times and shall be cleansed thoroughly after each use with soap and hot water. All razors, shears, clippers and applicators, cups or other instruments and appliances after being used on any patron shall be thoroughly sterilized immediately, either by boiling for three minutes in water, or kept for 15 minutes in a solution of one of the following; namely: fifty percent alcohol, five percent carbolic acid, 20 percent formaldehyde, or other established germicidal solution. Thereafter until used, such instruments and appliances shall be kept in a sterilized cabinet full of the fumes of formaldehyde gas solution, changed daily. 
(9)  Glass or metal articles which cannot be boiled shall be cleansed in soap and water, wiped in alcohol, and kept in a formaldehyde sterilizer, or immersed in an approved germicidal solution for not less than one hour. 
(10)  No barbershop or beauty shop shall be used as a sleeping room or dormitory, eating or dining room, restaurant or food establishment. 
(11)  Every barbershop or beauty shop employee shall thoroughly cleanse his hands after serving each patron. 
(12)  Only unused freshly laundered towels including dry towels, steam towels and wash cloths shall be used for each patron. All clean towels shall be kept in a closed cabinet until used. The headrest shall be covered with a freshly laundered towel or fresh paper for each patron. In cutting the hair of any patron, a newly laundered towel or a fresh paper neck strip shall be placed around the neck to prevent the haircloth from touching the skin. When shampooing the hair of any patron, a newly laundered towel shall be placed around the neck to prevent the haircloth or rubber apron from touching the skin. 
(13)  No person having an infectious or contagious disease shall be permitted to work in a barbershop or beauty shop, and no proprietor or manager shall permit any person suffering from a communicable disease or from any venereal disease in a communicable form to be employed, nor shall any service be performed on any person known to have an infectious, contagious, or venereal disease. In order to obtain a release to work, the person must have a clearance statement from his doctor. 
(14)  All tools, instruments, or appliances shall be thoroughly sterilized immediately after their use on a house call, or other use upon any sick person. 
(15)  All barbers and cosmetologists shall be attired in clean washable coverall outer garments, preferably white coats while working on patrons. 
(16)  The sanitary rules for barbershops and for beauty shops, promulgated by the department of professional regulation, or of any other agency of the state or of the county authorized to promulgate such rules, shall be given the same force and effect as if they were set forth in this article insofar as they are not inconsistent with the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 7-5) 
Sec. 22-91. - Inspections. 
    The Director of Community Development or his agents shall cause periodic inspections to be made of all barbershops and beauty shops licensed under this article to determine whether the health and sanitary regulations of this article are being observed. 
(Code 1965, § 7-6; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 22-92-22-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CIGARETTES, CIGARS AND TOBACCO 

Sec. 22-111. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or give away cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form within the village without first having obtained a cigarette, cigar or tobacco retail distribution license. This license shall be required regardless of the method of sale or dispensing and shall include the sales and dispensing by self-help, manual service, mechanical service or coin-operated device. 
(Code 1965, § 9-1; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 3, 4-28-98) 
Sec. 22-112. - Application for license. 
    Any person, desiring to obtain a license to sell cigarettes, cigars and tobacco shall make written application for that purpose to the Department of Community Development in which shall be set forth the full name and address of the applicant, and the name and address of the business firm or corporation at which such sales are proposed to be made. 
(Code 1965, § 9-2; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-113. - Cigarette machines to be registered; location. 
(a)  Before any cigarette or tobacco vending machine may be installed for use, it shall be registered in the office of the Department of Community Development by the owner of the machine, stating the name and address of the place where the machine is to be installed and the nature of the business which is or will be conducted therein. Only those persons holding valid licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be permitted to have such vending machines on their premises. 
(Code 1965, § 9-3; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-114. - License fee. 
    The license fee to sell cigarettes, cigars or tobacco within the village shall be as provided in section 22-66. 
(Code 1965, § 9-4) 
Sec. 22-115. - Scope of license. 
    The license required by this article shall authorize the licensee named therein to sell cigarettes, cigars and tobacco at the place designated therein only. 
(Code 1965, § 9-5) 
Sec. 22-116. - Unregistered cigarette machine. 
    It is unlawful for any person to install, use or permit the installation or use of any cigarette vending machine at any place unless the machine has been registered in the Department of Community Development. 
(Code 1965, § 9-8; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-117. - Inspection; enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the Department of Community Development and License Officers, and they are hereby authorized and empowered, from time to time, to inspect and examine all places where cigarettes are licensed to be sold within the Village, with the view of ascertaining whether the laws of the state, the provisions of this article and other ordinances of the Village in relation to the sale of cigarettes are being complied with at such places. It shall be their duty to cause all such laws and ordinances to be vigorously enforced. It shall be the duty of all persons licensed to sell cigarettes within the Village, upon demand of the Department of Community Development, to furnish to the department for its inspection, samples of all cigarettes sold or offered for sale by them, which samples of cigarettes shall be analyzed by or under the direction of the Department of Community Development, and a record of such analysis shall be made and kept in their office for the inspection of the public. 
(Code 1965, § 9-9; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-118. - Sale to minors; revocation of license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or furnish any cigars, cigarettes or tobacco in any form to any person under the age of 18 years. 
(b)  The sale of cigarettes, cigars and tobacco to minors as prohibited by this Code shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license to sell such products, irrespective of whether the sale to minors is made by the licensee or an agent of the licensee. 
(Code 1965, §§ 9-10, 9-12) 
Sec. 22-119. - Scavenging for discarded tobacco. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pick or gather up from the public streets, alleys or thoroughfares of the village, or in any restaurant, hotel or any public building in the village, any cigar or cigarette butt or stump, or the waste, unused or unburnt portion of any cigar, tobacco or cigarette for the purpose or with the intent of bartering or selling the same or disposing of the same for use in any form of manufactured tobacco. 
(Code 1965, § 9-11) 
Sec. 22-120. - Possession by minors; parental responsibility. 
(a)  No minor under 18 years of age shall buy or possess any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms. No person shall sell, buy for, distribute samples of or furnish any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms, to any minor under 18 years of age. For the purpose of this section, "smokeless tobacco" means any tobacco products that are suitable for dipping or chewing. 
(b)  Any parent or legal guardian who knowingly permits a minor entrusted to his/her care to violate subsection (a) hereof shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1995-25, § 1, 4-25-95) 
Sec. 22-121. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, repealed § 22-121, which pertained to sale of tobacco products is primary activity and derived from Ord. No. 1997-34, § 1, 10-28-97. 
Sec. 22-122. - Self-service sales prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, or display tobacco products for sale at any location where the consumer can acquire those products through self-service. All tobacco products will be displayed from behind a sales/service counter so that no consumer can access tobacco products without assistance by an employee of the licensee. This restriction shall not apply to customer self-service as described in section 22-113, cigarette machines to be registered; location. 
(Ord. No. 2002-37, § 1, 6-25-02) 
Secs. 22-123-22-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DANCES AND DANCING 

Sec. 22-141. - License required for dance halls; dancing schools. 
    It shall be unlawful to hold or conduct any public dance, or to hold or conduct classes in dancing, or to give instruction in dancing for hire, in any hall or place within the village until the hall or other place in which the dancing is held has been licensed as a public dance hall or dancing school. The fee payable for each license granted under this article shall be as provided in section 22-66. Dances held in connection with a picnic, for which a permit has been issued, shall not be governed by any of the provisions in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 5-4) 
Sec. 22-142. - Prerequisites to dance hall or dancing school license; license to be posted. 
    No license for a public dance hall or dancing school shall be issued until it shall be found that the place for which it is issued complies with and conforms to all laws, ordinances, health and fire regulations applicable thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 5-5) 
Sec. 22-143. - Revocation of dance hall or dancing school licenses. 
    The license for any public dance hall or dancing school may be revoked by the village president for the violation of any provision of this article or any other ordinance or law relating to such places, or rules or regulations promulgated under this article. If at any time the license of a public dance hall or dancing school shall be revoked, at least three months shall elapse before another license shall be granted to the manager, owner, or lessee of such dance hall or dancing school. 
(Code 1965, § 5-6) 
Secs. 22-144-22-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VENDING MACHINES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-166-22-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOOD VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 22-176. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain any machine or automatic device of any kind within the village for the sale, vending or distribution of any goods, wares, or merchandise for human consumption, including fruits, ice cream, candy and nuts, bakery goods, sandwiches, soups, soft drinks, coffee or other similar beverages, without first having obtained a license for each such vending machine as provided for in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 11-17) 
Sec. 22-177. - License fee; expiration; prorating. 
    The license fee to be charged for each machine or automatic vending device described in section 22-176 shall be as prescribed in section 22-66 for food vending machines or devices. All licenses issued under the provisions of this division shall expire on April 30 following the date of issuance, provided that if less than six months of the annual license period shall have expired at the time when such license is issued, the full license fee shall be charged. If six or more months of the annual license period shall have expired, one-half of the full license fee shall be charged. 
(Code 1965, § 11-18) 
Sec. 22-178. - Application for license; inspection; approval. 
    Application for a license to install, keep, maintain or use automatic food vending machines regulated by this article shall be made in writing to the Community Development Department and approved by the Department of Community Development. The application shall contain the name of the applicant, if an individual, the names of the partners, if a co-partnership, or the names of the principal officers, if a corporation, and shall include the location of the places at which such automatic food vending machines shall be kept, maintained or operated, and the number of machines for which licenses are desired. The applicant shall also set forth such further information as may be required by the Department of Community Development, in order to inform the department, as to the types of machines, the kinds of food to be dispensed therefrom and the location thereof, before any such license shall be issued. The type of vending machine intended to be operated shall be approved by the Department of Community Development, which shall also cause an inspection to be made of the premises where such machine is to be located to determine the character and fitness of the premises from the standpoint of ensuring protection of the food or beverage from improper handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other contamination. 
(Code 1965, § 11-19; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-179. - Cooperation with Department of Community Development. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons operating any food vending machines, upon demand of the Department of Community Development, to furnish, for its inspection, samples of all such food and drink, which samples may be analyzed by or under the direction of the department of Department of Community Development, or its agents, furnish keys for the vending machines, so that the contents of the vending machines may be inspected in company with a representative that the owner or operator of the vending machine may designate. 
(Code 1965, § 11-20; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-180. - General wholesomeness; periodic inspections. 
    All articles of food purveyed by means of automatic food vending machines shall be clean, wholesome, free from taint, decay or infection, and shall contain no poisonous, deleterious, or injurious ingredients of any kind or quantity, so as to render such article of food injurious or detrimental to health. The Department of Community Development and the License Officer shall have the authority to make periodic inspections of the automatic food vending machines, their locations, and the articles of food purveyed therefrom for the purpose of determining the purity and wholesomeness of the products vended and the preparation, wrapping, and handling of such products, and to see that all requirements of this division and other ordinances of the village are complied with, including the operation and use of the vending machines, to guard against improper handling, distribution and contamination of food purveyed thereby. 
(Code 1965, § 11-21; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-181. - Location. 
    The machine location shall be such as to minimize the potential for contamination of the product, shall be easily cleanable, and shall be kept clean. No automatic food vending machine shall be installed or kept for use in any toilet or washroom. 
(Code 1965, § 11-22) 
Sec. 22-182. - Exterior construction. 
    The exterior construction of the vending machine shall be such as to facilitate cleaning and to minimize the entrance of insects and rodents, and the exterior of the machine shall be kept clean. 
(Code 1965, § 11-23) 
Sec. 22-183. - Interior construction. 
    All interior surfaces and component parts of the vending machine shall be so designed and constructed as to permit easy cleaning and shall be kept clean. All product contact surfaces of the machine shall be of smooth, nontoxic, corrosion resistant, and relatively nonabsorbent material, and shall be capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and bactericidal treatment by normal procedures. 
(Code 1965, § 11-24) 
Sec. 22-184. - Water supply. 
    Water used in vending machines shall be from a source approved by the Department of Community Development. 
(Code 1965, § 11-25; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-185. - Waste disposal. 
    All waste shall be properly disposed of and, pending disposition, shall be kept in suitable containers so as to prevent creating a nuisance. 
(Code 1965, § 11-26) 
Sec. 22-186. - Source of supply. 
    All foods, beverages and ingredients shall be manufactured, processed and prepared in commissaries or establishments which comply with all applicable local, state and federal laws and regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 11-27) 
Sec. 22-187. - Milk machines. 
    Milk and fluid milk products offered for sale through vending machines shall be dispensed only in individual, original containers or from bulk containers into which such product was placed at the milk plant. All multi-use parts of any bulk milk vending machine which comes into direct contact with the milk or milk product shall be effectively cleaned and bactericidally treated at the milk plant. 
(Code 1965, § 11-28) 
Sec. 22-188. - Regulations declared additional. 
    The owners or operators of any food vending machines shall be governed by the regulations set out in this division, which shall not be exclusive of other regulations or rules promulgated by the Department of Community Development. 
(Code 1965, § 11-16) 
Sec. 22-189. - Permitting unlicensed machines on premises prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, keep or maintain or use, or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use upon his premises of any automatic food vending machine, for which automatic food vending machine a license has not been obtained in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1965, § 11-29) 
Secs. 22-190-22-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS 

Sec. 22-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm systems means and includes the following: 
(1)  Burglary alarm. A security system designed to allow notification to the police department of any unauthorized intrusion of a building or area. 
(2)  Holdup alarm. A security system designed to allow notification to the police department during normal business hours or during occupancy by authorized persons. 
(3)  Automatic dialer alarm. A device normally used with a telephone which when activated reproduces a prerecorded voice or digital coded message to report a robbery, burglary, ambush or other emergency message. 
    Banking hours means the time during which a financial institution is open for normal transaction of business with the banking public. 
    Banking office means the main office of any financial institution and any branch thereof. 
    Branch means any branch bank, branch office, branch agency, additional office or any branch place of business located within the limits of the village at which deposits are received. 
    Cash dispensing machines and automatic tellers means machines designed to automatically dispense currency by use of a coded identification card or to accept deposits and transact other bank services automatically. 
    Financial institution means any bank that has a state or national charter or any savings and loan association that has a state or federal charter. 
    Teller's station means a location in a financial institution at which customers routinely conduct transactions with the institution which involve the exchange of funds, including a walk-up or drive-in teller's station or window. 
    Security officer means an officer or employee of a financial institution designated by the board of directors thereof and charged with the responsibility for overall administration of matters relating to protection and security. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-212. - Inspection. 
    The Chief of Police shall test, inspect and evaluate the institution's equipment and any required records. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-2) 
Sec. 22-213. - Security officer. 
    The board of directors of each financial institution shall notify the Chief of Police of the name of the officer or other employee of the institution it has designated as its security officer for purposes of implementing and complying with the provisions of this article. The security officer shall act as liaison between the institution and the village in all matters of installation, maintenance and operation of security devices, the formulation, filing and implementation of its security plan, and the maintenance of all records required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-3) 
Sec. 22-214. - Security plan. 
    Each financial institution with established banking hours shall, no later than 90 days subsequent to the passage of this article, and any financial institution which shall establish banking hours after the passage of this article shall, within 30 days after its establishment, file with the police department a written copy of a security plan for each of its banking offices located within the village designed to discourage robberies, burglaries and larcenies and to assist in the identifications and apprehension of persons who commit such acts. The plan shall meet applicable federal security standards promulgated pursuant to the Federal Bank Protection Act of 1968 and standards set by the village and, in addition thereto, shall contain provisions for the notification to the police department of any change of banking hours, hours employees shall be on the premises, notification of the testing times and other information that may be deemed necessary in furtherance of this article. Each security plan shall also provide for an in-service training program for the training and periodic retraining of the employees in their responsibilities under the security plan, including but not limited to the proper use of security devices and proper employee conduct during and after a robbery. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-4) 
Sec. 22-215. - Testing police-connected alarms. 
    The transmitting and receiving equipment of police-connected alarms shall be tested by the transmitting of an actual alarm condition at such times as may be deemed necessary by the Chief of Police. Procedures for the testing of police-connected alarms shall be arranged by the institution's security officer in liaison with the Chief of Police. Such procedures shall be kept on file with the agencies involved and shall be reviewed and updated not less than twice each calendar year. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-5) 
Sec. 22-216. - Semiannual inspections. 
    The Chief of Police, with the cooperation and assistance of the security officer of the institution, shall conduct a test of all security devices of the financial institution, inspect the required records, and evaluate the institution's security plan two times in each calendar year. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-6) 
Sec. 22-217. - Physical security of building and premises. 
    Construction materials and exterior and interior designs of buildings housing financial institutions and their branches, or enclosures housing cash dispensing/automatic teller machines must meet minimum federal security standards promulgated by the appropriate federal agency pursuant to the Federal Bank Protection Act of 1968 and standards set by the village, including, but not limited to, the construction and design of safes, vaults, public areas, office areas, tellers' stations, and all possible points of entry such as doors, windows, transoms, skylights and depositories. In addition thereto, each financial institution shall undertake such other physical security measures on or about its property that are deemed reasonable and necessary by the Chief of Police of the village and the police department to protect the premises and discourage burglaries and holdups thereon. If the financial institution asked to undertake these further physical security measures by the Chief of Police disagrees with the findings, then it has the right to appeal that decision by going directly to the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-7) 
Sec. 22-218. - Alarm system required. 
    Each financial institution within the village shall install and maintain upon each of its premises an adequate alarm system. A facility separated from the main bank office which contains a drive-in operation or a cash dispensing/automatic teller machine shall be protected by its own alarm system, unless this requirement is waived by the village. Each premises' system shall consist of protective circuits, a control instrument, an on-premises signaling device and an off-premises alarm panel. All alarm systems must be installed by a person that has first complied with the provisions of this Code. 
(1)  Protective circuits. All devices used in the protective circuits shall be of a design and manufacture that have been proved effective and, where appropriate, should carry the Underwriters' Laboratories Inc., seal or an equivalent thereof. A premises' system shall include, but not be limited to, the following individual circuits: Perimeter and/or public area; teller and/or officers' desks; safe, vault and night depository; anti-ambush. 
(2)  Control instrument. The control instrument shall be of a design and manufacture that have been proved effective and, where appropriate, carry the Underwriters' Laboratories Inc., seal or an equivalent thereof. The installation of the control instrument shall meet Underwriters' Laboratories Inc., specifications as a grade A local bank and mercantile vault alarm or the equivalent thereof. 
(3)  Signaling devices. Each premises shall be equipped with an intermediate signaling device which when activated by the control instrument issues the warning signal to the appropriate person on premises and to the off-premises alarm panel. In addition, the on-premises system shall be capable of indicating through the use of an annunciator panel or a lock-out signaling device the location of the activating device. When an annunciator panel is used, one indicator shall be used for no more than two teller stations, or no more than two officers' desks, or no more than two other remote locations. When an outside bell is used as a signaling device in connection with the control instrument, the bell shall be designed to sound for at least five minutes and not more than 15 minutes and to stop and reset if the attack has subsided within that set time interval. If the attack continues, the bell shall be designed to continue to ring and the system must attempt to reset at the end of each set time interval. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-8) 
Sec. 22-219. - Lighting systems. 
    Each financial institution shall provide for the illumination during the hours of darkness, of the general business area if the area is visible from outside the banking office. In liaison with the Chief of Police and as part of the security plan, provisions shall be made for the illumination of night depositories, walk-up teller areas, drive-in teller windows, the general drive-in area and any remote cash dispensing/automatic teller machine. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-9) 
Sec. 22-220. - Surveillance systems. 
    Each financial institution shall provide for the installation and maintenance of photographic, recording, monitoring or other such device capable of reproducing images of persons exiting the premises through the normally used business exit doors. Such devices shall be reasonably silent in operation and be designed so as to preclude identification of operation by the general public. Operation of such surveillance systems may be automatic, activated by the alarm system or by a separate signal device. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-10) 
Sec. 22-221. - Preplan agreement. 
    Each financial institution shall cooperate with the police department in establishing a preplanned agreement encompassing what actions are to be taken by institution personnel when an alarm is activated. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-11) 
Sec. 22-222. - Holdup alarms. 
    A holdup alarm shall be activated only when a robbery is believed to be imminent, is in progress, or has taken place. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-12) 
Sec. 22-223. - Discontinuance or modification. 
    A financial institution shall not discontinue, alter or otherwise modify its security system or security plan as provided in this article without sending prior notice of such intended action to the Chief of Police. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-13) 
Sec. 22-224. - Fees. 
    An annual inspection fee shall be payable by each financial institution, subject to the provisions of this article. This inspection fee shall be separate from and in addition to any other fee provided for under this Code which may be applicable to such financial institutions. Please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 123/4-14; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 22-225-22-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SELF-SERVICE LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

Sec. 22-246. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment means any building, structure, room, establishment, or portion thereof available to and for the use of the general public for the purpose of washing, drying, extracting moisture from, or dry cleaning wearing apparel, table, bed or other household linens, towels, curtains, draperies, rugs, blankets, or other materials through the use of coin- or noncoin-operated machines or devices. 
(Code 1965, § 18-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-247. - Qualified attendant required. 
    A qualified attendant shall be on the premises at all times during which a self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment is open to the public. For the purpose of this section, the term "qualified attendant" is defined as a person trained in the use or operation and maintenance of coin-operated or noncoin-operated laundry or dry cleaning devices. 
(Code 1965, § 18-12) 
Sec. 22-248. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating any self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment within the village without first obtaining a license therefor. Any person seeking a license for the operation of a self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall comply with this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 18-13) 
Sec. 22-249. - Toilet facilities required. 
    A minimum of one toilet and one lavatory for each sex shall be installed in each self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1965, § 18-15) 
Sec. 22-250. - Inspection; approval prerequisite to license. 
    No license for the operation of a self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall be issued until the premises upon which such business is to be conducted, the equipment to be installed and the solvents, if any, to be used have been approved by the Community Development Department and the Fire Department. 
(Code 1965, § 18-16; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-251. - General maintenance. 
    Every premises used for the operation of a self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall be at all times kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1965, § 18-17) 
Sec. 22-252. - Refuse receptacle required. 
    Every owner, operator, manager or proprietor of a self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall cause an appropriate refuse receptacle to be situated upon its premises in a location easily accessible to the patrons. 
(Code 1965, § 18-18) 
Sec. 22-253. - Interior to be visible. 
    No self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall be open to the general public unless the area therein accessible to the general public is visible from the outside thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 18-19) 
Sec. 22-254. - Lighting. 
    Every premises used for the operation of a self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall provide for those areas used by the patrons thereof natural light of at least ten footcandles or artificial light of at least thirty footcandles. 
(Code 1965, § 18-20) 
Sec. 22-255. - Type; location of coin changers. 
    All coin-changing devices which may be situated within the confines of any self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall be of a vault type and located in a position as conspicuous to the exterior vantage points thereof as may be practicable. 
(Code 1965, § 18-21) 
Sec. 22-256. - Music; amusement prohibited. 
    No coin-operated music or other amusement devices may be situated upon the premises of any self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1965, § 18-22) 
Sec. 22-257. - Height; temperature; humidity. 
    No self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall be conducted upon any premises in which the clear height between the ceiling and the finished floor is less than nine feet, or in which the temperature and humidity therein are such as might endanger the health of persons utilizing the facilities therein. 
(Code 1965, § 18-23) 
Sec. 22-258. - Electrical outlets. 
    No electrical outlets shall be available for use by the general public in any self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1965, § 18-24) 
Sec. 22-259. - Certain appliances not to be accessible to public. 
    All facilities or mechanisms for the heating and softening of water, for the production of heat, for the operation of venting and cooling devices, for the operation and maintenance of dry cleaning devices and/or for the storage of dry cleaning solvents shall be inaccessible to the general public in every self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1965, § 18-25) 
Sec. 22-260. - Make; type; design of appliances; approval re-required. 
    Every washing, extracting, drying or dry cleaning device which shall be installed or maintained in a self-service laundry shall be of a make, type or design having principal component parts which have been tested and approved by, and which bear the tested label of, an organization nationally recognized as an authority on safety with respect to the type of device or part concerned. All equipment must have the approval of the Community Development Department and the Fire Department. 
(Code 1965, § 18-26; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-261. - Maximum capacity of appliances. 
    No washing, drying or extracting device having a capacity rated by its manufacturer to be in excess of 50 pounds of dry weight of materials shall be installed or maintained in any self-service laundry, and no cleaning device so rated as having a capacity in excess of 25 pounds dry weight of materials shall be installed or maintained in any self-service dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1965, § 18-27) 
Sec. 22-262. - Certain appliances to be inoperable when door is open. 
    Every dryer, extractor and dry cleaning device situated within any self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment shall be so designed that it is inoperable when the door thereof is open and, furthermore, every dry cleaning device so situated shall be so designed that its door cannot be opened during the course of its normal operating cycle, or upon an abnormal interruption thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 18-28) 
Sec. 22-263. - Temperature of wash water. 
    Any person operating a self-service laundry shall cause water of a temperature of not less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit to be provided to each washer for use therein during the wash cycle. 
(Code 1965, § 18-29) 
Sec. 22-264. - Dryers to be openable from inside. 
    No dryer shall be installed which is not capable of having its door opened from the interior thereof upon the application of outward pressure against it. 
(Code 1965, § 18-30) 
Sec. 22-265. - Dry cleaners to be accessible from front only. 
    Every dry cleaning device situated in a self-service dry cleaning establishment shall be accessible to the general public from its front only. 
(Code 1965, § 18-31) 
Sec. 22-266. - Inspections by Department of Community Development and Fire Department required. 
    It shall be the duty of the Community Development Department and the Fire Department to inspect each self-service laundry or dry cleaning establishment at least once every six months in order to ascertain that such establishment is operated in compliance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, amended section 22-266 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former section 22-266 pertained to type; construction of dry cleaners, and derived from Code 1965, § 18-32. 
Secs. 22-267-22-295. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, repealed §§ 22-266-22-274, which pertained to dry cleaners and derived from Code 1965, §§ 18-32-18-41. 
ARTICLE IX. - MOTELS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-296. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motel means a building or group of buildings containing sleeping accommodations for transients only and in which no facilities for cooking shall be provided. 
(Code 1965, § 20-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-297. - Size of rooms; closet and toilet facilities required; cooking prohibited. 
    A motel building shall contain single sleeping rooms with a minimum area of 180 square feet, and each sleeping room or suite of rooms shall have, in addition, attached or connected thereto, toilet and bath facilities of dimensions of not less than five feet by eight feet. Under no circumstances shall preparation of food be permitted in nor shall any cooking facilities be provided in any room or suite of rooms in a motel. The provisions of this section shall not apply to a room or suite of rooms occupied by a manager or agent of the motel. 
(Code 1965, § 20-4) 
Sec. 22-298. - Manager or agent required. 
    There shall at all times be a person in charge of the motel and responsible for its proper maintenance and operation. 
(Code 1965, § 20-5) 
Sec. 22-299. - Heating. 
    All motel rooms shall be heated by an automatic heating system. 
(Code 1965, § 20-6) 
Sec. 22-300. - Register required. 
    The operator of a motel shall keep a register which shall contain the names and addresses of all persons occupying any room or suite of rooms within the motel and the hour and date of arrival and departure of guests. The register shall include the state automobile license number. The register shall be available for examination at all times by the police department. 
(Code 1965, § 20-11) 
Sec. 22-301. - Registering under false name prohibited; registering of minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to register as a guest in any motel within the Village under an assumed or fictitious name, or to register in his own name for or on behalf of another person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to register as a guest in any motel within the Village unless accompanied by their parent or guardian, or for any motel owner, manager or agent to permit such registration. 
(Code 1965, § 20-12; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-302. - Police to check register; falsely registering as owner of car. 
    It shall be the duty of the Police Department of the village to from time to time check the register referred to in section 22-301. If, after such investigation, it is determined that the owner of the car is different than the person who has signed the register as the owner, then such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 20-13; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-303. - General cleanliness. 
    All rooms or suites of rooms located on motel grounds shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Code 1965, § 20-16) 
Sec. 22-304. - Length of stay. 
    No person registered at a motel shall be permitted to remain at the motel for more than 30 days at any one time. 
(Ord. No. 1995-38, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Secs. 22-305-22-315. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE AND PRIVILEGE TAX 

Sec. 22-316. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motel room means a room within a structure offered for rental on a daily basis and containing facilities for sleeping. One room offered for rental with or without an adjoining bath shall be considered as a single motel room. The number of motel rooms within a suite shall be computed on the basis of those rooms utilized for the purpose of sleeping. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-317. - Imposition of tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed upon the use and privilege of renting a motel room within the village a tax at the rate of six percent of the gross rental charge for such renting, leasing or letting. 
(b)  The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is to be borne by the person who seeks the privilege of occupying the motel room, such person referred to in this division as the "renter." 
(c)  The tax levied in this section shall be paid in addition to any and all other taxes and charges. It shall be the duty and obligation of the owner of every motel to secure the tax from the renter of the motel room and to pay over to the Finance Director the tax under procedures prescribed by the Finance Director, or as may be otherwise provided in this article. 
(d)  Every person required to collect the tax levied by this division shall secure the tax from the renter at the time he collects the rental payment for the motel room. Upon the invoice receipt or other statement or memorandum of the rent paid given to the renter at the time of payment, the amount due under the tax provided in this division shall be stated separately on the documents. 
(e)  If renter fails or refuses to pay the tax imposed in this section, the unpaid tax shall be collectible by the owner in the same manner as unpaid room rental charges. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(b); Ord. No. 2013-20, § 1, 4-23-13, eff. 6-1-13) 
Sec. 22-318. - Books and records. 
    The Finance Director, or any person certified by him as his deputy or representative, may enter the premises of any motel for inspection and examination of books and records in order to effectuate the proper administration of this article and to ensure the enforcement of the collection of the tax imposed. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder, or interfere with the Finance Director or his duly authorized deputy or representative in the discharge of his duties in the performance of this section. It shall be the duty of every owner to keep accurate and complete books and records to which the Finance Director, or his deputy or representative (authorized by him), shall at all times have full access, which records shall include a daily sheet showing: the number of motel rooms rented during the 24-hour period, including multiple rentals of the same motel room where such shall occur, and the actual motel tax receipts collected for the date in question. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(c)) 
Sec. 22-319. - Transmittal of tax revenue. 
(a)  The owner of each motel room within the village shall file tax returns with the Finance Director, on forms prescribed by him, showing tax receipts received with respect to each motel room during each calendar quarter. Quarterly returns are to be filed within 30 days after each calendar quarter. Each return shall be accompanied by payment to the village of all taxes due for the period for which the tax return applies. 
(b)  Any owner of a motel who for the preceding quarterly period has failed to file a proper return or pay over the proper amount of tax may be required by the Finance Director, in his discretion, to file subsequent returns and to pay the tax imposed in this division on a monthly basis. 
(c)  If any owner fails to collect or remit the tax imposed under this division, a penalty at the rate of two percent per month from the day or delinquency shall be added to the amount due and collected from the rentor or owner. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(d)) 
Sec. 22-320. - Collection. 
    Whenever any person shall fail to pay or collect and remit any tax as provided in this division, the Village Attorney shall, upon the request of the Finance Director, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the payment of the tax and penalty on behalf of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(e)) 
Sec. 22-321. - Suspension of license. 
    If the president, after a hearing held by or for him, shall find that any person has willfully failed to collect or remit the tax imposed by this division, he may suspend or revoke all village licenses held by such person. The owner shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, to be held not less than five days after notice of the time and place of the hearing to be held is mailed to him addressed at his last known place of business. Any suspension or revocation of any license shall not release or discharge the owner from his civil liability for the payment of the tax nor from prosecution for such offense. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(f)) 
Sec. 22-322. - Proceeds of tax and fine. 
    All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax under this division, including penalties, shall be paid into the treasury of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17(g)) 
State Law reference- Home rule unit authority to impose tax on motel rentals, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-6a. 
Secs. 22-323-22-345. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - NURSING HOMES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-346. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Developmentally disabled means those individuals whose disability is attributable to mental retardation, cerebral palsy, epilepsy, autism, or other pathological conditions which generally originate before such individuals attain the age of 18, and which can continue or can be expected to continue indefinitely, and which constitute a substantial functioning handicap to such individuals. 
    Home for the aged means any home operated not for profit under the auspices of a religious, fraternal, charitable or other nonprofit organization, or operated not for profit under an endowment, which through its ownership or management, and as its principal objective, provides maintenance, personal care, nursing or sheltered care to persons over the age of 65 with illnesses limited to the aging process, and in the conduct of which provides such service or services to not less than three persons who are not related to the applicant or owner by blood or marriage. 
    Maintenance means food, shelter and laundry. 
    Nursing means registered professional nursing or practical nursing, as these terms are defined in 225 ILCS 65/50-10, as amended, for sick or infirm persons who are under the care and supervision of licensed medical practitioners. 
    Nursing home means an establishment for the care of the aged or terminally ill residents whose condition requires the services of a skilled nursing facility. Such a home does not contain equipment for surgical care or for treatment of maternity cases, mental illness or drug addiction illness. 
    Owner means, in the case of a licensee who is an individual, the licensee, and, in the case of a firm, partnership or association, licensee means each member thereof. 
    Personal care means assistance with meals, dressing, transportation and movement, and such other general oversight or the physical well-being of the residents of the home, exclusive of nursing, as may be required by their condition. 
    Resident means any person admitted to a nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged for care. 
    Sheltered care means maintenance and personal care. 
    Sheltered care home means a private boardinghome, institution, building, residence, or other place operated for profit, which through its ownership or management, provides sheltered care to three or more adults who are not related to the applicant or owner by blood or marriage. 
(Code 1965, § 19-71; Ord. No. 1996-32, § 1, 6-25-96; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-347. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  In the event of a conviction by any court of record of any such person for a violation of any of the provisions of this article relating to the health, safety and accommodations of patients or residents, it shall be the duty of the Department of Community Development, and it is hereby authorized and empowered to close such nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged, and to cause its vacation of all residents or patients therefrom, pending the repairs, alterations or additions necessary to make it safe and proper for the occupancy of its patients or residents and to make it comply with the terms of this article. 
(b)  Whenever an inspection of a nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged discloses that the continued operation of such home would be found to be an immediate and serious menace to public health and safety, the Director of the Department of Community Development is hereby authorized to close such home forthwith. 
(Code 1965, § 19-72; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-348. - Patients relying upon treatment by prayer or spiritual means. 
    Nothing in the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto shall be construed as authorizing the medical supervision, regulation, or control of the remedial care or treatment of residents or patients in any home or institution conducted for those who rely upon treatment by prayer or spiritual means in accordance with the creed or tenets of any well recognized church or religious denomination. A license is required and all remaining rules and regulations and minimum standards shall apply. 
(Code 1965, § 19-73) 
Sec. 22-349. - Minimum standards. 
    The building used as a nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged shall comply with the building code; the zoning regulations; the fire regulations; and the minimum standards for nursing homes, sheltered care homes and homes for the aged as prescribed by the Department of Community Development, the Nursing Home Care Act (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq., and the State Department of Public Health. 
(Code 1965, § 19-74; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-350. - Compliance with rules and regulations of the Department of Community Development required. 
    Nursing homes, sheltered care homes or homes for the aged shall comply with rules and regulations adopted by the Department of Community Development relating to the operation and conduct of nursing homes, sheltered care homes or homes for the aged, and the care, treatment, rehabilitation, recreation, and maintenance of the residents thereof as it shall deem necessary; provided, however, that such rules and regulations shall require compliance with at least the minimum requirements established by the State Department of Public Health pursuant to the Nursing Home Care Act (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.) 
(Code 1965, § 19-75; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-351. - Isolation room required. 
(a)  Each nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged shall be provided with a suitable room, approved by the Department of Community Development, to be used for cases of serious illness, terminal cases and for the isolation of cases of contagious, infectious, epidemic or communicable diseases. The room thus provided shall have a stationary washstand with hot and cold running water supply. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating any nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged within the Village to cooperate with the Department of Community Development in minimizing the danger of transmission of communicable diseases as set forth in the rules and regulations promulgated by the Department of Community Development. 
(Code 1965, § 19-76; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-352. - Removal of dead. 
(a)  There shall be provided in each such home a suitable room or area approved by the Department of Community Development for the proper care of the dead pending their removal after the person has been pronounced dead by a duly licensed physician admitted to practice in the state. 
(b)  No person acting as superintendent or manager, or who is otherwise in charge or control of any nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged, nor any person connected with any nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged, in any capacity whatsoever as nurse, physician, or attendant, shall order, permit or allow the body of any resident or person who has been under care in such nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged, and who shall have died therein to be removed from such home at any time within 24 hours after the hour of death, unless the removal of such body has been authorized in writing by some member of the immediate family of such deceased person or by some other person legally authorized to order or permit such a removal. No such body shall be removed otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this article, provided that no body shall be kept at any nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged longer than 36 hours after death without the permission from the Department of Community Development. 
(Code 1965, § 19-77; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-353. - Required records; inspection. 
(a)  Each nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged shall maintain individual records for each resident and shall include resident's admission record, which record shall show the name, address, age, sex, marital status, information required for the filling in of death certificate, and the date of admission and discharge or disposition of each resident in the home, a medical record, physician's order record, nursing notes, and list of the resident's belongings. 
(b)  Accurate records of financial transactions involving use of the resident's funds shall be on file in the nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged. 
(c)  Personnel files shall be maintained for all employees and shall include records of education, experience, and findings of physical examinations as to physical and mental fitness and also showing freedom from any communicable disease. Daily work and time schedules of employees shall be maintained. 
(d)  Each home shall maintain a permanent residents' registry book in which the name of each resident is entered in chronological order with the date and number of the entry. 
(e)  All records shall be open at all times to the inspection of the Department of Community Development or its duly authorized representatives. 
(Code 1965, § 19-78; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-354. - Required reports. 
(a)  Certain diseases. It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating any such nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged within the village to make a report to the Department of Community Development daily, by telephone and by mail, of all epidemic, communicable, or contagious diseases. Such daily reports shall contain the names and residents of all persons suffering from any of these diseases, together with such other information as may be required by the Department of Community Development. 
(b)  Monthly reports. It shall be the further duty of all such persons to make written reports to the Department of Community Development on or before the fifth day of each calendar month, showing a complete record of such nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged during the preceding month, including the names and addresses of residents who have died during the month, the cause of each death, and such other information as may be specified by the Department of Community Development. 
(c)  Forms. All reports required under this section shall be made in full upon forms furnished for that purpose by the Department of Community Development, and shall be signed by the chief physician, manager or licensee in charge of such nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged. 
(Code 1965, § 19-79; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-355. - Inspections of homes. 
(a)  Every home shall be open at all reasonable times to inspection by the Department of Human Services, the Department of Community Development, Police Department and the Fire Department, as often as is deemed necessary: 
(1)  When there is a reasonable suspicion of an endangerment to the health and safety of the residents; or 
(2)  When the Director of Housing and the village deem it appropriate. 
(b)  Guns or other weapons are not allowed in a nursing home. 
(Code 1965, § 19-80; Ord. No. 00-35, § 2, 6-27-00; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-356. - Emergency care. 
    It shall be the responsibility of each nursing home to provide or to have available emergency medical care, including transportation, for its residents. If the nursing home fails to provide such care and/or transportation and as a result the village is requested to respond, there shall be a $500.00 charge for any of the following: 
(1)  Transportation to a hospital for any treatment which can be handled by basic life support ambulance. 
(2)  In-house treatment of residents not requiring advanced life support. 
(3)  If the village paramedics are called to a nursing home to provide emergency medical care for a resident and if, upon arrival, it is determined that such resident is deceased, the paramedics will not transport that person. The nursing home will be responsible to make proper arrangements for the disposition of the body. 
(Code 1965, § 19-81) 
Sec. 22-357. - Abuse of residents prohibited. 
(a)  An owner, licensee, administrator, employee, agent, guest or resident of any nursing home licensed by the village under division 2 of this article shall not abuse any resident of such nursing home. 
(b)  The term "abuse" means any physical or mental injury inflicted other than by accident, and sexual assault and sexual abuse as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-1.20, 5/11-1.50, as amended. 
(c)  It is the duty of any nursing home administrator, employee or agent who becomes aware of such abuse, or who becomes aware of facts which indicate that such abuse may have occurred, to report the information immediately to the village police department. 
(d)  The failure of any administrator, employee or licensee to make a report as required by subsection (c) of this section shall be grounds for the revocation and/or suspension of the nursing home license, or for such other penalties as provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 19-82; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-358. - Employee personal background investigations; polygraph required; penalty for noncompliance. 
(a)  The licensee or administrator shall, at the request of the Village, furnish to the Department of Community Development or Police Department, or both, the name, sex, race, date of birth, fingerprints, photograph, prior employment history, and current home address of all employees for the purpose of determining if any such employees have been charged and/or convicted of abuse, as defined in section 22-357, or of any felony. 
(b)  The licensee shall require, as a condition of employment, that the employee take a polygraph test consistent with the provisions of the Employee Polygraph Protection Act, 29 USCA section 2001 et seq., and as amended, at such times as reasonably requested by the licensee or the village where such employee has or may have direct access to controlled substances as defined by such act. 
(c)  Any applicant for employment or employee with a record of violence and/or abuse shall be denied employment in accordance with section 3-206(a)(1) of the nursing home care act (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.), as amended. 
(d)  The failure of any nursing home licensee or administrator to conduct personnel background investigations to require polygraph examinations, or to furnish information as provided by subsection (a) of this section shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the nursing home license and such other penalties as provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 19-83; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-359. - Level of care. 
(a)  No nursing home licensed in accordance with this section shall grant admission to persons with specific disabling conditions unless the facility shall have prior approval of the village for the equipment, rooms, etc., to care for such persons. This includes persons with HIV, Hepatitis, TB or other communicable diseases. 
(b)  A care facility licensed in accordance with this section must admit all adult (i.e., over the age of 18 years) patients who need the level of care these facilities are licensed to provide. An individual assessment will be completed and documented, if and when, a particular patient's needs cannot be met. Such documentation must be completed prior to denial of admission to the facility. 
(Ord. No. 1996-32, § 1, 6-25-96) 
Sec. 22-360. - Verification of sex offenders or other felons who may be living in nursing homes. 
(a)  Nursing homes located within the Village of Niles shall provide the village nursing home officer, a monthly certification that the nursing home has verified whether any of its residents are convicted sex offenders or other felons. 
(b)  The Department of Community Development shall create procedures for implementing [subsection] (a) [of this section from] 30 days of promulgation of this section. 
(c)  There shall be a fine up to $500.00 per day for each violation of this section. 
(d)  This section shall not abridge the authority or responsibilities of the village nursing home officer. 
(Ord. No. 2005-36, § 1, 9-27-05) 
Secs. 22-361-22-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-371. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the state, the county or the village to conduct or operate any nursing home, sheltered-care home or home for the aged within the village without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 19-85) 
State Law reference- Authority to license and regulate, 210 ILCS 45/3-104. 
Sec. 22-372. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a license to conduct and operate a nursing home, sheltered-care home, or home for the aged, shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this article relating to applications for licenses. The application shall be under oath and shall contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant, if an individual; if a firm, partnership, or association, of every member thereof; in the case of a corporation, the name and address thereof and of its officers; and, in the case of a municipality or political subdivision, the name and address of its chief executive officer. 
(2)  The location of the home for which a license is sought. 
(3)  The name of the person under whose management or supervision the home will be conducted. 
(4)  The number and type of residents for which maintenance, personal care, or nursing is to be provided in accordance with the license classifications established by the department of human services. 
(5)  Such information relating to the number, experience, and training of the employees of the home, and of the moral character of the applicant and employees as the department of human services may deem necessary. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a statement relative to the financial status of the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 19-86) 
Sec. 22-373. - Investigation; issuance. 
    The Community Development Department, upon the receipt of an application for a license under this division, shall cause the Fire Prevention Bureau and the Department of Community Development to make a thorough investigation of the premises proposed to be licensed, and, if satisfied that the minimum standards prescribed in section 22-349 are met; and, if the applicant is otherwise qualified, the Community Development Department shall, pursuant to a favorable report from the departments described in this section of their findings in writing, issue a license to the applicant to conduct a home of the class designated at the location specified, which license shall state the maximum number of residents that may be accommodated at any one time. 
(Code 1965, § 19-87; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-374. - Denial; petition for review. 
    If the application for license is denied, the applicant may, within 30 days thereafter, file a petition for review of the action denying the application, which petition shall be under oath and shall be filed with the hearing board as provided in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 19-88) 
Sec. 22-375. - Revocation; renewal. 
    The president may revoke or deny the renewal of any license issued under the provisions of this article for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Cruelty or indifference to the welfare of a resident. 
(2)  Misappropriation of the property of a resident. 
(3)  Conversion of the property of a resident. 
(4)  Violation of any provision of this article or of the minimum standards, rules and regulations promulgated thereunder or promulgated by the department of human services. 
(5)  Any ground upon which an application for a license may be denied as prescribed thereunder. 
(Code 1965, § 19-89) 
Sec. 22-376. - Hearing board-Appointment; members; duties. 
    The Mayor shall appoint a hearing board consisting of the Director of Family Services, the Fire Chief, and the Director of Community Development. Such board shall review applications for license for nursing homes, shelter care homes, or homes for the aged which have been denied for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure to meet the minimum standards prescribed in this article. 
(2)  Conviction of the applicant, or if the applicant is a firm, partnership or association of any of its members; or if a corporation, any of its officers or directors; or of the person designated to manage or supervise the home, of a felony or of two or more misdemeanors involving moral turpitude as shown by a certified copy of the record of conviction; or in the case of a conviction of a misdemeanor by a court not of record, as shown by other evidence or other satisfactory evidence that the moral character of the applicant, manager or supervisor of the home is not reputable. 
(3)  Personnel insufficient in number or unqualified by training or experience to provide proper and adequate care for the number and type of residents. 
(4)  Insufficient financial or other resources to operate and conduct the home in accordance with the requirements of this article and the minimum standards, rules and regulations promulgated under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 19-90; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-377. - Same-Proceedings. 
(a)  Investigation and notice. The hearing board, may, upon the petition of an applicant whose petition for license has been denied, or upon its own motion, and shall upon the verified complaint in writing of any person setting forth facts which if proven would constitute grounds for the denial of an application for a license, the refusal of renewal of a license and the revocation of a license, investigate the applicant or licensee. Before denying an application or refusing to renew a license, or revoking a license, the board shall notify the applicant or licensee, in writing, of a hearing to be held thereon. Such notice shall specify the date, time and place of the hearing and shall not be held less than ten days after the notice is mailed or delivered in person. The notice shall also state the nature of the charges or reasons for the board's contemplated actions, denial, refusal to renew, or revocation of license. 
(b)  Procedure. The hearing shall be conducted by the board or the majority thereof and shall permit the applicant or licensee to appear in person and to be represented by counsel at the hearing, at which time the applicant or licensee shall be afforded an opportunity to present all relevant matters in support of his application for license or renewal of a license or in resisting the revocation thereof. Such hearing scheduled for a day certain may be continued for some other date if any witness whose testimony is relevant to the issues of the hearing is unable to be present on that day. The board shall not be bound by common law or statutory rules of evidence or by technical or formal rules of procedure but shall conduct hearings in such manner as seems best calculated to result in substantial justice. 
(c)  Board to make findings of fact; right to review. The hearing board shall make findings of fact and render a decision which shall be entered upon record of the board. The applicant shall have the right to review such decision as provided in this section. 
(d)  Final decisions subject to judicial review. All final administrative decisions rendered by the board shall be subject to judicial review as provided by law. 
(e)  Transcript of proceedings. The board at its expense shall provide a stenographer to take the testimony and preserve a record of all proceedings under this article. The notice of hearing, the complaint and all other documents in the nature of pleadings and written motions filed in proceedings, the transcript of testimony and the findings of fact and decisions shall be the record of the proceedings. The board shall furnish a transcript of such record to any person interested as a party to such hearing upon payment therefor of $0.75 per page for each original transcript, and $0.25 per page for each carbon copy thereof. However, the charges of any part of such transcript ordered or paid for previous to the writing of the original record shall be $0.25 per page. 
(f)  Certification of records. The board shall not be required to certify any record or file any answer or otherwise appear in any proceeding for judicial review, unless the party filing the complaint deposits the sum of $0.95 per page representing costs of such certification. Failure on the part of the plaintiff to make such deposits shall be grounds for dismissal of the action. Upon judicial review, the secretary of the board shall certify the record. 
(Code 1965, § 19-91) 
Sec. 22-378. - Inspection fee; exemptions. 
(a)  Annual fee. The annual inspection fee for a skilled nursing facility, intermediate-care facility and sheltered-care. Please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Exemptions. Homes which are operated without profit shall be exempt from the payment of an inspection fee. An application for a license requesting an exemption shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating that no gain is made from the care of residents. After investigation by the Department of Community Development and upon the recommendation of that body, any home that is not operated for gain, but where a charge is made for the care of patients, shall be exempt from payment of the inspection fee provided in subsection (a) of this section by a specific ordinance of the Village Board. Such exemption shall continue only for the duration of the license period. 
(Code 1965, § 19-93; Ord. No. 2010-09, § 1, 1-26-10; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 22-379-22-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - CONGREGATE HOUSING AND CONTINUING-CARE FACILITIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-401. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Congregate housing means specially planned, designed and managed multiunit housing, typically with self-contained apartments. Supportive services, such as meals, housekeeping, transportation, social and recreational activities, are provided. No continuous onsite personal or medical care is provided. 
    Continuing-care facilities means a housing development planned, designed and operated to provide a full range of accommodations and services for older adults, including independent living, congregate housing, and medical care. Residents may move from one level to another as their needs change. 
(Code 1965, § 19-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-402. - Penalties for violation of article. 
(a)  In the event of a conviction by any court of record of any such person for a violation of any of the provisions of this article relating to the health, safety and accommodations of patients or residents, it shall be the duty of the Director of Human Services who is hereby authorized and empowered to close the congregate housing/continuing care facility and to cause its vacation of all residents or patients therefrom, pending the repairs, alterations or additions necessary to make it safe and proper for the occupancy of its patients or residents and to make it comply with the terms of this article. 
(b)  Whenever an inspection of a congregate housing/continuing care facility discloses that the continued operation of such facility would be found to be an immediate and serious menace to public health and safety, the village president is hereby authorized to close such home forthwith. 
(Code 1965, § 19-99) 
Sec. 22-403. - Guidelines. 
    The following guidelines shall be applicable to congregate housing and continuing care facilities constructed, operated and maintained in the village: 
(1)  Objectives. The general purpose of these guidelines is listed in this subsection and used as a reference guideline for the evaluation of proposed senior congregate or continuing care facilities. The following guidelines shall be used by developers who are contemplating a development in the village: 
a.  Locate in an area where needed services and facilities are accessible to the elderly residents. 
b.  Locate in a neighborhood that is compatible in terms of land use, building type, and density to the congregate elderly housing residents. 
c.  Provide adequate space in the building and on the site for privacy, recreation, socialization, transportation and other beneficial living activities for the elderly residents. Provide physical and psychological security and serenity throughout the project. 
d.  Provide adequate facilities for the safety, health, and convenient access in the building and on the site for elderly residents, staff and visitors. 
e.  Provide staff with a program of services that is multidisciplinary for the sensitive and responsible care for the unique social, psychological, recreational and medical needs of the elderly residents. 
(2)  Project proposal. The owner and developer shall submit the following documents to the senior housing committee: 
a.  Preliminary development plan and written plan description; 
b.  Site plan showing existing building, proposed building, parking areas, walkways, other outdoor structures, and a proposed landscape plan; 
c.  Neighborhood location map showing the relation of the subject site to the surrounding land uses; 
d.  Sketch of the elevation of building and other structures on the site; 
e.  Floor plan of each floor of the building; 
f.  Outline of a proposed staffing plan, emergency medical plan, tenant contract, assessment procedures, meal options and other services; 
g.  Explanation of any other affiliate relationships with other nursing homes, health care institutions, etc.; 
h.  Information on developers' and management's prior experience in elderly housing and the length of the management contract; 
i.  Information that licensing for congregate/continuing care has been applied for and/or obtained; and 
j.  Any other documents requested by the senior housing committee. 
(Code 1965, § 19-100) 
Secs. 22-404-22-415. - Reserved.
