Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-05, § 1, adopted January 28, 2014, repealed § 22-404, which pertained to senior housing committees. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-416. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the state, the county or the village, to conduct or operate any congregate housing/continuing-care facility within the village without first having a license therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 19-95(a)) 
Sec. 22-417. - Application; contents. 
    Application for a license to conduct or operate a congregate housing/continuing-care facility shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this article and the rules and regulations of the senior housing committee. The application shall be under oath and shall contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant, if an individual; if a firm, partnership or association, of every member thereof; in the case of a corporation, the name and address thereof and of its officers; and in the case of a municipality or political subdivision, the name and address of its chief executive officer. 
(2)  The proposed location of the congregate housing/continuing care facility. 
(3)  The name of the person under whose management or supervision the home will be conducted, and the professional resumè of such person. 
(4)  Preliminary plans for the congregate housing/continuing care facility including, but not limited to, number and size of units, dining, recreational and social service facilities, dimension of structure, type of construction, and landscaping. 
(5)  Statement by the applicant that he has read the rules and regulations of the senior housing committee and that the proposed congregate housing/continuing-care facility will be in full compliance with such rules and regulations. 
(6)  Such information relating to the number, experience, and training of the employees of the facility, and of the moral character of the applicant and employees as the Village Senior Housing Committee may deem necessary or desirable. 
(7)  A nonrefundable application fee, please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 19-95(b); Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-418. - Investigation; issuance. 
(a)  An application for a congregate housing/continuing care facility shall be referred to the senior housing committee which shall conduct a thorough investigation of all matters set forth in the application, including interviews with the applicant, the owners and the proposed manager of the facility. If the applicant meets all standards set forth in this article and the rules and regulations of the senior housing committee, the committee shall issue its preliminary report of approval. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the preliminary report of approval, the applicant shall then proceed to obtain zoning approval by the Planning and Zoning Board as required by the Village zoning code. 
(c)  After zoning approval and construction of the facility, the Department of Community Development and the Fire Prevention Bureau shall inspect the premises to determine if the facility is in compliance with this article and the rules and regulations of the senior housing committee. The Community Development Department shall, upon the favorable report of such departments and upon payment of the appropriate fee, issue the license. 
(Code 1965, § 19-95(c); Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-419. - Duration. 
    Licenses issued under this division are for a period of one year. 
(Code 1965, § 19-95(d)) 
Sec. 22-420. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, repealed § 22-420, which pertained to fees and derived from 1965 § 19-95(e). 
Sec. 22-421. - Denial; petition for review. 
    If the application for license is denied, the applicant may, within 30 days thereafter, file a petition for review of the action denying the application, which petition shall be under oath, and shall be filed with the Village Clerk to be heard by the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 19-97) 
Sec. 22-422. - Revocation; renewal. 
    The president may revoke or deny the renewal of any license issued under the provisions of this division for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Cruelty or indifference to the welfare of a resident. 
(2)  Misappropriation of the property of a resident. 
(3)  Conversion of the property of a resident. 
(4)  Violation of any provision of this article or of the minimum standards, rules and regulations promulgated thereunder or promulgated by the senior housing committee. 
(5)  Any ground upon which an application for a license may be denied as prescribed thereunder. 
(6)  Any person whose license is revoked or not renewed shall have the right to a hearing before the president, or his designated hearing officer. A request for a hearing must be filed with the Village Clerk within seven days of notice of such revocation or nonrenewal. 
(7)  Before any such license is renewed, the senior housing committee shall review current reports of the code enforcement, fire, human services and police departments, to ensure compliance with applicable code provisions and the rules and regulations of the senior housing committee. 
(Code 1965, § 19-98) 
Secs. 22-423-22-429. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SINGLE-ROOM OCCUPANCY BUILDINGS 

Sec. 22-430. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Single-room occupancy building means any dwelling or part thereof designed or used primarily for single-room occupancy, containing five or more single-room living units, and which is occupied by the same tenants for an uninterrupted period of not less than 32 days. 
    Single-room occupancy unit is a room used or intended to be used as a residential housekeeping unit by not more than two occupants for living and sleeping, with or without cooking facilities, that contains not more than one habitable room consisting of not more than 250 square feet of floor area excluding from the calculation of floor area any kitchen having less than 70 square feet of floor area. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 1, 10-23-07) 
Sec. 22-431. - Single-room occupancy buildings-License required. 
    Any person or entity operating a single-room occupancy building, as defined in section 22-430, must obtain a single-room occupancy building license every two years. If a single-room occupancy building shall maintain four or more units for permanent residents then it shall apply for a license. Every person operating a single-room occupancy building shall maintain written records identifying the name(s) of the occupant of each unit, and the date(s) of tenancy for each occupant residing within the building. Such records shall be maintained on an annual basis and shall be open at all times for examination by the Community Development Director or a designee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 1, 10-23-07) 
Sec. 22-432. - Single-room occupancy buildings-Inspection-Fees. 
    Every building operated and maintained, in whole or in part, as a single-room occupancy building, as defined in section 22-430, shall be inspected at least annually by the Community Development Director or a designee. No single-room occupancy license shall be issued unless the Community Development Director or a designee has conducted such annual inspections and determined that the premises comply with all building, fire prevention and sanitary provisions of this Code. It shall be the duty of every person or entity operating a single-room occupancy to pay to the Department of Community Development an annual inspection fee please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. Such annual inspection fee shall be assessed under the authority of the Department of Community Development Director or a designee and may be billed prior or subsequent to the actual inspections conducted by the Department of Community Development and shall be payable to the Department of Community Development within 30 days of receipt of the notice of inspection fee from the department of buildings. The inspection fee for single-room occupancy buildings shall be assessed only once within a 12-month license period. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 1, 10-23-07; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-433. - Single-room occupancy buildings-Security guards. 
    Every single-room occupancy building shall employ a security force. A security guard must punch a time clock on every floor of the single-room occupancy building at least twice every day between the hours of 2200 and 600 hours the next morning. The single-room occupancy building director shall keep a record of the above activity ready for inspection by the Director of Community Development or a designee at a reasonable time. In any event, the single-room occupancy director shall send month records of security guard activities to the Director of Community Development at the first of each month. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 1, 10-23-07) 
Sec. 22-434. - Single-room occupancy buildings-Identification. 
    Any person or entity operating a single-room occupancy as defined in section 22-430 and licensed pursuant to this chapter may utilize the word "hotel" as part of its business name or identification. However, such name or identification shall also include the words "single-room occupancy" or the abbreviation "SRO." 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 1, 10-23-07) 
Sec. 22-435. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person violating, neglecting or failing to comply with any provisions of this chapter please refer to Appendix E Penalties of the Code of Ordinances. If it is found by the administrative adjudication hearing officer that a single-room occupancy building continually operates in total disregard of its occupants it shall be grounds for revocation and suspension of that licensee's single-room occupancy license pursuant to the procedures under the general licensing provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 1, 10-23-07; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 22-436-22-445. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS 

Sec. 22-446. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means all kinds of vocations, occupations, professions, enterprises, establishments, and all other kinds of activities and matters, together with all devices, machines, vehicles and appurtenances used therein, any of which are conducted for private profit, or benefit, either directly or indirectly, on any premises in this Village, or anywhere else within its jurisdiction. 
    Continuous Operating Business means any real business in which their business does not secure or lock their outside doors to prevent patrons from entering the business. A Continuously Operating Business does not have a closing time; it is in operation 24 hours a day. 
    Merchandiser, general retailer means a person that sells at retail, all or almost all of those items that are generally sold at retail in a store commonly known as a department store or discount store. These items, by way of illustration only, are items such as auto accessories, cameras, electrical appliances, fence and patio supplies, floor coverings, furniture, glassware, china, hardware, jewelry, lawn and garden supplies, lawn mowers, musical instruments, paint, power equipment, sporting goods, stationery and such other goods and wares that are commonly associated with department store or discount merchandisers. 
    Owner means the person in whom is vested all or part of the legal title to the property or all or part of the beneficial ownership and right to present use and enjoyment of the premises. 
    Precious metals means items of gold, silver or platinum such as bullion, coin collector/dealer rings, bracelets, silverware, teeth, jewelry, chains, necklaces or items of similar import, whose value per item exceeds the sum of $25.00. The purchase price paid for an item shall be prima facie evidence of its value. However, any person may establish another value by competent evidence. 
    Precious metals dealer means a person who purchases precious metals from the public. No person shall be deemed a precious metals dealer if the number of purchases in a calendar year does not exceed three, if the purchases are not for resale and if no advertising to make purchases was used. 
    Premises means all lands, structures, places, and also the equipment and appurtenances connected or used therewith in any business, and also any personal property which is either affixed to, or is otherwise used in connection with any such business conducted on such premises. 
    Public garage means any premises used for housing or care for more than four motor-driven vehicles, or where any such vehicles are equipped for operation, repaired, or kept for remuneration, hire or sale, not including exhibition or showrooms. 
    Secured means a building that has a permanent door or window in each appropriate building opening that is secured to prevent unauthorized entry and has all its door and window components, including frames, jambs, rails, stiles, muntins, mullions, panels, sashes, lights and panes intact and unbroken. 
(Code 1965, §§ 19-60, 19-64, 19-69(b), 19-69(c); Ord. No. 2017-64, § 1, 11-28-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 22-447. - Blasting. 
(a)  License required. No blasting operations shall be permitted within the village except upon special license to be granted by the President and Board of Trustees and upon such conditions and restrictions as shall be necessary for the protection and safeguarding of life and property. 
(b)  Bond required. Previous to the issuance of any such license, the applicants shall furnish and file with the Community Development Department a bond in the sum of $10,000.00, with sureties approved by the President and Board of Trustees, conditioned for the payment of any loss, damage or injury resulting to persons or property by reason of the use of such explosives, and for the strict observance of the ordinances of the village relating to the subject of such explosives. 
(c)  License fee. The fee for such license shall be as provided in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Niles Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 19-50; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-448. - Car dealers; storage on streets prohibited. 
    No automobiles shall be stored or exhibited for sale on any part of the street or sidewalk by a car dealer but must be kept within the boundaries of the property as described in the application for a license. 
(Code 1965, § 19-51) 
Sec. 22-449. - Regulation of carwashes. 
(a)  Prevention of ice formation. The owner, manager or operator of a motor vehicle-washing facility shall, during the operation of the facility at any time when the outside temperature is at or below the freezing point, salt or otherwise treat the paved areas of its facility and the surface of the public street, lane, road or highway adjacent to the motor vehicle washing facility to prevent the formation of a traffic hazard from the freezing of water on the street, lane, road or highway caused by motor vehicles tracking water from the motor vehicle washing facility. 
(b)  Hours of operation. The hours of operation of a carwash facility shall be from 6:00 a.m. to midnight; provided, however, that where the structure housing the carwash facility is within 100 feet of a residential structure, the hours of operation shall be from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1965, § 19-51.1) 
Sec. 22-450. - Florists displays on streets; sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any florist to place or display any flowers, plants, arrangements or merchandise on any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 19-52) 
Sec. 22-451. - Service stations; posting signs advertising gas prices. 
    No gasoline service station doing business in the village shall dispense, sell or offer for sale gasoline or diesel fuel except by the gallon or tenths of gallons; nor shall any such service station post signs advertising the price of gasoline being sold at such station unless the price so advertised corresponds with the actual total price per gallon being charged, including all applicable taxes. 
(Code 1965, § 19-58) 
Sec. 22-452. - Public garage; other businesses in conjunction with garage. 
    Every person licensed to conduct a public garage shall have the privilege of managing, conducting, operating or carrying on a private garage within the same building, structure, premises or enclosure; and shall also have the privilege of conducting therein the business of an automobile repair shop, the business of an automobile salesroom for automobiles and automobile accessories, and the business of a filling station, provided that the combined capacity of all containers or tanks, either portable or stationary, or the storage of ether, carbon bisulphite, gasoline, naphtha, benzol, hydrocarbon, liquefied petroleum gas, acetone, kerosene, turpentine or other inflammable liquids, having a flashpoint below 165 degrees Fahrenheit, do not exceed 500 gallons, without the necessity of obtaining additional licenses. 
(Code 1965, § 19-61) 
Sec. 22-453. - Scavengers. 
(a)  License required; fee. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of scavenger, or the collection or disposal of animal or vegetable refuse or offal, without having first secured a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as provided in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Application for license; issuance. Application for such permits shall be made to the Community Development Department, and licenses shall be issued through that office. 
(c)  Vehicles. Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight, and equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the transportation of refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicles to be driven over or through any street in the village during or on a Sunday. 
(d)  Required collection of landscape wastes. All scavengers must collect from their customers landscape wastes which are placed in proper containers. The failure or refusal of a scavenger to collect properly containerized landscape wastes shall be grounds for revocation of the license required by this section. 
(Code 1965, § 19-62; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-454. - Landscaper. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of landscaper without having first secured a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as provided in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Niles Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 19-62.1; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-455. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, repealed § 22-455, which pertained to pay telephones and derived from Ord. No. 1994-1, § 1, 1-25-94. 
Sec. 22-456. - Precious metals dealers. 
(a)  License required; fees. It shall be unlawful for any person to act or operate as a precious metals dealer in the village without obtaining a license prior thereto. The fee for a licensee who has a permanent place of business within the village shall be $100.00 annually. The fee for a licensee who has not or is in the process of establishing a permanent place of business within the village shall be $1,000.00, with $900.00 returnable upon evidence of a lease or ownership for 12 months or longer. 
(b)  Recordkeeping. Every precious metals dealer shall keep a book in which shall be written in ink at the time of each and every purchase an accurate account and description of all goods, items, articles and other things purchased; the amount of the purchase price; the name and address of the seller; the driver's license number of the seller and the social security number of the seller. The driver's license number of the seller shall be taken by the purchaser from a driver's license presented to him. If the seller does not have a current driver's license or social security number, two other items of identification verifying the name, address and identity of the seller must be used and written down. 
(c)  Inventory number; inspection. The record book, as well as all items on the premises, shall bear an inventory number and shall at all times be open for inspection by the village police department and/or license department agents. 
(d)  Purchase from person under 18. No dealer shall purchase any precious metals from any person under the age of 18. Proof of age shall consist of three pieces of identification, one of which shall be a valid driver's license and/or state identification card indicating proof of age. 
(e)  Waiting period. No item purchased shall be transferred, sold, or otherwise permitted to be removed from the place of purchase for a period of seven days after the purchase thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 19-69) 
Sec. 22-457. - Going-out-of-business and other special sales. 
(a)  Adoption of state regulations. The fraudulent sales act (815 ILCS 350/0.01 et seq.), as amended, is hereby adopted by the village for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing going-out-of-business sales, insurance, salvage, removal, creditor's and other special sales, and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out verbatim herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Enforcement. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the License Officer. 
(c)  License fee. The license fee for any sale governed by this section shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1965, § 19-70) 
Sec. 22-458. - Occasional sales/transient merchant. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section a transient merchant is defined as any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the village or not, who engages in a temporary business of auctioning, selling, swapping, trading or exchanging, and delivering the goods, wares and merchandise within such village, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, restaurants or any street, alley or other place within the village, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. The person, firm or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this section merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(b)  [Application.] Every transient merchant must make application for an occasional sale license not less than three weeks before the sale and must have obtained the license before commencing the sale. 
(c)  Enforcement. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the License Officer. 
(d)  License fee. The license fee for any sale governed by this section shall be $10.00 per day. 
(Ord. No. 1995-9, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 22-459. - Motor vehicle repair facilities and gasoline stations to keep records of vehicles parked overnight. 
(a)  All motor vehicle repair facilities and gasoline stations shall keep records of all motor vehicles that are parked overnight at the facilities. 
(b)  Each record must contain the: 
(1)  Name of the owner of the vehicle; 
(2)  Current address of the owner of the vehicle; 
(3)  Telephone number of the owner of the vehicle; 
(4)  The state license plate number of the vehicle on which work or repairs are to be performed; 
(5)  Type of work or repair to be performed on the vehicle; 
(6)  The date in which the vehicle was allowed to be parked at the facility; 
(7)  The number of days in which the auto is to be parked at the facility; and 
(8)  The number of days the vehicle is actually parked at the facility. 
(c)  If a motor vehicle repair facility does not keep the above required records, all parked vehicles may be towed from the facility at the expense of the repair owner. 
(Ord. No. 1999-18, § 1, 4-27-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1999-18, § 1, adopted Apr. 27, 1999, was intended to be set out as a new § 22-458; however, since § 22-458 already existed within the Code, said ordinance was included as a new § 22-459 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 22-460. - Unused property. 
    When a commercial building goes unused for over 90 days, and the owner or lessee makes no attempt to or refuses to lease or use the unused building or space, the owner or lessee of the commercial property shall be fined a sum not to exceed $500.00 per day for each day the commercial property remains unused. No fine will be imposed unless approved by the village Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2004-32, § 1, 8-24-04) 
Sec. 22-461. - Crowd control. 
(a)  Whenever it becomes necessary for reasons of crowd control or traffic control, the owner or operator of a business shall institute all crowd and/or traffic control measures to insure that there is sufficient parking for patrons and the patrons or crowds entering or leaving the business shall conform to all Niles ordinances and be orderly and respectful of the surrounding area. 
(b)  When a business is found violating subsection (a) above, and it becomes necessary for the Village of Niles to assume the business's responsibility for compliance of (a) above, the business will be assessed a fee for the use of Niles Police, please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. The fee shall not exceed $500.00 per calendar year. This fee will be added to the violator's Niles Business License. This subsection does not limit the Village of Niles from seeking any other appropriate remedy or penalty. 
(Ord. No. 2007-03, § 1, 1-23-07; Ord. No. 2008-25, § 1, 5-21-08; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-462. - The affirmative action plan requirement. 
(a)  All contractors and sub-contractors involved in all water pollution control projects for the Village of Niles shall develop and implement written affirmative action plans to overcome underutilization of minority persons and /or women. Underutilization of minorities means having fewer minority workers and/or women in a particular job classification than would reasonably be expected by their availability. An affirmative action plan shall include: 
(1)  A description of the contractor's or subcontractor's workforce analysis made in accordance with 44 IAC 750.120 and 44 IAC 750.130; and 
(2)  Goals and timetables to which the contractor's or subcontractor's recruitment, hiring or promotion efforts shall be directed to correct any identified underutilization. 
(b)  The affirmative action plan must ensure equal opportunity as defined in 41 CFR 60-1 et seq. in all awards of bids to contractors and sub-contractors who perform work pursuant to water pollution control projects as defined in 35 ILCS 365.110 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2014-49, § 1, 8-26-14) 
Sec. 22-463. - Physical security of building and premises. 
    Construction materials and exterior and interior designs of buildings and standards set by the Village, including, but not limited to, the construction and design all possible points of entry such as doors, windows, transoms, skylights. In addition thereto, each business shall undertake such other physical security measures on or about its property that are deemed reasonable to protect the premises and discourage burglaries and holdups thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2017-64, § 1, 11-28-17) 
Sec. 22-464. - Duties to secure, property. 
(a)  The business, owner, manager or a non-residential property of a non-continuous operating business is responsible to secure the property during non-business times. 
(1)  Ensuring that there are no accessible structures into the premises. 
(2)  Ensuring that there are no conditions upon the property presenting an immediate risk to public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  Any business, owner, manager or non-residential property of a non-continuous operating business who is contacted by a representative of the Niles Police Department and notified of an unsecured door, in which is unable to be secured by the police, is required to respond to the business to secure the property. 
(Ord. No. 2017-64, § 1, 11-28-17) 
Sec. 22-465. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to the penalties prescribed in Appendix E, Penalties and Section 1-11, General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. The four or more offenses will be considered a petty offense. 
(Ord. No. 2017-64, § 1, 11-28-17) 
Secs. 22-466-22-480. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - CHILD CARE 

Sec. 22-481. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Child care is the adult supervision of children under the age of 14 to assure the safety of the children, to provide lunch and snacks and to offer educational and/or entertaining programs or games. 
    Child day care is a child care facility operated in a commercial building. 
    Child home care is for compensation child care maintained in a single family detached home which is the permanent residence of the principal person giving such care. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Sec. 22-482. - License required; fee. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a child care facility without having first obtained a license from the Village. Please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-483. - Application for license. 
    Applications for a child day care license or child home care license shall be made to the Department of Community Development on forms designated by the director of such department. The applicant shall attach to the application a copy of a valid license to operate such facility issued by the state department of children and family services. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-484. - Fingerprinting required; persons not eligible for license. 
(a)  Before the license is issued the applicant and all other staff or volunteers must be fingerprinted by the Niles Police Department. 
(b)  No person who has been arrested for any felony or misdemeanor relating to improper conduct with a child or minor shall be a licensee or an employee of a licensee under this section if that person pleaded guilty, pleaded no contest, stipulated to the facts alleged in a criminal complaint, pleaded guilty or no contest to a reduced criminal charge, or was found guilty of criminal charges involving a child or minor. 
(c)  No person who was discharged from employment at a day care facility or whose license to operate a day care facility has been suspended or revoked shall be a licensee or employee of a day care facility in the village. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Sec. 22-485. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, repealed § 22-485, which pertained to zoning requirements and derived from Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95. 
Sec. 22-486. - Hours of operation. 
    Hours of operation are from 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Sec. 22-487. - Compliance with applicable regulations. 
    Every licensed child care facility shall at all times maintain the standards set forth in the Illinois Child Care Act of 1969, the applicable standards;p0; Every licensed child care facility shall at all times maintain the standards set forth in the Illinois Child Care Act of 1969 (225 ILCS 10/1 et seq.), the applicable standards promulgated by the state department of children and family services, the standards required by the Life Safety Code, National Fire Protection Association, 1994, and shall comply with ordinances and regulations of the Village. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-488. - Maximum number of children in a child home care residence. 
    The maximum number of children permitted in a home day care is six, which number includes persons under the age of 14 years who are permanent residents of the household. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Sec. 22-489. - Nuisance. 
    In the event the operation of a child home care facility becomes a nuisance to neighbors, the village may commence proceedings to suspend or revoke the license. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Sec. 22-490. - Inspection. 
    Members of the Departments of Community Development, Fire and Human Services shall have the authority to inspect a child care facility during hours of operation to insure compliance with the standards and the safety and well-being of the children. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-491. - License renewals. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this section must be renewed annually. The requirements for an initial license shall apply to renewals. 
(Ord. No. 1995-36, § 1, 6-27-95) 
Secs. 22-492-22-500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - ADULT DAYCARE CENTERS 

Sec. 22-501. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as "The Niles Ordinance for Adult Daycare Centers." 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 1-1, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-502. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this article and of the village to establish standards, regulations, and criteria to require optimal levels of service and supervision to be provided to the participants of any adult daycare center as defined here. 
(b)  The standards, regulations, and criteria defined shall be adhered to in order to obtain and retain a license for an adult daycare operation within the village. 
(c)  In absence of a proposed vendor with the Illinois Community Care Program, the village adopts by reference the Standards and Guidelines for adult daycare issued by the National Council on Aging's National Institute on adult daycare as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 1-2, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-503. - Definitions. 
    Activities of daily living (ADL) are activities that include but are not limited to: walking, bathing, shaving, brushing teeth, combing hair, dressing, eating, using the telephone, transferring and using a toilet. 
    Adult daycare centers are facilities, any piece other than home, which provide direct care and supervision of adults 60 years of age and older, in a community based setting, for the purpose of providing personal attention: promoting social, physical, and emotional well-being in a structured setting, not exceeding 12 hours in a 24-hour period. 
    Applicant means any person filing an application for a license under this article. 
    Participation means an adult enrolled in an adult daycare program. 
    Staff means participant ratio includes those who spend 70 percent of their time in direct service. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 1-3, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-504. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this article are severable. Invalidity of any provision herein shall not invalidate the other provisions. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 1-4, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-505. - Adoption of other statutes. 
    The village adopts by reference the rules/regulations for vendors of adult daycare for the community care program of the Illinois Department of Human Services, Chapter II, Section 240.92 as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 1-5, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-506. - Licensing requirements. 
(a)  No person shall establish, operate, maintain, or advertise adult daycare within the village without obtaining a valid business license and approval of the village board. 
(b)  All initial applications shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant, if an individual; if a film, partnership or association, of every member; and in the case of a corporation the name and address of the corporation and of its board of directors, officers, and registered agent. 
(2)  The location and proposed name for the facility/program for which a license is being sought. 
(3)  The number of participants for whom programs and services will be provided, including admission criteria. 
(4)  The range of services that will be provided at the facility. 
(5)  A statement of financial resources, including an annual operational budget. 
(c)  All initial applications shall also be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  Statement of ownership for the building and the services, if different, which contains: 
a.  Names, addresses, telephone numbers of all owners of the building and program management services. 
b.  Tax exempt identification, if applicable 
(2)  Any management agreements for the operation of the facility. 
(3)  Information relating to the number, experience, and training of the employees of the adult daycare center. 
(4)  Certified copies of the state department of human services community care program vendors agreement, if any. 
(5)  Certified copies of the Older Americans Act, Title III contracts, if any. 
(6)  Such other information as the Director of Community Development or the Village Board may request. 
(d)  Initial applicants shall also meet all applicable local building and zoning codes, health codes, fire codes and all requirements set forth in the American Disability Act and the Life Safety Code of the National Fire Protection Association. 
(e)  Any waivers to the 60 and over age category of participants must be approved by the Director of Human Services of the village. 
(f)  The number of adults specified on the application shall be the maximum number allowed in the center at any one time. 
(g)  Applicants seeking renewal of license are subject to inspection by the Village code enforcement, Fire, and Human Services Departments prior to renewal of license. 
(h)  All applications for license renewal shall be accompanied by a special use fee that is non-refundable. Please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(i)  All applications for license renewal shall be accompanied by an annual license fee to be refunded if application renewal should be denied. Please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(j)  All licenses shall be granted for a period of one year. 
(k)  A license may be revoked or renewal denied for: 
(1)  Cruelty or indifference to welfare of the participant, or 
(2)  Violations of any provision of this article or of the minimum standards rules, regulations or orders of the village. 
(l)  A licensee will be entitled to a hearing if a license is to be revoked. according to rules set forth in the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Niles. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, §§ 2-1-2-11, 9-23-97; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-507. - Operational standards-Admission practices. 
    Each operation shall develop and adhere to a policy which establishes the physical and/or mental conditions of persons both eligible or ineligible for services. 
(1)  The operation shall admit only the number of participants permitted by its license. 
(2)  No adult day care center shall admit persons with a communicable disease requiring isolation or persons who are active abusers of controlled substances, including but limited to drugs and alcohol. 
(3)  Adults applying for admission in to an adult daycare center shall be given a written statement which specifies the admission policy, services available, discharge policy, fee schedule, hours of operation. 
(4)  The operation shall develop and adhere to a policy which describes the circumstances that will lead to discharge of a participant, including procedures for the refund of fees. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 3-1, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-508. - Same-Individual service plans. 
(a)  Each participant shall have a written individualized plan of care which shall include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Assessment of functional status and limitations. 
(2)  Medical history and drug therapy, if any. 
(3)  Goals and objectives appropriate to the individual. 
(4)  Activities and services to achieve those goals. 
(b)  Individual service plans shall be completed by the end of the third week and reviewed every six months, or as often as the condition warrants. Plans shall contain progress notes for services which the center has agreed to provide. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 3-2, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-509. - Same-Emergency preparedness. 
(a)  Each operation shall have a written and posted plan which specifies its procedure for obtaining emergency care, evacuation of the premises, and training for the staff and participants. 
(b)  Participants records shall contain the name, address and phone number of the person(s) to be notified in the event of an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 3-3, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-510. - Same-Services and programs. 
    Each operation shall specify the services that shall be provided to the participants. At a minimum, the services shall include: 
(1)  Transportation to enable participants to attend the program and sponsored outings. Transportation may be provided by the operation or through a contract with another carrier. 
(2)  Assistance with and supervision of activities of daily living, as needed. Activities of daily living include but are not limited to the following: walking, bathing, shaving, brushing teeth, combing hair, dressing, eating, using the telephone, transferring, and using a toilet. 
(3)  A daily meal and supplementary nutritious snacks and special diets as ordered by the participant's physician. 
(4)  An activity program including reality orientation, resocialization and guidance to promote interactions with others, supportive counseling, and group and individual activities. 
(5)  Rest periods when needed or ordered by a participant's physician. 
(6)  Opportunities for physical exercises, in relation to impairments, including indoor and outdoor activities 
(7)  Nursing services provided by program nurse which include evaluation of the participant's needs, routine health monitoring, and supervision and administration of medications. 
(8)  Each operation shall specify additional services, if any, that are available to participants. Such services may include but are not limited to, physical therapy; occupational therapy, speech and hearing therapy, skilled and restorative nursing services, except that such services shall be provided only upon written order from a participant's physician and provided by staff licensed to delivered such services. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 3-4, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-511. - Closure by department. 
    The Community Development Department may order immediate closure of a daycare facility it finds: 
(1)  An immediate threat to health, safety or welfare of participants: 
(2)  Evidence of abuse, cruelty or indifference to participants of their need. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 3-5, 9-23-97; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-512. - Facility requirements. 
(a)  There shall be a minimum of 60 square feet of activity area per participant. The minimum is exclusive of exit passages, fire escapes, administrative space, storage areas, bathrooms, and space required for equipment or other such areas. The square footage is dependant on the mobility need of the clients. 
(b)  Each facility shall have at least one handicapped accessible bathroom facility for up to 12 participants and a minimum of two bathroom facilities (one handicapped accessible) to serve 13 or more participants. 
(c)  Adult daycare shall have electronic door locks on all exterior doors to ensure the safety and security of participants. 
(d)  Adult daycare shall provide at least one quiet space equipped with reclining chairs, cots, beds where the participant may rest. 
(e)  All furniture, equipment, materials and facilities shall be capable of easy cleaning and sanitation. 
(f)  Call bells shall be installed or placed in rest areas, bathroom stalls and showers. 
(g)  A fire alarm system as designated by the village fire department shall be installed and operational. 
(h)  Table space shall be adequate for all participants to be served a meal at a table at the same time. 
(i)  All rugs and floor coverings must be securely fastened down. Floors shall not be slippery. 
(j)  Handrails should be provided as necessary to ensure safety of the participants. 
(k)  A separate locked area for storing chemicals, poisons, and other potentially harmful products (cleaning fluids, disinfectants. etc.) shall be provided. 
(l)  A separate locked cabinet for medications with the client's name shall be provided. All medications should come in a prescription bottle and prescription medications shall be documented by a physicians order. All medications shall be administered by an appropriately licensed professional. 
(m)  Participant files shall be maintained in a confidential file and contain the following: 
(1)  Name, address, phone, sex, age, next of kin, person to be notified in case of emergency. 
(2)  Functional (physical and psycho-social) assessment including original and revised progress notes. 
(3)  Individualized care plan. 
(4)  Physicians report including medical assessment and other subsequent information. 
(5)  Medications. 
(6)  Any accident reports. 
(7)  Periodic update to reflect client's condition and staff interventions. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 4-1-4-15, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-513. - Staffing and personnel requirements. 
    The following minimum ratios of full time staff or full time equivalent staff shall be present at daycare center when participants are in attendance: 
Staff Participants 2 1-12 3 13-20 4 21-28 5 29-35 6 36-45  
Required daycare staff must include a program nurse who is an RN licensed by the state or an LPN licensed by the state under the supervision of an RN. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 5-1, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-514. - Qualifications of an adult daycare administrator. 
    An adult daycare administrator, director, or program coordinator shall be required for the center. This person shall have a bachelor's degree in health, human services or related field (including social or health sciences) or be an RN or health service administrator. They shall demonstrate two years of responsible supervisory experience in programs serving the elderly. The director shall designate a qualified alternate to serve in his or her absence. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 5-2, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-515. - Qualifications of the staff. 
    Each staff member shall have a high school diploma or two years prior experience. It is recommended that staff have a background in human, physical, pyscho-social concepts and appropriate working experiences with first aid and CPR training. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 5-3, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-516. - Staffing requirements. 
    Medical consultant: Must be M.D. licensed in State of Illinois. 
    Social worker: Must have a BS in Social Work and one year of experience. 
    Rehab consultant: Must have a BS degree, be licensed, registered or certified in Illinois. 
    Registered dietician: Must on staff or on a contractual basis. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 5-4, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-517. - Physical examination. 
    Each employee shall have a physical examination including a TB screening within 12 months prior to employment. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 5-5, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-518. - Food handling. 
(a)  All food service operations whether catered or prepared on-site, must comply with all applicable requirements of the state. Food Service Sanitation Rules and Regulations and the provisions of the Village of Niles Code relating to food and food service establishments. 
(b)  At least one staff member shall have certification from the State Department of Public Health as a certified food handler. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, §§ 6-1, 6-2, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-519. - Transportation. 
(a)  Transportation staff shall meet all applicable requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.). 
(b)  Transportation shall be available to enable participants to attend sponsored outings and be a part of the programs and services offered. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, §§ 7-1, 7-2, 9-23-97; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-520. - Parking. 
    Operations must meet the parking requirements as outlined in the village zoning ordinance of special uses for adult daycare centers and provide an additional space for a van or bus. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, § 8-1, 9-23-97) 
Sec. 22-521. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The Community Development Department of the Village shall have the responsibility to assure compliance with this article and coordination of inspections for renewal on an annual basis. 
(b)  Inspectors of the Community Development Department of the Village shall within constitutional limitations be able to enter an adult daycare center at any reasonable time in order to inspect the premises so as to determine whether an adult daycare center is in compliance with this ordinance. The building code enforcement department shall issue a report of findings and statement of violation to which the adult daycare provider shall report of corrections within 30 days. Violations shall be based on rate of non-compliance threat to safety, health or welfare of participants and other findings so documented in the report. 
(c)  Any adult daycare provider who violates, disobeys, omits neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article shall be subject to fines in accordance with the general provisions of the Village of Niles Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 1997-30, §§ 9-1-9-3, 9-23-97; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 22-522-22-540. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - SEXUALLY-ORIENTED BUSINESSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, adopted Mar. 28, 2000, was intended to be included as a new art. VIII, §§ 12-230-12-241. However, to maintain the continuity of the Code, said ordinance was included as a new art. XV, §§ 22-541-22-552. 

Sec. 22-541. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person directly or indirectly to own or operate a sexually-oriented business as defined herein without a license as provided herein. 
(b)  A sexually-oriented business is one in which the dominant commercial activity is sale, rental, exhibition of material or activity depicting: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
(2)  Aspects of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; or 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breast, or any performance of such sexual activities. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-542. - Eligibility for license. 
(a)  A license to own and operate a sexually-oriented business may be issued only to a natural person who is: 
(1)  Not less than 25 years of age; and 
(2)  A resident of the village or who agrees to become such within 30 days of issuance of a license. 
(b)  No such license may be issued to any corporation. Further, no license shall be issued to any natural person who: 
(1)  Has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for determination of eligibility to receive a license or has given false or deceptive information; or 
(2)  Has been convicted in any jurisdiction of any felony or of any offense involving sexual conduct or obscenity or has owned directly or indirectly any sexually-oriented business as to which a license has been revoked or suspended in any jurisdiction; or is residing with any such person. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-543. - Term of license; fee. 
    A license shall be valid for a period for a period of six months unless sooner terminated or revoked. Please refer to the Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Sec. 22-544. - Hours of operation. 
    No business licensed under this chapter shall be open to the public before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. or at any time on Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-545. - Minimum age. 
    No person shall be employed in any licensed sexually-oriented business who is not at least 21 years of age. No person shall be allowed to enter such business premises who are not at least 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-546. - Other sales prohibited. 
    No licensed sexually-oriented business shall be permitted to sell any food, beverage, or tobacco product. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-547. - Inspections. 
    Any premises licensed under this chapter shall comply with all reasonable rules and regulations of the village health department, fire department, and police department and shall be subject to inspection by any authorized city officer at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-548. - Visibility; lighting. 
    Any premises licensed under this chapter shall have a front window or windows and an interior arrangement such that there is a clear and unobstructed view from outside the premises, through the front window(s) into all parts of the premises accessible to customers. Lighting in all parts of the premises accessible to customers shall be not less than 150 foot-candles at all times that the building is open for business. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-549. - Suspension, revocation, hearing, fines, and cost. 
(a)  The president shall be charged with the administration of this chapter. The president may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this chapter if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of the chapter, and may levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed by the president shall not exceed $500.00 for each violation. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing before the liquor license review board with not less than ten days' written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The hearing shall be conducted as in the case of hearings regarding liquor license violations, and the liquor license review board shall have the power to recommend to the president findings and policies for violations of this chapter. The president shall serve a written order setting forth his findings and any penalty to be imposed. 
(c)  Any licensee determined by the president to have violated any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to any fine imposed, pay to the village the costs of the hearing before the president on such violation. The president shall determine the costs incurred by the village for said hearing including, but not limited to, court reporters' fees, the cost of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the cost of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the village may allow. The licensee shall pay said costs to the village within 30 days of notification of the costs by the president. Failure to pay said costs within 30 days of notification is a violation of this chapter and may be cause for license suspension or revocation or the levy of a fine. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-550. - Transfer of license. 
    The license shall be purely a personal privilege and shall not constitute property nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment, or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable voluntarily or involuntarily or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. The license shall permit the licensed activity only on the premises described in the application and license. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-551. - Bond required. 
    No license shall be issued unless the licensee shall first deposit with the city a bond with a corporate surety, such corporate surety to be an "AA"-rated surety company regularly authorized to act as surety and approved by the Director of Finance with respect to its rating as a surety company. Such bond shall provide against any violation by the principal, his agents, or employees of any of the terms of this chapter or any rules and regulations now in force or which may hereafter be enforced in the village affecting the operation of such business. The penalty of such bond shall be $3,000.00, and the purpose of such bond shall be to cover the costs of enforcement, prosecution, as well as the cost of hearing by the president on the question of suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 22-552. - Penalty. 
    In addition to, or in lieu of any administrative sanction imposed pursuant to section 22-549, any violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof by a court of law, be punishable by a fine. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. Please refer to the Appendix E Penalties of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 3-28-00; Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, 1-24-17) 
Secs. 22-553-22-559. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - CYBER CENTERS[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-05, § 1, adopted January 24, 2017, repealed §§ 22-560-22-570, which pertained to cyber centers and derived from Ord. No. 2003-06, § 1, 1-28-03. 

Secs. 22-560-22-589. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES 

Sec. 22-590. - Licensing residential properties used for rental purpose. 
(a)  Definition: Rental Unit means a single-family detached dwelling, a single-family attached dwelling, a multiple-family dwelling, townhouse, condominium or rooming house. 
(b)  License required: No person shall rent a rental unit unless they hold a current unrevoked operating license issued by the Director of Community Development in his name for the specific named rental unit. 
(c)  Period of license: All licenses issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall commence on October 1 of the year for which such license is issued and shall expire on September 30 of the following year. 
(d)  Requirements: The Director of Community Development is hereby authorized to issue a new operating license for each rental unit. No such license shall be issued unless the rental unit meets all applicable requirements of this Code and all laws of the state regarding rental units. 
(e)  Application form: No operating license shall be issued or renewed unless the owner or operator has submitted a completed application on an application form provided by the Director of Community Development. 
(f)  Inspection: No operating license shall be issued or renewed unless the owner or operator agrees, on the application, to inspections as the Director of Community Development will require once every three years. Inspections are to determine whether the rental unit(s) for which such license is being sought is in compliance with the applicable provisions of this Code and with the applicable rules and regulations. Properties that are initially enrolling into the crime free multi-housing program shall be inspected prior to a license being issued. 
(g)  License fee: No operating license shall be issued or renewed unless the complete application form is accompanied by payment of a license fee as outlined in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. The fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar months which have expired prior to the issuance of the license. 
(h)  Representation for notice: No operating license shall be issued or renewed for a nonresident applicant unless such applicant designates in writing to the Director of Community Development the name of an agent in the Village of Niles for the receipt of service of notice of violation of the provisions of this Code. No operating license shall be issued or renewed for a resident applicant, unless such applicant has first designated an agent for the receipt of service of violations of the provisions of this Code when the applicant reasonably expected to be absent from the village for a period of 30 days or more. Such designation shall be made in writing, and shall accompany each application form. All applications shall include a street address of the owner and designated agent(s). Post office boxes will not be accepted. 
(1)  A property manager shall be considered an agent of the owner. If a new property manager is hired, the new property manager shall have three months after hiring to attend the Village of Niles Crime Free Multi Housing Program Seminar. 
(2)  Any owner, agent or designee shall attend the Seminar once every three years and be compliant with this article prior to expiration of a license for that particular year. 
(i)  Display of license: Each license shall be displayed in the foyer or other conspicuous place within the common ways of a multiple family dwelling. License for single-family detached dwelling units, single-family attached dwelling units, townhouse, condominium and rooming house rental units need only be retained by the licensee. 
(j)  Transferability: No license shall be transferable to another person or to another rental unit. Every person holding an operating license shall give notice in writing to the Director of Community Development within 24 hours after having transferred or otherwise disposed of the legal control of any licensed rental unit. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person or persons succeeding to the ownership or control of such rental unit. 
(k)  Notice of violation: Whenever, upon inspection of the licensed rental unit, the Director of Community Development or his designee finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of the provisions of this Code or of any applicable rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto the Director of Community Development shall serve the owner or operator with notice of such violation in the manner hereinafter provided. Such notice shall state that unless the violation(s) cited is corrected within a reasonable time period, the operating license may be suspended or revoked. 
(l)  Re-inspection and suspension of license: At the end of the time the Director of Community Development has allowed for correction of any violation cited, the code enforcement officer shall re-inspect the rental property and if he determines that such condition(s) has not been corrected, Director of Community Development may issue an order suspending the operating license and inspection of the rental property. 
(m)  Crime free Multi-Housing Seminar: Any owner, agent or designee will be required to attend the Village of Niles Crime Free Multi-Housing Seminar: 
(1)  Any owner, agent or designee will be required to re-attend the Village of Niles Crime Free Multi-Housing: 
(i)  If the property rented by the owner is becoming a nuisance residential property as defined in section 18-220 of this Code. 
(ii)  Criminal activity in excess of two incidents in a six-month period, which is indicated or perpetrated by renters, guests, or visitors. 
(iii)  Any property in which they are deemed a public nuisance as defined in section 66-4 of the Niles Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Reciprocal Seminar Agreement: An owner, agent or designee may provide proof of attendance at another agency's Crime Free Multi Housing Seminar. If you have attended a seminar in another town within the last year, an owner, agent or designee may be exempt from attending Niles seminar with a few exceptions: 
(i)  An owner, agent or designee must provide a copy of the lease addendum you will be using in Niles and provide the Crime Free Coordinator with a signed letter from the police department in the town you attended the seminar. 
If you are attending a seminar in Niles and own property in any of the towns designated by the Crime Free Housing Coordinator as approved communities towns or any new towns that participate in the program, a signature from coordinator and a letter of exemption will be given to you for your other properties. 
(3)  Retraining Required: All owners, agents or designees are required to complete a refresher course every three years. Failure to maintain Seminar Certification or Refresher Certification will result in a license suspension or revocation. 
(n)  Appeal and revocation of license: Any person whose license for a rental unit has been suspended shall be entitled to a reconsideration of the order by an administrative hearing. If no request for reconsideration reaches the hearing officer within ten days following the issuance of the order of suspension, the license shall be revoked, except that prior to revocation any person whose license has been suspended may request a re-inspection upon showing that the violation or violations cited in the notice have been corrected. If the violations are corrected, the suspension shall be lifted by the Director of Community Development. 
(o)  Extremely hazardous conditions: In the event of a condition of extreme hazard to health or safety is found to exist, the Director of Community Development may immediately revoke the license. Further action may be taken pursuant to Chapter 18, Buildings and Building Regulations, Article V, Dangerous Buildings. 
(p)  Separate violation: Each day a licensed residential rental property continues to operate after a license has been revoked shall constitute a separate violation of this Code subject to fine, within the limits as provided by state or local laws. 
(q)  Fine: Any licensee violating any provisions of this Code shall be subject to fine within the limits as provided by state or local laws. 
(r)  Reinstatement of license: If, upon re-inspection, the code enforcement officer finds that a licensed residential rental property is now in compliance with this Code and with applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto the code enforcement officer shall reinstate the license. 
(Ord. No. 2008-30, § 1, 6-25-08; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 1-28-14; Ord. No. 2016-44, § 1, 7-26-16; Ord. No. 2017-10, § 2, 2-28-17; Ord. No. 2018-41, § 1, 7-10-18) 
Sec. 22-591. - Crime free multi-housing program. 
    The Niles Police Department in conjunction with the Village of Niles Community Development Department offers this mandatory program in an effort to deter crime on rental properties. 
(a)  Any owner of the property or property manager, which property is being rented out for residential purposes will attend and complete the Village of Niles Crime Free Multi-Housing Program Seminar. In the event that the owner, resides outside the State of Illinois for longer than 90 days the owner will designate an agent or designee who lives within the state who is required to attend the seminar. 
(b)  The crime free multi-housing coordinator, as designated by the chief of police, shall provide the Director of Community Development with the list of owners, agents and/or designees who have attended the Village of Niles Crime Free Multi-Housing Program Seminar with the date of attendance and verification that the owner, agent or designee has complied with this article. 
(c)  Any owner, agent or designee of residential rental property is required to utilize a crime free lease addendum or have a clause in the lease similar to a crime free lease addendum. The crime free multi-housing coordinator shall provide at no cost samples of the crime free lease addendum and shall review any clauses within actual leases with the Village Attorney to determine if the clause is similar to the crime free lease addendum. The clause is to make criminal activity (not limited to violent criminal activity or drug related criminal activity engaged by, facilitated by or permitted by the renter, member of the household, guest or other party under the control of the renter) a lease violation. The landlord shall have authority under this clause to initiate eviction proceedings as specified in the Illinois Compiled Statues Forcible Entry and Detainer 735 ILCS 5/9-101 et seq. Proof of criminal violation shall be by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(d)  Nuisance residential rental property. It is hereby declared a nuisance and against the health, peace and comfort of the village for any property owner, agent, or manager to allow or permit the following: a) rental of a residential unit, or residential building within an apartment community or governed by a homeowner's association to a tenant who allows any of the following offenses relating to the tenant, member of the tenant household, guest or other party under control of the tenant to occur: murder, kidnapping, aggravated kidnapping, prostitution, solicitation of prostitution, pandering child pornography, harmful materials, criminal housing management, possession of explosive, unlawful use of weapons, sale of firearms, gambling, keeping a gambling place, concealing a fugitive, violation of the Illinois Controlled substances Act, violation of the Cannabis Control Act or commission of any two or more of any other crimes under the State of Illinois or under the Federal Government not specifically listed above; b) rental of a residential unit, or residential building within an apartment community or governed by a homeowner's association to a tenant who allows said property to be deemed a chronic nuisance property as set forth in section 18-138 of the Village Code. 
(e)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in section 22-591 (c) and (d) the Village shall not enforce its crime free multi-housing program based on: 
(1)  Contact made to police or other emergency services if (i) the contact was made with the intent to prevent or respond to a domestic violence or sexual violence (ii) the intervention or emergency assistance was needed to respond to or prevent domestic violence or sexual violation or (iii) the contact was made by on behalf of, or otherwise concerns an individual with a disability and the purpose of the contact was related to that individuals disability; 
(2)  An incident or incidents of actual or threatened domestic violence or sexual violence against a tenant, household member or guest occurring in the dwelling unit or on the premises; or 
(3)  Criminal activity or a Village ordinance violation occurring in the dwelling unit or on the premises that is directly relating to domestic violence or sexual violence, engaged in by a tenant, member of a tenant's household, guest or other party, and against a tenant, household member, guest or other party. 
(f)  However, nothing with respects to this section: 
(1)  Limits enforcement of Section 15.2 of the Illinois Emergency Telephone System Act, Article 26 of the Criminal Code of 2012 or Article IV of the Code of Civil Procedure; 
(2)  Prohibits the Village from enacting or enforcing its crime free multi-housing program and ordinance to impose penalties on the basis of underlying criminal activity or Village ordinance not covered in section (e), subsections (1), (2), and (3) and to the extent otherwise permitted by existing State and Federal Law; or 
(3)  Limits or prohibits the eviction of or imposition of penalties against the perpetrator of the domestic violence, sexual violence or other criminal activity. 
(Ord. No. 2008-30, § 1, 6-25-08; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 1-28-14; Ord. No. 2017-38, § 1, 6-27-2017) 
Secs. 22-592-22-609. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - AMUSEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - TRAMPOLINE CENTERS 

Sec. 22-610. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms used herein are defined as follows: 
    Monitor shall mean a person in close proximity to a trampoline whose function is to watch and protect the safety of another person while the latter is using a trampoline. 
    Supervisor shall mean a person trained and experienced in the supervision and control of persons in the use of trampolines as provided herein. 
    To operate a trampoline center shall mean to manage, conduct, maintain, carry on, or own the business of operating a trampoline center. 
    To use a trampoline shall mean to jump, bounce, or tumble, or otherwise perform tricks, stunts, or acrobatics upon, or otherwise use, such trampoline. 
    Trampoline shall mean a device consisting of a bed of canvas, fabric, or other material attached to a framework by springs, rubber coils, or other elastic material upon which a person can jump, bounce, or perform acrobatic tumbling. 
    Trampoline center shall mean any place of business open to the public for the purpose of offering the use of a trampoline at a price. 
    Trampoline court shall mean many trampolines arranged in a grid, with thick layers of padding covering the metal support structure. The walls of each court are trampolines set at an angle, so there's no danger of bouncing off the side. 
(Ord. No. 2011-33, § 1, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Sec. 22-611. - Business license; requirement; application. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, or corporation to operate a commercial trampoline center within the corporate limits of Niles, Illinois, without first having obtained a business license. Application for the business license shall be made to the Community Development Director upon forms to be supplied by the village, containing the following information: 
(a)  Name and address of the applicant; 
(b)  Business capacity of applicant (corporation, partnership, sole proprietor, or other); 
(c)  Name and address of manager; 
(d)  Location of proposed facility; 
(e)  Number of trampolines to be located at each center; 
(f)  Such other information respecting the proposed facility as may be required by either the Director of Community Development or by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 2011-33, § 1, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Sec. 22-612. - Special building permit; application and plans. 
    Every person, partnership, or corporation who locates and constructs a commercial trampoline center within the corporate limits shall first procure a special permit from the Director of Community Development. Each such application shall be accompanied by two sets of plans and specifications, each page of which shall be appropriately identified as to name of applicant and location of facility and signed by the applicant and showing, to the satisfaction of the building official, the following: 
(a)  The plot plan or layout of the components of the facility, including size, location, and height of all trampolines (including bed and framing), buildings, seating, fences and other structures, lighting, entrances and exits, landscaping, off-street parking facilities, and the like. 
(b)  Elevation plan showing cross-section in detail of typical trampoline equipment in place, including excavation, structural support and manner of installation, and indicating the size and nature of construction materials. 
(c)  Specifications showing type and manufacturer of trampoline equipment and padding, including materials of construction, capacity, and the like. (Manufacturer's specifications, if complete, may be submitted for this purpose.) 
    The applicant for such permit shall pay a fee as found in appendix D, section 18-2 for such permit which shall be paid before the permit is issued. No permit shall be issued within any district in which such commercial trampoline center is prohibited by the zoning ordinance as it now exists or may hereafter be amended. If the Director of Community Development is satisfied that the application for permit and accompanying documents and the proposed trampoline center conform to the requirements of this chapter and other applicable laws, and that the prescribed fees have been paid, the Director of Community Development shall issue a special building permit therefor to the applicant. Such permit may be in the form of a city building permit whose caption has been amended by the Department of Community Development to read "building permit-trampoline," in which case such permit, when issued, shall constitute any required building permit for construction under the building code. Nothing herein shall be deemed to relieve the applicant of complying with any applicable permit fee or permit application requirements contained in the building code or other ordinances of the Village of Niles. 
(Ord. No. 2011-33, § 1, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Sec. 22-613. - Amendment of plans. 
    Any person who desires to make any addition to, or change or alteration in a trampoline center or any part which is not shown on or in conformity with plans and specifications previously filed by such person as required in section 22-612, shall first file an application for an amended permit accompanied by appropriate amended plans and specifications showing such change or changes. The fee for filing such application shall be found in appendix D, section 18-2. 
(Ord. No. 2011-33, § 1, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Sec. 22-614. - Construction to comply with plans. 
    After issuance of a permit, no person shall construct, install, or operate a trampoline center which is, or any portion or facility of which is designed or constructed other than in accordance with the plans and specifications on file with the building official and upon which a permit or amended permit has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 2011-33, § 1, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 2011-41, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Sec. 22-615. - Construction and installation specifications. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a trampoline center unless: 
(a)  The minimum distance from any individual trampoline that makes up or is a part of a trampoline court, measured from the outside dimension of the frame, to any other trampoline or structure or other obstruction, shall be at least five feet at the ends and four feet at the sides and around the corners. 
(b)  There shall be maintained above each trampoline a clearance of 18 feet from any ceiling, roof, wire, or other overhead obstruction. 
(c)  The rigid framework of each trampoline shall be completely covered at the ends, sides, and corners with padding. 
(d)  Each trampoline shall be rigidly installed to prevent shifting of the equipment while in use. 
(e)  All trampoline equipment, including the bed, springs, frame, and padding shall be maintained in a good state of repair. 
(f)  Safety netting or similar material shall be provided for each trampoline or court. 
(g)  An outdoor trampoline center (excluding that portion devoted to off-street parking) shall be completely surround by a fence of at least five feet in height, or by any structure equivalent thereto. 
(h)  There shall be conveniently located up on the premises a telephone available for emergency use at all times. There shall be conspicuously posted on or near such telephone the phone number of available emergency medical service and of the fire department and police department.
