    The person discriminated against by any violation of any provision of this chapter may, not later than 60 days after the date of the alleged violation, file a written complaint setting forth his grievance with the board of trustees. The complaint shall state the name and address of the complainant and of the person against whom the complaint is brought and shall also state the facts claimed to constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 111/2-6(a)) 
Sec. 58-72. - Enforcement of article. 
(a)  Investigation; conciliation conference; report. The village manager or his designee shall investigate immediately every such complaint filed. If the village manager determines that the respondent has not engaged in any unlawful practice, he shall state his findings of fact in writing and dismiss the complaint. If the village manager determines that probable cause of a violation exists, he shall set a date for a conciliation conference. At such conference the village manager shall interview the complainant and the person against whom the complaint has been directed and shall attempt to resolve the complaint by all proper methods of conciliation and persuasion. At the conclusion of the conference, the village manager shall render a written report and recommendations to the board of trustees, copies of which shall be served by certified mail upon the complainant and the respondent. 
(b)  Methods of enforcement. If the board of trustees shall have determined that probable cause of a violation of this chapter exists and if the conciliation efforts shall not have resulted in a settlement of the complaint, the board shall enforce the provisions of this article in one or more of the following ways: 
(1)  Direct the village attorney to file with the state department of professional regulation a complaint against any real estate broker or salesperson found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter, seeking suspension or revocation of the certificate of registration issued to such broker by the state. 
(2)  Impose a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00. 
(Code 1965, § 111/2-7) 
Chapter 62 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6; board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.; Illinois police training act, 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Police Department created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a Police Department of the Village which shall consist of the Chief of Police, and such number of sworn officers and other employees as may be provided by the Board of Trustees from time to time; provided, however, that the Board of Trustees shall have the discretion to determine if the maximum number of such positions shall be filled. In the Police Department, there shall be one entry-level rank, namely patrol officer, and one promotional rank, namely sergeant, and exempt deputy chiefs and watch commanders as may be provided for by the Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 25-1; Ord. No. 2019-16, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 62-2. - Office of Police Chief created; term, Appointment; Tenure; Compensation; Removal. 
    There is hereby created the office of Chief of Police. The Office of the Police Chief shall be filled by an appointment, made by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, of a person competent to carry out the duties of the office. Such appointment shall be based upon the demonstrated ability, knowledge and experience in the management of government affairs effectively in law enforcement. The Police Chief shall be responsible to the Village Manager for the effective management and control of the law enforcement activities of the Village. The Police Chief shall report to the Village Manager and submit to the Village Manager or the Board of Trustees such reports as the law requires. Compensation may be set by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. The Police Chief may be removed by the Village Manager with the consent of the President and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 25-2; Ord. No. 2019-16, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2019-16, § 1, adopted May 28, 2019, changed the title of § 62-2, from "Office of police chief created; term" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 62-3. - General duties of Police Chief. 
    The Chief of Police is the chief administrator and executive officer of the Police Department. Upon this office rests the final responsibility of determining departmental policies, together with the full responsibility for the complete discharge of all duties imposed on the Chief of Police by law, ordinance and/or resolution. In the capacity as chief executive and administrative head of the department, the Chief of Police maintains administrative control and governs departmental activity through Deputy Chiefs and Watch Commanders, who also act in an advisory capacity in matters of general departmental policies and procedures. 
(Code 1965, § 25-2.1; Ord. No. 2005-35, § 2, 9-27-05; Ord. No. 2019-16, § 1, 5-28-19) 
Sec. 62-4. - Probationary period for patrol officers-Original. 
(a)  All original patrol officer appointees to the police department shall be appointed on a probationary basis. The term of each appointee's probationary status shall commence on the date of the appointee's original appointment to the police department and shall continue for a period of two years from and after the date excluding any periods of leave of absence, whether paid or unpaid. 
(b)  After successful completion of the probationary period and upon written recommendation of the chief of police that the officer be certified, and the concurrence of the board of fire and police commissioners, the officer shall attain certified status and be listed by the commission in the official records as a certified nonprobationary patrol officer. 
(Code 1965, § 25-3) 
State Law reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 62-5. - Same-Promotions to sergeant. 
    A patrol officer who is appointed to the rank of sergeant shall serve a probationary period of one year. The probationary sergeant who fails to successfully complete the probation period for deficiencies in leadership ability, administrative skills, communication skills, ability to function in a satisfactory manner in emergency situations, ability to supervise subordinates, ability to perform duties and functions in conformance with the established goals of the department, or violates any rule or regulation of the police department or the board of fire and police commissioners shall retain the right to reemployment with the rank from which promoted and hold certified status with reduction in compensation to a rate not exceeding the maximum rate of such lower rank. Upon successful completion of the probationary period, the probationary sergeant shall, upon the written request of the chief of police and concurrence of the board of fire and police commissioners, attain status as a certified sergeant and be listed by the commission in the official record of certified sergeants. 
(Code 1965, § 25-3.1) 
Sec. 62-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-16, § 1, adopted April 24, 2018, repealed former § 62-6 which pertained to auxiliary police, and derived from the 1965 Code, § 25-4; Ord. No. 1994-29, § 1, adopted May 24, 1994; and Ord. No. 2007-48, § 1, adopted Oct. 23, 2007. 
Sec. 62-7. - Reserved.

Sec. 62-11. - Regulations governing police officers. 
    The police officers of the village shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed from time to time by the chief of police and the board of fire and police commissioners; provided, however, that no rule or regulation made or issued by the chief of police shall conflict with any rule or regulation which may be made by the president and board of trustees for the conduct and control of the police department, and all rules and regulations made by the president and board of trustees shall be transmitted to the chief of police who shall, in turn, make such provisions as are necessary for their enforcement. 
(Code 1965, § 25-9) 
Sec. 62-12. - Participation in program provided by state police training act. 
(a)  The village hereby elects to participate in the program as provided by the state police training act (50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.), as amended. 
(b)  To become and remain eligible for continued participation in the program, the chief of police for the village is hereby instructed to comply with each and every provision, requirement and condition as provided in the state police training act (50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 25-10) 
Sec. 62-13. - Fingerprinting. 
    The police department is authorized to make copies of the fingerprints of any person, at that person's request, upon the filing of an application for fingerprints on a form designated by the chief of police. Refer to Appendix D Fee Schedule for all related fees. 
(Code 1965, § 25-12; Ord. No. 2014-19, § 1, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 62-14. - Golf Mill Shopping Center security. 
    Pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/3-9-4, as amended, security officers employed by the Management firm on behalf of Milwaukee Golf Development Company, the owner of the Golf Mill Shopping Center, shall be designated conservators of the peace subject to individual approval by the chief of police. The chief of police shall establish such limitations and controls upon the exercise of such authority as may be appropriate to limit the authority to the issuance of parking citations on shopping center property while such employee is on duty. The authorization may be terminated by the chief of police at any time without cause. 
(Code 1965, § 25-13) 
Secs. 62-15-62-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PENSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Police pension fund, 40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 

Sec. 62-36. - Board created; membership. 
    The police pension fund of the village shall be administered by a board of trustees consisting of five members, chosen in the manner set forth in this section. All members of the board of trustees of the police pension fund of the village shall serve for a one-year term. Two members of the board of trustees shall be appointed by the president with the consent of the village board of trustees. Two members of the board of trustees shall be elected by the active members of the police department. One member of the board of trustees shall be elected by the retired members of the police department receiving a pension from the fund. Terms of office shall begin on the first Tuesday in May of the year in which they are elected. The election provided for in this section shall be held annually on the third Monday of April under the Australian ballot system, in such places in the village, under such regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the board. In the event of the death, resignation or inability to act of any such elected member of the board, the successor of the member shall be elected for the unexpired term in a special election, which shall be called by the board and shall be conducted in the manner as the annual election provided for in this section. The majority of the board of trustees of the police pension fund shall be required to transact business, and a majority vote of the full membership, as provided by law, is required for effective action by the board. Membership on the board shall not preclude membership on any other board or commission of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 25-41; Ord. No. 2006-57, § 2, 4-25-06) 
State Law reference- Police pension board of trustees, 40 ILCS 5/3-128. 
Sec. 62-37. - Offices; meeting rooms. 
    Suitable rooms for offices and meetings of such board shall be assigned by the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 25-42) 
Sec. 62-38. - Board to manage fund. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the exclusive control and management of the fund mentioned in this section, and of all moneys donated, paid or assessed for the relief or pensioning of disabled, superannuated and retired members of the police department, their widows, minor children and dependent parents. All such moneys shall be placed by the treasurer of the village to the credit of the fund, subject to the order of board. 
(Code 1965, § 25-43) 
State Law reference- Control and management of pension fund, 40 ILCS 5/3-132. 
Sec. 62-39. - Board to draw and invest funds. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the power and duty to draw such pension funds from the treasurer or other officials of the village and invest such fund or any part thereof in the name of the board of trustees of the police pension fund in interest bearing bonds or tax anticipation warrants of the United States, of the state or of any county of this state, or of any township or municipal corporation of the state and in insured shares of state chartered building and loan associations and insured shares of federal chartered federal savings if the shares are insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. All securities shall be deposited with the treasurer of the village and be subject to the order of the board. The interest received from any such investment shall be credited to the account of the pension fund. 
(Code 1965, § 25-44) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-135. 
Sec. 62-40. - Board may compel testimony; oaths. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the power to compel witnesses to attend and testify before it, upon all matters connected with the operation of this article in the same manner as is or may be provided by law for the taking of testimony before masters in chancery, and its president or any member of the board may administer oaths to such witnesses. 
(Code 1965, § 25-45) 
State Law reference- Authority to subpoena, administer oaths, 40 ILCS 5/3-136. 
Sec. 62-41. - Appointment; duties of clerk for board. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have power to appoint a clerk and define his duties; provided, however, that no person drawing a pension under this article shall be employed by the board as a clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 25-46) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-137. 
Sec. 62-42. - Board to pay expenses. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the power to provide for the payment from the fund of all its necessary expenses, including clerk hire, printing and witness fees, provided that no compensation or emolument shall be paid to any member of the board for any duty required or performed under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 25-47) 
State Law reference- Payment of expenses, 40 ILCS 5/3-138. 
Sec. 62-43. - Rules and regulations of board. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the power to make all necessary rules and regulations for its guidance in conformity with the provisions of this article. Such rules and regulations shall be published by the board, and copies shall be transmitted from time to time to all pensioners and contributors. 
(Code 1965, § 25-48) 
State Law reference- Authority to make rules and regulations, 40 ILCS 5/3-140. 
Sec. 62-44. - Treasurer to keep funds. 
    The treasurer of the village shall be the keeper of the funds of the board. 
(Code 1965, § 25-49) 
Sec. 62-45. - Reports; records of treasurer and other officials. 
    On the second Tuesday in May of each year, the treasurer and all other officials of the village who have had the custody or possession of any pension funds provided for in this article shall make a sworn statement to the board of trustees of the police pension fund, and to the president and board of trustees of the village, of all moneys received and paid out by such official on account of the pension fund during the year, and owing to the pension fund. All surplus then remaining in the official's hands shall be paid by him to the treasurer of the village, provided any official shall at any and all times upon demand by the pension board, furnish to the board a statement or information of any kind relative to the official method of collection or handling of the pension funds. All books and records of such official shall be produced at any time by the official for examination and inspection by the board of pension trustees for the purpose provided in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 25-50) 
State Law reference- Annual report by treasurer, 40 ILCS 5/3-141. 
Sec. 62-46. - Reports by board. 
    The board of trustees of the pension fund shall make report to the board of trustees of the village of the condition of the pension fund. Such report shall be made prior to the meeting of such board of trustees held for the purpose of levying of taxes for the year for which such report is made. The board shall certify to the board of trustees of the village: 
(1)  The assets in their custody at such time. 
(2)  The estimated receipts during the next succeeding calendar year from deduction from the salaries or wages of police officers as provided in this article and from all other sources. 
(3)  The estimated amount required during the calendar year for paying all pensions and other obligations provided for in accordance with the provisions of this article and establishing and maintaining the reserve fund provided for by law. 
(Code 1965, § 25-51) 
State Law reference- Report by pension board to village board of trustees, 40 ILCS 5/3-143. 
Secs. 62-47-62-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESTORATION TO ACTIVE SERVICE 

Sec. 62-80. - Procedures. 
(a)  Preliminary procedure. Before a police officer can be reinstated to active service, he or she shall submit to the following process: 
(1)  Submit to a reemployment physical examination to determine overall health. 
(2)  Submit to a psychological evaluation by the police psychologist. 
(3)  Submit to a work capacity evaluation test based upon his/her specific job description. 
(b)  Reinstatement procedure. Having successfully completed subsection (a) above, the reinstatee shall submit to the requirements of the police department as follows: 
(1)  Refer to a certified police academy for the physical power and range qualifications/requirements. 
(2)  Take and pass the 40-hour legal course required by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board. 
(3)  Refer to the Niles Police Department Field Training Program (FTO) staff for recertification in this program. 
(4)  Submit to an oral interview by the Command Staff of the Niles Police Department addressing job skills/talents for the reinstatee's specific position with subsequent recommendations. 
(c)  [Completion.] Having successfully completed the above requirements, the chief of the department shall notify the reinstatee that he/she is being reinstated to active duty. 
(Ord. No. 2006-34, § 1, 8-22-06) 
Chapter 66 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; civil emergencies, ch. 30; emergency services, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 82; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6; crimes generally, 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Interrupting funeral procession or assembly. 
    Whoever willfully drives a vehicle into or interrupts or disturbs a funeral procession shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-21) 
State Law reference- Right-of-way of funeral processions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1420. 
Sec. 66-2. - Intoxication. 
    If any person shall be in a state of intoxication in any highway, street, thoroughfare or public place within the village, or in any private house or place to the annoyance of any citizen or person, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-22) 
Sec. 66-3. - Smoking prohibited in certain locations. 
    Smoking or the carrying of a lighted cigar, pipe or cigarette is prohibited in the following locations: 
(1)  High hazard rooms. 
(2)  Institutional buildings, except in the administrative office and in rooms designated as smoking rooms. 
(3)  Theaters, except in rooms designated as smoking rooms. 
(4)  Churches, schools, garages and hangars, except in rooms designated as smoking rooms. 
(5)  Structures housing livestock, including circuses and stock shows. 
(6)  Mercantile establishments. 
(7)  Any other room or space where the combustible nature and quantity of contents, or the occupancy content are deemed by the fire prevention bureau to be hazardous to life and property from fire. 
(Code 1965, § 22-30) 
Sec. 66-4. - Public nuisance. 
(a)  When a determination of the existence of a nuisance is made as a result of an order issued by the village president pursuant to the administrative hearing process, or by section 66-4(b), the village attorney may commence an action to abate the public nuisance in circuit court. 
(b)  It is a public nuisance: 
(1)  After a determination by the health and safety officer of the village, when an unreasonable risk to a resident's health and safety exists. 
(2)  To be in violation of any ordinance in chapter 22, article X, division 1, nursing homes. 
(3)  To be in violation of any ordinance in chapter 22, article XIV, adult day care centers. 
(4)  To be in violation of any ordinance in chapter 22, article XV, sexually-oriented businesses. 
(5)  Any other unreasonable risk to a resident's health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 2003-04, § 1, 1-28-03) 
Secs. 66-5-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses against the person, 720 ILCS 5/9-1 et seq. 

Sec. 66-31. - Use of certain devices in certain parts of village buildings prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall use (i) any electronic, mechanical, manual, electric, digital, voltaic or other device, instrument or means capable of recording, producing, duplicating, reproducing, storing, copying, transmitting or displaying any visual, video, photographic, electronic, digital, recorded, or other visual image, picture, or representation, including but not limited to any camera, photographic camera, video camera, fiber optic camera, motion picture camera, television camera, camcorder, or videotaping device, or (ii) any cell phone of any kind regardless of its capacity or lack thereof to produce a visual image, in any restroom, locker room, lavatory, bathroom, shower facility, or dressing room, in any building owned, leased to, or under the control of the village. 
(b)  Any person violating or disobeying any provision of this section may be arrested by the police hereinafter appointed to enforce this section and may be fined upon conviction the sum of $1,000.00, which fine may be recovered by an action in the name of the District in the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2004-4, § 1, 1-27-04) 
Secs. 66-32-66-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 66-51. - Cost of emergency services. 
    Any person who has more than 0.08 alcohol concentration in his blood or whose blood or urine contains evidence of the unauthorized use of cannabis, as defined by the State Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.), as amended, or of the unauthorized use of a controlled substance, as defined by the State Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.), as amended, and who causes an incident resulting in appropriate emergency response shall be required to make restitution to the village for the costs of that emergency response. Anyone under the age of 21 years found with any concentration of alcohol in their blood or urine who causes an incident resulting in appropriate emergency response shall be required to make restitution to the village for the costs of that emergency response. 
(Code 1965, § 22-4; Ord. No. 2002-10, § 2, 2-26-02) 
Sec. 66-52. - Maintaining public nuisance. 
    Any building used in the commission of offenses prohibited by sections 9-1, 10-1, 10-2, 11-14 through 11-17, 11-20, 11-20.1, 11-21, 11-22, 16-1, 20-2, 24-1(a)(7), 24-3, 28-1, 28-3, 31-5 or 37-1 of the state criminal code of 1961 (720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.), as amended, or prohibited by the state controlled substances act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.), as amended, or the cannabis control act (720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.), as amended, or prohibited by article V, division 2 of this chapter, or used in the commission of an inchoate offense relative to any of the principal offenses described in this section is a public nuisance. 
(Code 1965, § 22-10) 
State Law reference- Maintaining public nuisance, 720 ILCS 5/37-1. 
Sec. 66-53. - Trespassing on property. 
    No person shall enter into or upon any lot, block, or tract of ground in the village unless such person is an owner, lessee, or person entitled so to enter, or the duly authorized agent thereof, and any person found by the police in and upon such premises shall be treated as a trespasser unless he can produce satisfactory evidence of ownership or right to be in and upon any such premises. 
(Code 1965, § 22-29) 
Sec. 66-54. - Petit theft; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit petit theft which is hereby defined as a theft when the property taken is of a value of less than $150.00. 
(b)  Any person accused of such violation may settle and compromise the violation claim in respect of such ordinance by paying the municipality the amount of $50.00 within a period to be specified in the citation. If payment has not been received during this specified period of time, payment of $100.00 shall be accepted as settlement. 
(c)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject, upon conviction, to the penalties set forth in section 1-11. 
(Code 1965, § 22-31) 
State Law reference- Theft, 720 ILCS 5/16-1. 
Secs. 66-55-66-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE 

Sec. 66-76. - Loitering; authority to order persons loitering to disperse; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone and/or in consort with others in a public place in such manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tend to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians. 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress, therein, thereon and thereto. 
Persons waiting in line to purchase goods, services, or admission tickets may not do any act in violation of subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of this section nor violate any other law of the state or ordinance of the village. 
(b)  When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 22-9(a), (b)) 
Sec. 66-77. - Disorderly conduct. 
    A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly: 
(1)  Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; 
(2)  With intent to annoy another, makes a telephone call, whether or not conversation thereby ensues; 
(3)  Transmits in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village or fire protection district a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists; 
(4)  Transmits in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such bomb or explosive is concealed in such place; 
(5)  Transmits in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable ground for believing that such an offense has been committed; 
(6)  Enters upon the property of another and for a lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other opening in it; or 
(7)  While waiting in line, either alone or with others, to purchase goods, services or admission tickets, violates any law of the state or ordinance of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 22-9(c)) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1. 
Sec. 66-78. - Disturbing places of worship. 
    Any person who shall disquiet or disturb any congregation or assembly met for religious worship by making a noise, or by rude and indecent behavior or profane discourse within the place of worship, or so near to the same as to disturb the order and solemnity of the meeting, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-11) 
Secs. 66-79-66-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cannabis means marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant cannabis sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt derivative, mixture, or preparation of such plant, its seeds or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients; whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction or independently by means of chemical synthesis; or by a combination of extraction and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt derivative, mixture or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil, or cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination. 
    Gambling device means any clock, tape machine, slot machine or other machines or devices for the reception of money or other thing of value on chance or skill or upon the action of which money or other thing of value is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost, or any mechanism, furniture, fixture, equipment or other device usable for gambling. A gambling device does not include vending machines by which full and adequate return is made for the money invested and in which there is no element of chance or hazard. 
    Gambling place means any real estate, vehicle, boat or other property whatsoever used for the purpose of gambling. 
    Lottery means any scheme or procedure whereby one or more prizes are distributed by chance among persons who have paid or promised consideration for a chance to win such prizes, whether such scheme or procedure is called a lottery, raffle, gift, sale or some other name. 
    Policy game means any scheme or procedure whereby a person promises or guarantees by any instrument, bill, certificate, writing, token or other device that any particular number, character, ticket or certificate shall in the event of any contingency in the nature of a lottery entitle the purchaser or holder to receive money, property or evidence of debt. 
(Code 1965, §§ 22-15, 22-16, 22-32(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/28-2. 
Sec. 66-102. - Applicability of provisions relative to disorderly houses; gambling; obscenity within three miles of outer boundaries of village. 
    The provisions of this chapter pertaining to bawdy or disorderly houses and also houses of ill fame or assignation, gaming, gambling houses, lotteries, and all fraudulent devices or practices for the purpose of obtaining money or property, and the sale or exhibition of obscene or immoral publications, prints, pictures, illustrations or acts, shall apply to and regulate such conduct within three miles of the outer boundaries of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 22-9.1) 
State Law reference- Authority for application of ordinances outside municipal boundaries, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1. 
Sec. 66-103. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of gambling. A person commits gambling when he: 
(1)  Plays a game of chance or skill for money or other thing of value; 
(2)  Makes a wager upon the result of any game, contest, or any political nomination, appointment or election; 
(3)  Operates, keeps, owns, uses, purchases, exhibits, rents, sells, bargains for the sale or lease of, manufactures or distributes any gambling device; 
(4)  Contracts to have or give himself or another the option to buy or sell, or contracts to buy or sell, at a future time, any grain or other commodity whatsoever, or any stock or security of any company, where it is at the time of making such contract intended by both parties thereto that the contract to buy or sell, or the option, whenever exercised, or the contract resulting therefrom, shall be settled, not by receipt or delivery of such property, but by the payment only of differences in prices thereof; however, the issuance, purchase, sale, exercise, endorsement or guarantee, by or through a person registered with the secretary of state pursuant to section 8 of the securities law of 1953 (815 ILCS 5/8), as amended, or by or through a person exempt from such registration under said section 8, of a put, call, or other option to buy or sell securities which have been registered with the secretary of state or which are exempt from such registration under section 3 of the securities law of 1953 (815 ILCS 5/3), as amended, is not gambling within the meaning of this subsection; 
(5)  Uses or keeps any book, instrument or apparatus for the purpose of recording or registering bets or wagers or holds any funds which have been bet or wagered; 
(6)  Sells pools upon the result of any game or contest of skill or chance, political nomination, appointment or election; 
(7)  Sets up or promotes any lottery or sells, offers to sell, or transfers any ticket or share for any lottery; 
(8)  Sets up or promotes any policy game or sells, offers to sell or knowingly possesses or transfers any policy ticket, or other similar device; 
(9)  Knowingly transmits information as to wagers, betting odds, or changes in betting odds by telephone, telegraph, radio, semaphore or similar means; or knowingly installs or maintains equipment for the transmission or receipt of such information; except that nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the transmission or receipt of such information for use in news reporting of sporting events or contests; or 
(10)  Knowingly advertises any lottery or policy game or drafts, prints or publishes any lottery ticket or share, or any policy ticket or similar device, or any advertisement of any lottery or policy game. 
(Code 1965, § 22-13) 
State Law reference- Gambling, 720 ILCS 5/28-1 et seq. 
Sec. 66-104. - Insurance not considered gambling. 
    Participants in agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance including without limitation contracts of indemnity or guaranty and life or health or accident insurance shall not be guilty of gambling. 
(Code 1965, § 22-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/28-1(b)(1). 
Sec. 66-105. - Maintenance or keeping of gambling establishment or place. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly permit any premises or property owned or occupied by him or under his control to be used as a gambling place. When any premises is determined by a court having jurisdiction to be a gambling place: 
(1)  Such premises is a public nuisance and may be proceeded against as such; 
(2)  All licenses, permits or certificates issued by the village authorizing the serving of food or liquor on such premises shall be void; and no license, permit or certificate so cancelled shall be reissued for such premises for a period of 60 days thereafter; nor shall any person, convicted of keeping a gambling place, be reissued such license for one year from his conviction; and 
(3)  Such premises of any person who knowingly permits thereon a violation of sections 66-104 through 66-106 shall be held liable therefor and may be sold to pay any unsatisfied judgment that may be recovered and any unsatisfied fine that may be levied under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 22-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/28-3. 
Sec. 66-106. - Seizure of devices. 
    Every gambling device shall be subject to seizure, confiscation and destruction by the chief of police. 
(Code 1965, § 22-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 5/28-5. 
Sec. 66-107. - Sale of illegal drug usage paraphernalia. 
    No person licensed to do business in the village shall sell any item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed and primarily used for illegal drug usage. In addition to any other sanctions contained in this Code for violations thereof, conviction of a violation of this section shall be deemed cause for revocation of a business license. 
(Code 1965, § 19-68) 
Sec. 66-108. - Possession of cannabis prohibited; scope of section; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to knowingly possess any quantity of any substance containing cannabis, except the scope of this section shall be limited to persons knowingly possessing less than thirty (30) grams of any substance containing cannabis. 
(b)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject upon conviction as set forth in Appendix E Penalties and Section 1-11. 
(c)  In addition to the stated fines provided in this section, no provision of this section shall be construed to preclude or limit the presiding judge in each case in exercising his discretion to further issue and order such other corrective measures of the defendant as may be reasonable, equitable and appropriate, and as in each case may be necessary, including court supervision, probation, drug abuse counseling or psychiatric or social service counseling. 
(Code 1965, § 22-32(b), (c); Ord. No. 2017-12, § 1, 2-28-2017) 
Sec. 66-109. - Indecency; generally. 
    If any person shall appear in a public place in a state of nudity, or in indecent or lewd dress, or shall make any indecent exposure of his person, or be guilty of any lewd or indecent act or behavior, or shall exhibit, sell, or offer to sell, any indecent or lewd book, picture, film, or other thing, or exhibit or perform any indecent, immoral or lewd film, or play or representation, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-19) 
State Law reference- Public indecency, 720 ILCS 5/11-9. 
Sec. 66-110. - Marijuana flavored candy. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  "Person" shall mean any natural person, individual, corporation, unincorporated association, proprietorship, firm, partnership, joint venture, joint stock association or other entity or business organization of any kind. 
(2)  "Marijuana flavored candy" shall mean a lollipop, gumdrop or other candy which is flavored to taste like marijuana including, but not limited to, "Chronic Candy(r)." 
(b)  No person shall sell, give away, barter, exchange or otherwise furnish and marijuana flavored candy or other confection, dessert or food item which is flavored to taste like marijuana. No person shall make or manufacture any marijuana flavored candy or other confection, dessert or food item which is flavored to taste like marijuana. 
(c)  Any persons who is found in repeated violation of this subsection shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Any repeat violations of any provision of section 66-110 by a licensee shall be grounds for revocation or suspension of such license. For purposes of this section, "license" included any and all licenses issued by any officer, department or agency of the Village of Niles required for retail or other business operations at the location at which the offense occurred, and includes but is not limited to business licenses. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, each sale equals one violation of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 2005-26, § 1, 7-26-05) 
Sec. 66-111. - Possession of drug paraphernalia prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this subsection, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Drug paraphernalia means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are peculiar to and marketed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance. 
(b)  Possession. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to knowingly possess an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingestion, inhaling or otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance in the human body, or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use. 
(c)  Violations; penalties. All persons found in violation of this section shall be liable for penalties as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 1, 2-27-08) 
Secs. 66-112-66-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OBSCENITY 

Sec. 66-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Available to the public means that the matter or performance may be purchased or attended on a subscription basis, on a membership fee arrangement, or for a separate fee for each item or performance. 
    Disseminate means to transfer possession of, with or without consideration. 
    Knowingly means being aware of the character and the content of the material. 
    Material means any book, magazine, newspaper or other printed or written material or any picture, drawing, photograph, motion picture, video, or other pictorial representation or any statue or other figure, or any recording, transcription or mechanical, chemical, or electrical reproduction or any other articles, equipment or machines. 
    Nudity means the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks, any portion of the female breast below the top of the nipple, or the nipple with less than a full opaque covering, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernable turgid state. 
    Obscene means that to the average person applying contemporary community standards: 
(1)  The predominant appeal of the material, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest in that it depicts or describes in a patently offensive way sadomasochistic sexual acts or ultimate sex acts, whether normal or perverted, actual or simulated, or masturbation, excretory functions or lewd exhibition of the genitals; and 
(2)  The material, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
    Performance means any preview, play, show, skit, film, dance or other exhibition performed before an audience. 
    Promote means to cause, permit, procure, counsel or assist. 
    Service to patrons means the provision of services to paying guests in establishments providing food and beverages, including, but not limited to, hostessing, hat checking, cooking, bartending, serving, table setting and clearing, waiter and waitressing, and entertaining. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(b)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 66-122. - Injunction; penalties. 
(a)  The village attorney is authorized to seek an injunction, including temporary and preliminary relief, to restrain and enjoin any violation of this division. 
(b)  Any person who violates this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the penalties described in section 1-11. 
(c)  The violation of this division by any person issued a business license by the village shall constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of such business license. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(h)) 
State Law reference- Obscenity, 720 ILCS 5/11-20. 
Sec. 66-123. - Prohibited conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Knowingly disseminate, distribute or make available to the public any obscene material; 
(2)  Knowingly engage or participate in any obscene or nude performance made available to the public; 
(3)  Knowingly engage in commerce for commercial gain with material depicting and describing explicit sexual conduct, nudity, or excretion utilizing displays, circulars, advertisements and other public sales efforts that promote such commerce primarily on the basis of their prurient appeal; 
(4)  Provide service to patrons in such a manner as to expose to public view: 
a.  His genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anal region or pubic hair region; 
b.  Any device, costume or covering which gives the appearance of or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, perineum, anal region or pubic hair region; 
c.  Any portion of the female breast at or below the areola thereof; or 
(5)  Knowingly promote the commission of any of the unlawful acts described in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(c)) 
Sec. 66-124. - Notice of obscene material or action. 
    A person who promotes any obscene activity as prohibited in section 66-125 in the course of his business is presumed to do so with knowledge of its content and character. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(d)) 
Sec. 66-125. - Exposing minors to harmful materials. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Distribute means to transfer possession of, whether with or without consideration. 
    Exhibit means to show or display, offer or present for inspection a product in public so that it may be taken into possession or viewed by persons under 17 years of age. 
    Harmful to minors means that quality of any description or representation, in whatever form, of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement or sadomasochistic abuse when it: 
(1)  Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of minors. 
(2)  Is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material for minors. 
(3)  Is lacking serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
    Knowingly means having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inspection or inquiry of both: 
(1)  The character and content of any material described in this section which is reasonably susceptible of examination; and 
(2)  The age of the minor; provided, however, that an honest mistake shall constitute an excuse from liability hereunder if the defendant made a reasonable bona fide attempt to ascertain the true age of such minor. 
    Minor means any person under the age of 17 years. 
    Sadomasochistic abuse means flagellation or torture by or upon a person clad in undergarments, a mask or bizarre costume, or the condition of being fettered, bound or otherwise physically restrained on the part of one so clothed. 
    Sexual conduct means acts of masturbation, homosexuality, sexual intercourse, or physical contact with a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks or, if such person is a female, her breast. 
    Sexual excitement means the condition of human male or female genitals when in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
(b)  Unlawful to sell, loan, or distribute obscene material to a minor. It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, loan with or without monetary consideration, distribute or exhibit, to a minor: 
(1)  Any picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, motion picture film, or similar visual representation or image of a person or portion of the human body which depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse and which is harmful to minors; or 
(2)  Any book, pamphlet, magazine, printed matter, however reproduced, movie, video, or sound recording which contains any matter enumerated in subsection (b)(1) of this section, or explicit and detailed verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sexual excitement, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse and which, taken as a whole, is harmful to minors. 
(c)  Unlawful to admit a minor to obscene motion picture or show. It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to exhibit for a monetary consideration to a minor or knowingly to sell to a minor an admission ticket or pass or knowingly to admit a minor for a monetary consideration to premises whereon there is exhibited a motion picture, show or other presentation which, in whole or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse and which is harmful to minors. 
(d)  Circulation of educational material and parental guidance allowed. Circulation of educational material and parental guidance is permitted as follows: 
(1)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit any public library or any library operated by an accredited institution of higher education from circulating harmful material to any person under 17 years of age, provided such circulation is in aid of a legitimate scientific or educational purpose, and it shall be an affirmative defense in any prosecution for a violation of this section that the act charged was committed in aid of legitimate scientific or educational purposes. 
(2)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit any parent or legal guardian from distributing to his child any harmful material or permitting the child to listen to or watch radio or television broadcasts of harmful material. It shall be an affirmative defense in any prosecution for a violation of this section that the parent or legal guardian has consented to the distribution or broadcast of any harmful material to his child. 
(e)  False identification prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person under 17 years of age to state falsely, either orally or in writing, that he is not under the age of 17 years, or to present or offer to any person any evidence of age and identify which is false or not actually his own for the purpose of ordering, obtaining, viewing or otherwise procuring or attempting to procure or view any harmful material. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(e)) 
Sec. 66-126. - Violations. 
(a)  Each day a violation of this division occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Each piece of obscene material or material harmful to minors, and each obscene or nude performance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(f)) 
Sec. 66-127. - Evidence; defenses. 
(a)  Expert affirmative evidence that the materials or activities are obscene is not required when the materials or activities themselves, or copies or recordings of them, are presented as evidence. 
(b)  The creation, purchase, procurement or possession of a mold, engraved plate or other embodiment of obscenity specially adapted for reproducing multiple copies, or the possession of more than three copies of obscene material shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to disseminate. 
(c)  It shall be an affirmative defense in any prosecution under this article that allegedly obscene material was disseminated, or presented for a bona fide scientific, medical, educational, governmental, or judicial purpose by a physician, psychologist, teacher, clergyman, prosecutor, or judge, or such similar professional persons acting in the course of their duties. 
(Code 1965, § 22-20(g)) 
Secs. 66-128-66-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AFFECTING GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS 

Sec. 66-151. - False fire and police alarms. 
    Whoever, without reasonable cause, by outcry or otherwise, or through the use of the village fire and police emergency reporting system, makes or circulates or causes to be made or circulated any false alarm of fire or false alarm for police shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-12) 
State Law reference- False alarms declared disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1(a)(2), 1(a)(4). 
Sec. 66-152. - Impersonating village officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person falsely to represent himself as being an officer or employee of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 22-18) 
State Law reference- False personation of public officer or public employee, 720 ILCS 5/32-5. 
Sec. 66-153. - Obedience to officer. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer, fire department official or any other authorized officer of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 22-23) 
Sec. 66-154. - Damaging streetlights or electrical, telephone, cable television or telegraph equipment. 
    Any person who shall carelessly or maliciously break, deface, disturb, interfere with, carry away, or in any way injure or destroy any electric lamp, globe or any part of, or appurtenance to, any lamp or light of any kind, used in or upon or about any street, alley or public place in the village, or who shall carelessly or maliciously break, injure, destroy or in any way disturb or interfere with any electric light, telephone or telegraph wire, cable television, or any appurtenance thereto, at any place within the limits of the village, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-6) 
Sec. 66-155. - Damaging village property. 
    No person shall damage, injure, mark, or deface any village building, vehicle, sewer, water pipe, hydrant, or other village property, or any tree, grass, shrub or walk in any public way or public park. 
(Code 1965, § 22-7) 
Sec. 66-156. - Depositing articles on streets; sidewalks; property. 
    No person shall throw, cast, or put into, drop or leave in or on any street, alley or sidewalk, public place, or on another's private property without owner's consent, or on any enclosed public grounds in the village, any refuse, stone, nails, missiles, ice, glass, iron, or any other metal, or any other article or thing. 
(Code 1965, § 22-8) 
Secs. 66-157-66-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MINORS 

Sec. 66-176. - Curfew. 
(a)  Established. It shall be unlawful for any child as defined in subsection (b) of this section to be upon any public way or public place in the village between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Friday and 6:00 a.m. Saturday, or between the hours of 11:30 p.m. Saturday and 6:00 a.m. Sunday, or between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any other day of the week, unless accompanied by and in the charge of a parent, guardian, or other proper companion approved by the parent or guardian, of the age of 21 years or more, or unless engaged in some occupation or business in which such child may lawfully engage under the statutes of the state. 
(b)  Child defined. For the purpose of this section only, a child is defined as any person, male or female, who has not reached his 18th birthday. 
(c)  Parents' responsibility. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having custody or control of any child to suffer or permit or by inefficient control to allow such child to violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Notification of parents after child taken under police custody. Any police officer of the village finding a child or children violating the provisions of subsection (a) of this section may retain custody of such child or children and may require the parent or guardian of such child or children to report to the police department of the village in order that custody of such child or children may be delivered to such parent or guardian. It will be the duty of a police officer taking a child or children into custody under the provisions of this section, to notify the parent or guardian as promptly as possible of such fact and request the parent or guardian to report to the police department as quickly as possible for the purpose of receiving custody of such child or children. 
(e)  Penalties for violation. Penalties for violation of this section are as follows: 
(1)  Any parent, guardian or other adult person having custody or control of any child violating the provisions of this section shall be penalized $15.00 for the first offense. 
(2)  Any parent, guardian or other adult person having custody or control of any child violating the provisions of this section a second time within one year of the date of the first violation shall be penalized $25.00. 
(3)  Any parent, guardian or person in charge of a child or children violating the provisions of this section a third time within one year of the date of the first violation shall be required to appear in court on a day certain named in the citation issued for violation of this section and, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $100.00 for each offense. 
(4)  Any parent, guardian or other adult person having custody or control of any child, who received notice that such child is in custody of the police department who shall wilfully fail and refuse to report to the police department for the purpose of receiving custody of such child shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $10.00 nor more than $100.00 for each offense. 
(5)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the village from instituting any other appropriate action or proceeding to punish any person who violates this section. 
(Code 1965, § 22-5) 
State Law reference- Authority to enact curfew, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-5.1. 
Sec. 66-177. - Parental responsibility. 
(a)  Liability of parent. The parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the wilful or malicious acts of such minor which cause injury to a person or property. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Legal guardian means a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of the state, but does not include a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the state juvenile court act of 1987 (705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.), as amended. 
(2)  Minor means a person above the age of 11 years but not yet 19 years of age. 
(c)  Recovery of damage costs; limit. Recovery of damages under this article shall include actual damages occasioned by such minor, which damages shall be payable to the person or entity entitled to such damages; court costs and/or administrative filing fees and attorneys costs and fees incurred in enforcement of this article, and any attorneys costs and fees, court costs or administrative fees, if any, incurred by the village in the prosecution of such minor for a violation of any ordinance, law or statute prohibiting wilful and malicious acts causing injury to a person or property, if such minor is convicted of violating such a law. In no event shall the amount recoverable under this section exceed the sum of $2,000.00. 
(d)  Judgments; applicability of other laws. Section 12-107 of the code of civil procedure (735 ILCS 5/12-107), as amended, is not applicable to judgments obtained under this article. 
(e)  Common law damages. Nothing in this article shall affect the recovery of damages in any other cause of action where the liability of the parent or legal guardian is predicated on a common law basis. 
(f)  [Child unattended in motor vehicle.] No parent or legal guardian of a child under 10 years of age shall leave that child unattended in any motor vehicle. 
(Code 1965, §§ 221/4-1-221/4-5; Ord. No. 1994-50, § 1(221/4-3), 8-23-94; Ord. No. 2008-12, § 1, 2-27-08) 
State Law reference- Parental responsibility law, 740 ILCS 115/1 et seq. 
Sec. 66-178. - Truancy prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 who is enrolled in any public, private, or parochial elementary or secondary school to be present in any public place, building, street, or assembly, other than school, during any hours when school is in session during the regular school term, unless he is: 
(1)  Traveling to and from school by the most direct route. 
(2)  Engaged in school-related activities with written approval of school authorities, or as otherwise authorized by written school policy. 
(3)  Engaged in personal business, including but not limited to, employment, medical care, and religious activities, with prior written notice from a parent or legal guardian to school authorities. 
(b)  A person violating this section shall, if practical, be taken to school authorities or a parent or legal guardian, and may be issued a notice to appear in the circuit court. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a parent, legal guardian, or other person having custody or control of any person subject to this section to knowingly permit such person to violate this section. 
(Ord. No. 1994-52, § 1(22.5), 8-23-94)) 
Secs. 66-179-66-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - GRAFFITI 

Sec. 66-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Graffiti means any and every name, identification description, announcement, declaration, demonstration, display, illustration or insignia, any symbol (including any letter, word, numeral, emblem or combination thereof), other than advertising which is otherwise provided for by village ordinances, which without authorization is marked, written, drawn, painted, scratched, inscribed or affixed directly to or upon any object or structure. 
    Legal guardian means a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act of 1987 (705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.), as amended. 
    Minor means a person who has attained 11 years of age but who has not yet reached 18 years of age. 
    Parent means the lawful mother or father of an unemancipated minor, whether by birth or adoption. 
(Code 1965, § 22-65) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 66-202. - Placement prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place graffiti upon any public or private curbstone, flagstone, or any portion or any part of any sidewalk or street or upon any tree, lamppost, utility pole, postal mail receptacle, sign, hydrant, gate, fence, door, wall, window, garage, enclosure, vehicle, bridge, or any other public or private structure, building, or property. 
(Code 1965, § 22-66) 
Sec. 66-203. - Removal. 
(a)  Upon written notification by a Village representative or written notification by the Village via U.S. mail (certified, return receipt requested), the owner of property upon which graffiti has been illegally placed shall remove the graffiti within two working days from the date of the notice. Such property owner or other owners of property upon the exterior of which graffiti has been placed may obtain a primer paint that is neutral in color for the removal of graffiti from the Village Public Works Department. Primer paint will be supplied in original containers with manufacturer's instructions for use and warnings intact. 
(b)  The Village shall remove graffiti from the exterior of private property if owners inform the Village of their inability to remove it. Owners must sign a statement authorizing removal by the Village and must sign a release holding the Village harmless from the actions taken by the Village or its employees to remove the graffiti within the time specified. The Village will not undertake to provide for the painting or repair of anymore extensive an area than that where the graffiti is located. The property owner will be responsible for the costs to the Village associated with the removal or covering of the graffiti. 
(c)  An extension of the time in which graffiti must be removed may be granted by the Village upon application of the property owner to the police department and a showing of cause. Cause shall include, but not be limited to, weather, temperature, availability of primer paint, or physical limitations. 
(Code 1965, § 22-67; Ord. No. 2007-39, § 2, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 7-25-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 66-204. - Penalties for violation; lien. 
(a)  A person convicted of violating section 66-202 shall be obligated to pay such restitution or reparation as a court may require in the amount of the actual loss or damage to property or pecuniary loss but not to exceed $1,000.00. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude such additional civil remedies as are available to a complaining party for any sum not recovered under this section. 
(b)  In addition or in lieu of such restitution or reparation, as provided in subsection (a) of this section, a fine may be imposed of not to exceed $1,000.00 for each such offense. The fine may be imposed upon the parent or legal guardian. 
(c)  A person found violating section 66-203, please refer to Appendix E for all related penalties. Additionally, the Village shall require that the person found violating section 66-203 make full and complete restitution to the Village for expenses incurred in the removal of the graffiti. If the property owner does not pay such bills within 45 days from the date of mailing to the owner, then the cost of removal shall become a lien upon the property serviced, the lien to be perfected according to the provisions of this Code, and as otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 22-68; Ord. No. 2007-39, § 2, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 2017-44, § 1, 7-25-17) 
Secs. 66-205-66-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - WEAPONS AND FIREARMS 

Sec. 66-226. - Possession; dealing in certain weapons prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry, possess, sell, loan, or give to any person any blackjack, slingshot, metal knuckles, billy or bludgeon, or with intent to use the same unlawfully against another a dagger, dirk, dangerous or switchblade knife, razor, stiletto or any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument of like character. 
(Code 1965, § 22-40) 
Sec. 66-227. - Carrying dangerous weapons. 
    No person shall carry on or about his person a pistol, revolver or other firearm, or bow and arrow. This section does not apply, however, to the following officers while engaged in the discharge of their official duties: sheriffs, coroners, constables, policemen or other duly constituted peace officers and wardens, superintendents and keepers of prisons, penitentiaries, jails and other institutions for the detention of persons accused or convicted of crime. This section shall also not apply to the following employees or agents while actually engaged in the performance of their duties at a fixed place of employment: watchmen, special agents, and policemen employed by railroads or express companies; nor shall this section apply to persons lawfully summoned by an officer to assist in making an arrest or preserving the peace while so engaged in assisting such officer. No person under the age of 18 years shall carry or possess a knife, the blade of which shall be longer than three inches. 
(Code 1965, § 22-41) 
Sec. 66-228. - Discharging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any gun, pistol or other firearm, or any air gun, air rifle, air pistol, BB rifle, BB pistol, gas gun, spring-operated gun, toy pistol, toy rifle, peashooter or other gun or object from which projectiles are propelled, or to shoot a bow and arrow within the corporate limits of the village unless within a licensed shooting gallery. 
(Code 1965, § 22-42) 
State Law reference- Deadly weapons, 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq. 
Sec. 66-229. - Dealers to keep register. 
    All persons dealing in firearms within the village shall keep a register of all such firearms sold or given away by them. Such register shall contain the date of the sale or gift; the name, address, age and occupation of the person to whom the firearm is sold or given; the price of the firearm; the kind, description and number of the firearm; and the purpose for which it is purchased or obtained. The register shall be in the following form: 
(1)  Date of purchase or gift; 
(2)  Name, address and age of purchaser or donee; 
(3)  Occupation of purchaser or donee; 
(4)  Kind, description and number of firearm; 
(5)  Purpose for which firearm was purchased or obtained; and 
(6)  Price of firearm. 
(Code 1965, § 22-43) 
Sec. 66-230. - Affidavit to purchase firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person dealing in firearms to sell, barter, loan, or give away to any person within the village any pistol, revolver, or other firearm of like character which can be concealed upon the person, unless such person so purchasing or receiving such firearm shall have filed with the dealer an affidavit affirming the requirements stated in this section, and it shall be the duty of the person dealing in firearms to receive and keep such affidavit in a permanent file for inspection purposes. Every such person dealing in firearms shall, on demand, allow any police officer, sheriff or deputy sheriff to enter and inspect all stock on hand and shall, on request of such officer, produce for inspection all affidavits of purchasers and the register so required to be kept. 
(b)  The following persons are covered by this and not eligible to purchase a firearm: 
(1)  Any person convicted of a felony; and any person having been convicted of any misdemeanor contained in chapter 38, article 12 of the criminal code of 1961 (720 ILCS 5/12-1 et seq.), as amended; 
(2)  Any minor under the age of 18 years; 
(3)  An addict as defined by section 1-103 of the state alcoholism and other drug dependency act (20 ILCS 305/1-103), as amended; 
(4)  Any person convicted of the unlawful use or possession of a weapon; 
(5)  Any person who has been a patient in a mental treatment facility within the past five years or has been acquitted of a criminal offense by reason of insanity. 
(c)  The affidavit required by subsection (a) of this section must be on file with the dealer for not less than seven days before the sale is consummated and possession transferred. 
(Code 1965, § 22-44) 
Sec. 66-231. - Selling; furnishing firearms to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, loan or furnish to any minor under the age of 18 years any gun, pistol, rifle, revolver or other firearm within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 22-45) 
Sec. 66-232. - Selling; furnishing other weapons to minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, loan or furnish to any minor under the age of 18 or for any such minor to possess within the corporate limits of the village any air gun, air rifle, air pistol, BB rifle, BB pistol, gas gun, toy pistol, toy rifle, peashooter or other gun or object from which a projectile is propelled; any knife, the blade of which is longer than three inches; or any bow and arrows. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, exhibit for sale, give, loan, rent or possess within the village any gun or firearm of every kind and description which fires pellets containing paint, dye, powder or any other substance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, exhibit for sale, give, loan, rent or possess within the village pellets containing paint, dye or any other substance, which pellets are designed, or readily adapted, to be fired from a gun or firearm. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, exhibit for sale, give, loan, rent or possess within the village any replica or facsimile of a gun or firearm. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any replica or facsimile firearm which, because of its distinct color, size or other design feature, cannot reasonably be perceived as a real firearm. The expression "replica or facsimile of a firearm" shall mean any device or subject made of plastic, wood, metal, or any other material which is a replica, facsimile, or toy version of, or is otherwise recognizable as, a pistol, revolver, shotgun, sawed-off shotgun, rifle, machine gun, rocket launcher, or any other firearm. As used in this section, the expression "replica or facsimile of a firearm" shall include, but is not limited to, toy guns, movie props, hobby models (either in kit form or fully assembled), starter pistols, air guns, inoperative firearms, or any other device which might reasonably be perceived to be a real firearm. 
(e)  Parents or legal guardians of minors who damage or deface property by the use of guns or firearms, as described in this section, shall be liable for damages. 
(Code 1965, § 22-46) 
State Law reference- Parental responsibility law, 740 ILCS 115/1 et seq. 
Sec. 66-233. - Switchblades prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give, loan, or furnish any knife, commonly referred to as a switchblade knife, which has a blade that opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle of the knife. 
(Code 1965, § 22-47) 
Sec. 66-234. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antique handgun means any firearm, including, but not limited to, any firearm with a matchlock, flintlock, percussion cap or similar type of ignition system, which is incapable of being fired or discharged; or any firearm manufactured before 1898 for which cartridge ammunition is not commercially available and is possessed as a curiosity or ornament or for its historical significance or value. 
    Assault weapon means: 
(1)  Any semiautomatic action, centerfire rifle or carbine that accepts a detachable magazine with a capacity of 20 rounds or more. 
(2)  Any semiautomatic shotgun with a magazine capacity of more than six rounds. 
(3)  Any semiautomatic handgun that is: 
a.  A modification of a rifle described in this definition or a modification of an automatic firearm; or 
b.  Originally designed to accept a detachable magazine with a capacity of more than 20 rounds. 
(4)  Any firearm which may be restored to an operable assault weapon. 
(5)  Any part or combination of parts designed or intended to convert a firearm into an assault weapon which may be readily assembled if those parts are in the possession or under the control of the same person. 
(6)  The term "assault weapon" does not include any of the following: 
a.  Any firearm that uses .22 caliber rimfire ammunition with a detachable magazine with a capacity of 18 rounds or less. 
b.  Any assault weapon which has been modified to either render it permanently inoperable or to permanently make it a device no longer defined as an assault weapon. 
    Automatic or semiautomatic firearm means any firearm designed or specially adapted to fire a succession of cartridges with a single function of the trigger. 
    Firearm means any deadly weapon capable of expelling or propelling one or more projectiles by the action of an explosive or combustible propellant. The word firearm includes an unloaded firearm and any firearm which is inoperable but which can readily be rendered operable. 
    Handgun means a firearm designed to be held and fired by the use of a single hand, and includes a combination of parts from which such firearm can be assembled. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, company, association, firm, partnership, club or society, including wholesale and retail gun dealers. 
    Rifle means a weapon designed or redesigned, made or remade and intended to be fired from the shoulder or designed or redesigned and made or remade to use the energy of the explosive in a fixed metallic cartridge to fire only a single projectile through a rifled bore for each single pull of the trigger. 
    Sale means the transfer of possession within the village for consideration. 
    Shotgun means a firearm, whether or not it is intended to be fired from the shoulder, that is designed or redesigned, made or remade to fire a fixed shotgun shell. 
(Code 1965, § 22-48(a); Ord. No. 1994-12, § 1, 2-22-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 66-235. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person shall sell, offer or display for sale, give, lease, lend or transfer ownership of any assault weapon. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to federal, state and local law enforcement officials while engaged in the operation of their official duties. 
(c)  The sale of handguns, except antique handguns, is prohibited. However, this prohibition shall not apply to sales to law enforcement officers on active duty, security personnel licensed by the state to carry firearms, and members of any other federal bureau or agency who are authorized to carry firearms. 
(Code 1965, § 22-48(b); Ord. No. 1994-12, § 2, 2-22-94) 
Sec. 66-236. - Seizure and destruction. 
    Any assault weapon offered for sale in violation of this division is hereby declared to be contraband and shall be seized and disposed of as authorized by law. 
(Code 1965, § 22-48(c)) 
Sec. 66-237. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor. 
(b)  Each calendar day that any violation of this section is repeated or continued shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 22-48(d)) 
Chapter 70 - SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-52, § 1, adopted September 27, 2016, amended Ch. 70 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 70, §§ 70-1, 70-2, 70-46-70-51, 70-61-70-63, 70-76-70-83, pertained to peddlers and solicitors, and derived from Code 1965, § 23-1-23-11, 23-13-23-17, 23-19; Ord. No. 1993-43, § 1, 9-28-93; Ord. No. 1994-56, § 1, 9-27-94; Ord. No. 2002-38, § 2, 7-23-02; Ord. No. 2010-38, § 1, 5-25-10. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22.
