    Whenever upon engineering investigation, the width of a roadway is found to be insufficient to meet the requirements set forth in section 98-149, the Director of Public Works is hereby authorized to erect signs giving notice of prohibition of parking. 
(Code 1965, § 21-314; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 98-60. - Illegal cancellation of violation notice. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic violation notice or complaint in any manner other than as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 21-315) 
Sec. 98-61. - Private parking and moving violation enforcement. 
    The following private areas will have parking regulations and moving violations enforced by the Village of Niles: 
(1)  8900 through 9070 Heathwood Circle. 
(Ord. No. 2010-70, § 1, 11-23-10) 
Secs. 98-62-98-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE LICENSES 

Sec. 98-81. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall take, destroy, remove or obliterate any license, tag, plate or emblem provided for in this article, without the consent of the owner of the vehicle, shall be punished as provided by section 1-11. Every such wrongful destruction, obliteration or removal of such license, tag, plate or emblem from any vehicle shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 21-27) 
Sec. 98-82. - Required; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or park, or cause or permit any of his agents or employees to use or park any motor vehicle upon the public ways of the village when such person is a resident of the village and/or the situs or base of the vehicle is located within the village unless such vehicle is licensed as provided in this article. 
(b)  Situs or base of vehicle is the place where a motor vehicle is principally garaged, or from where it is principally dispatched, or where the movements of each vehicle usually originate. 
(c)  Any person violating this article shall be fined not less than $50.00. 
(Code 1965, § 21-16; Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, 6-27-00) 
Sec. 98-83. - Application; expiration and renewals. 
(a)  An application for a license for any motor vehicle subject to this article shall be made upon the form provided by the village therefor, which form shall state the name and address of the applicant, a description of the vehicle for which the license is sought, and other required information. Application shall be made not more than 30 days after acquiring legal title to such motor vehicle or after establishing the situs of the vehicle within the village. Upon payment by the applicant of the license fee as provided, which payment must accompany the application, the applicant shall be issued a sticker license emblem authorizing the use of such motor vehicle within the village until the expiration of such license, which emblem must be affixed in the lower right corner of the windshield of the vehicle for which it is purchased. 
(b)  The vehicle license issued for all vehicles shall expire on June 30 of each calendar year. Applications for renewal of licenses shall be made upon preprinted applications provided by the village. New sticker emblems may be displayed on June 1 of each calendar year. 
(Code 1965, § 21-17) 
State Law reference- Motor vehicle license tax authorized, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-4, 625 ILCS 5/2-121. 
Sec. 98-84. - Fees. 
    The following vehicles are subject to annual license fees: 
(1)  Passenger car, including ambulances and hearses. 
(2)  Bus. 
(3)  Taxi. 
(4)  Motorcycle, motor bicycle, scooters, etc. 
(5)  Dealer, original. 
Dealer, each additional. 
(6)  Recreational vehicle, R.V. 
(7)  Trucks: 
Gross Weight in Pounds, 
Including Vehicle and 
Load Class Trucks 
"B" Under 8,000 pounds. 
"D" 8,001 to 12,000. 
"F" 12,001 to 16,000. 
"H" 16,001 to 26,000. 
"J" 26,001 to 28,000. 
"K" 28,001 to 32,000. 
"L" 32,001 to 36,000. 
"N" 36,001 to 40,000. 
"P" 40,001 to 45,000. 
"Q" 45,001 to 50,000. 
"R" 50,001 to 54,999. 
"S" 55,000 to 59,500. 
"T" 59,501 to 64,000. 
"V" 64,001 to 73,280. 
"X" 73,281 to 77,000. 
"Z" 77,001 to 80,000. 
Tow trucks. 
(8)  Passenger car owned by a resident who is 62 years of age or older upon presentation of the applicant's current Illinois driver's license verifying applicant's age, (limit of one senior citizen vehicle license per licensed driver). 
(9)  Vehicles subject to section 98-12, prohibition of motorized vehicle storage. 
(Code 1965, § 21-18; Ord. No. 1994-30, § 1, 5-24-94; Ord. No. 1994-61, § 1, 10-25-94; Ord. No. 2003-15, § 2, 4-22-03; Ord. No. 2008-32, § 1, 6-25-08; Ord. No. 2008-36, § 1, 7-24-08; Ord. No. 2010-30, § 1, 4-27-10) 
Sec. 98-85. - Proration of fees. 
    If a motor vehicle other than a truck has been purchased or lawfully acquired by the owner or applicant on or after January 1 of any current year, or the owner has established residence within the village limits on or after January 1 of any current year, the license fee to be paid shall be one-half of the annual license fee. Before any applicant shall be entitled to a half-fee license, the applicant shall furnish satisfactory evidence that either of the prerequisites described in this section has been satisfied; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the license purchased by an applicant who has qualified as a senior citizen, as provided in section 98-84. 
(Code 1965, § 21-19) 
Sec. 98-86. - Waiver of fees. 
(a)  One annual vehicle license fee imposed by section 98-84 shall be waived for the following classes of persons per valid driver's license: 
(1)  Residents of the Village who are entitled to and display a disabled veteran's license plate. Registration and valid driver's license must be presented at the time of purchase to receive the discount. 
(2)  Residents of the Village who are entitled to and display a valid charitable vehicle license CV issued by the Illinois Secretary of State. 
(3)  Permanent, disabled person license plate or permanent, disabled person placard issued by the Illinois Secretary of State. Registration and valid driver's license must be presented at the time of purchase to receive the discount. 
(4)  Only one waiver of vehicle license fee or discount of vehicle license fee will be permitted per valid driver's license. No additional discounts or waivers of the vehicle license fee will be permitted for additional cars owned by 1 person. 
(b)  Persons in the classes described in subsection (a) of this section shall make application for an annual vehicle license in the manner provided by this article. The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to issue license stickers at no charge to those classes of residents described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The transfer fee provided in section 98-90 shall be waived for all persons in the classes described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 21-20; Ord. No. 2015-49, § 1, 7-28-15) 
Sec. 98-87. - License emblem required. 
(a)  The Village Clerk shall deliver to the holder of any license for an automobile, motor truck, motor ambulance or hearse, motor coach or motor bus, a sticker license emblem which shall bear the words "Village of Niles" and the numerals designating the year for which such license is issued, and such other information as may be prescribed thereon. The color of the sticker license emblem shall be designated by the Village Clerk. 
(b)  Such sticker emblem shall be affixed in accordance with the provisions provided thereon, which are made a part hereof, and without the use of supplemental adhesives, at the lower righthand corner of the glass windshield of such motor vehicle, approximately one inch from the righthand lower sections of the frame of such windshield. 
(Code 1965, § 21-23) 
Sec. 98-88. - Sale of licensed vehicle. 
(a)  Immediately upon the sale of any vehicle licensed under this article when such sale is made prior to the date of expiration of such license, the vendor shall remove the license sticker emblem from the vehicle so sold. 
(b)  Except where a vehicle license shall be regularly transferred as provided, it shall be the duty of the purchaser of any used automobile, or other vehicle, to remove and deliver to the vendor or the vendor's agent, immediately, any license, tag, transparent sticker or any other license emblem which may be attached to such vehicle at the time of the purchase thereof, which the vendor of such vehicle may have refused, failed or omitted to detach from such vehicle as required. It shall be unlawful for any such purchaser to use, sell or offer for sale such used automobile or other vehicle without first having removed all such license, tags, plates, transparent stickers, or other license emblems. 
(Code 1965, § 21-24) 
Sec. 98-89. - Placing emblem on wrong vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to affix or cause to be affixed any license, tag, plate, transparent sticker or other license emblem to any automobile or other vehicle other than the vehicle to which such license, tag, plate, transparent sticker or other license was intended to be affixed at the time of the issuance thereof by the Village Clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 21-25) 
Sec. 98-90. - Transferring license from one vehicle to another. 
(a)  Whenever the owner of any vehicle licensed under this article, before the expiration of such license, sells or otherwise disposes of such vehicle, and thereafter acquires another vehicle and desires to transfer the vehicle license originally issued for the vehicle disposed of, to such newly acquired vehicle, such owner shall immediately make application to the Village Clerk for a transfer of the vehicle license to the newly purchased vehicle. The application shall state the name and address of the licensee and the name and address of the purchaser of the vehicle, together with a description of the newly purchased vehicle. Upon surrender of the original license and sticker, the Village Clerk shall transfer the license to apply to the newly acquired vehicle upon payment of the proper license fee. 
(b)  The transfer fee shall be $2.00. If the newly acquired vehicle is of a class requiring the payment of a license fee higher than was paid for the license originally obtained for the vehicle disposed of, the fee required to be paid for such transfer shall be a sum equal to the difference between the fee paid for the original license and the fee fixed for licenses for vehicles of such class, plus the transfer fee of $2.00. 
(Code 1965, § 21-26) 
Secs. 98-91-98-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- When traffic signs required, 625 ILCS 5/11-207, 5/11-208(b); traffic signs, signals and markings, 625 ILCS 5/11-301 et seq.; sign manual, 625 ILCS 5/11-301. 

Sec. 98-111. - General speed restrictions. 
(a)  No vehicle may be driven upon any street, alley or highway at a speed which is greater than is reasonable and proper with regard to traffic conditions and the use of the street, alley or highway, or endangers the safety of any person or property. The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the applicable maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway, or when special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions. Speed must be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle on or entering the street, alley or highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(b)  No person may drive a vehicle upon any street, alley or highway at a speed which is greater than the applicable statutory maximum speed limit established by a regulation or ordinance made under this chapter. 
(c)  Unless some other speed restriction is established under this chapter, the maximum speed limit for all vehicles is: 
(1)  Twenty-five miles per hour; and 
(2)  Fifteen miles per hour in an alley. 
(Code 1965, § 21-37) 
Sec. 98-112. - Alteration of speed restrictions. 
    The president and the board of trustees may alter any speed restriction in section 98-111 to a higher or lower restriction, in which event signs shall be posted upon such street, alley or highway indicating the speed restriction. 
(Code 1965, § 21-38) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate speed limits, 625 ILCS 5/11-604. 
Sec. 98-113. - Restrictions during certain periods. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in violation of markings, signs, barriers or other devices placed to designate streets, parts of streets or specific lanes thereon upon which vehicular traffic shall proceed in one direction during one period and the opposite direction during another period of the day. 
(Code 1965, § 21-40) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate one-way streets, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(4), 5/11-708; obedience to signs, 625 ILCS 5/11-708. 
Sec. 98-114. - Play street barricades and signs. 
    During the hours that any play street is in use for purposes of recreation, the roadway thereof shall be closed to vehicular traffic by ropes or other removable barriers, and, at each end of such section, there shall be placed a standard or sign on which shall be printed in letters plainly legible for a distance of 100 feet a notice designating such street as a play street. Such signs shall be kept in place until the close of the period of recreation each day that it is so used and shall then be removed, together with the barriers. 
(Code 1965, § 21-39) 
Sec. 98-115. - Driving on play streets. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then, any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 21-60) 
Sec. 98-116. - Vehicles obstructing traffic. 
    The operator of a vehicle shall not operate or allow the vehicle to remain upon any street in such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. 
(Code 1965, § 21-61) 
Sec. 98-117. - Towing or pushing vehicles regulated. 
(a)  When one vehicle is towing another, the drawbar or other connection shall be of sufficient strength to pull all weight towed thereby, and the drawbar or other connection shall not exceed eight feet. 
(b)  When one vehicle is towing another, and the connection consists of a chain, rope, or cable, there shall be displayed upon such connection a yellow flag or cloth not less than 16 inches square. 
(c)  No person shall push a vehicle with another vehicle upon any public way for a distance greater than 600 feet. 
(d)  Every disabled vehicle being pushed or towed on any public way between the hour of sunset and the hour of sunrise shall display a red light plainly visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the sides and rear thereof. Such red light shall be in addition to any other lights required by any law or ordinance. 
(e)  No person shall drive any vehicle pushing or towing a disabled vehicle at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard to the traffic and the use of the way or so as to endanger life or limb or injure the property of any person. 
(Code 1965, § 21-62) 
Sec. 98-118. - Trailers and towed vehicles. 
    No trailer shall be operated on any trafficways while attached to a self-propelled motor vehicle or to a leading trailer or semitrailer, unless, in addition to the regular coupling device, it shall have suitable and adequate safety chains or devices attached to the corners of the trailer frame of sufficient strength to pull the trailer and its maximum load, provided that any trailer having a gross weight of 3,000 pounds or less including the weight of the trailer and maximum load may be coupled to the towing vehicle by means of clamp-on hitches, which hitches shall be designed and installed to effectively transfer stresses to the chassis of the towing vehicle. Such clamps and coupling bar shall be of sufficient strength to hold and control such trailer when fully loaded. Such trailers shall be equipped with two safety chains or cables which are permanently affixed to the tongue of the trailer. When such trailer is attached to the towing vehicle, the free end of each chain or cable shall be attached to the towing vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 21-220) 
Sec. 98-119. - Driving under the influence of a controlled substance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or to be in actual physical control of any vehicle within the village if such person's blood or urine contains evidence of the unauthorized use of cannabis, as defined by the state cannabis control act (720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.), as amended, or of the unauthorized use of a controlled substance, as defined by the state controlled substances act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 21-63) 
Sec. 98-120. - Privileges of authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, subject to the conditions stated in this section. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the speed limits. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The exemptions granted in this section to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of any vehicle, while in motion, sounds an audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying an oscillating, rotating or flashing red beam visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle, nor need the driver of a police vehicle, while in motion, sound an audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle if such vehicle is displaying an oscillating, rotating or flashing red beam described in this subsection. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Code 1965, § 21-80) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-205. 
Sec. 98-121. - Duties of drivers in funeral processions. 
    Each driver in a funeral procession shall drive as near to the righthand edge of the roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Code 1965, § 21-81) 
State Law reference- Rules of the road for funeral processions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1420. 
Sec. 98-122. - Soliciting fares by public passenger vehicles. 
    No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall solicit business in such manner as to interfere with the lawful movement of traffic. 
(Code 1965, § 21-83) 
Sec. 98-123. - Riding on motorcycles; motor-driven cycles; motor scooters. 
(a)  A person operating a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto, and such operator shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride upon such cycles unless such cycles are designed to carry more than one person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for two persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the rear or side of the operator. 
(b)  No person other than the driver thereof shall ride upon a motor scooter. 
(Code 1965, § 21-84) 
State Law reference- Riding on motorcycles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1403. 
Sec. 98-124. - Regulations applicable to pushcarts; animals. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1965, § 21-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-206. 
Sec. 98-125. - Coasters; roller skates; toy vehicles. 
    No person upon roller skates, skateboards, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and, when so crossing, such person shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street set aside as a play street, as authorized by ordinance of this village. 
(Code 1965, § 21-86) 
Sec. 98-126. - Driver and passenger required to use safety seat belts. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases when used in this section shall, for the purposes of this section have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in Chapter 625 ILCS, Section 5 et seq.: "driver," "motor vehicle," "passenger car," "motorcycle," or "roadway." 
(b)  Violations; exceptions; penalties; applicability. 
(1)  Each driver and front seat passenger of a motor vehicle operated on a roadway in this village shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened seat belt; except that a child less than six years of age shall be protected as required pursuant to the Illinois Child Passenger Protection Act (625 ILCS 25/1 et seq.). Each driver of a motor vehicle transporting a child six years of age or more, but less than 16 years of age, in a motor vehicle shall secure the child in a properly adjusted and fastened safety seat belt. 
(2)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any of the following: 
a.  A driver or passenger frequently stopping and leaving the vehicle for roadway maintenance or roadway construction, if the speed of the vehicle between stops does not exceed 15 miles per hour. 
b.  A driver or passenger possessing a written statement from a physician that such person is unable, for medical or physical reasons, to wear a safety seat belt. 
c.  A driver or passenger possessing an official certificate or license endorsement issued by the appropriate agency in another state or country indicating that the driver or passenger is unable for medical, physical, or other valid reasons, to wear a safety seat belt. 
d.  A driver operating a motor vehicle in reverse. 
e.  A motor vehicle with a model year prior to 1965. 
f.  A motorcycle. 
g.  A motor vehicle which is not required to be equipped with safety seat belts under federal law. 
(3)  Violation under any provision of this section is hereby declared to be a petty offense, and any operator or passenger of a passenger motor vehicle convicted of a violation hereunder shall be fined up to $40.00. 
(4)  Failure to wear a safety seat belt in violation of this section shall not be considered evidence of negligence, shall not limit the liability of an insurer, and shall not diminish any recovery for damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance, or operation of a motor vehicle. 
(5)  Any Village Police Officer may stop any motor vehicle, solely on the basis of a violation or suspected violation of this section while such motor vehicle is being operated on any roadway within this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1999-4, § 1, 1-26-99) 
Sec. 98-127. - Operations of motor driven scooters restricted. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Motor driven scooter defined. For the purpose of this section, a "motor driven scooter" is defined as any electric or gas driven wheeled scooter, motor-driven cycle or other similar motor-driven vehicle for which the State of Illinois does not issue a title document, and does not issue license plates or registration documents. 
(b)  Operation of motor driven scooters restricted. No person shall operate a motor driven scooter upon any public street, sidewalk, parking lot, bike path, park or on any other public property. 
(c)  Exemptions. The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained in this section: 
(1)  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, special district vehicle, county vehicle or Forest Preserve District vehicle operated by an employee in the course of his or her duties. 
(2)  Motorized wheelchairs. For purposes of this section, a motorized wheelchair means any motorized vehicle designed for and used by a person with disabilities. 
(3)  Electric personal assistive mobility devices, as defined in section 5/1-117.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.). 
(d)  Violations. Any person 18 years of age or older who violates any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be subject to a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense. An offense committed by a minor under the direct control or with the consent of a parent or guardian may subject the parent or guardian to the penalties provided in this section. 
(e)  Effective date. This section shall be in full force and effect 180 days after its approval by the board of trustees. Between the date of its approval by the board of trustees and its effective date, the Village of Niles shall disseminate information about this section to the public. 
(Ord. No. 2004-36, § 1, 8-24-04) 
Secs. 98-128-98-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STANDING, STOPPING AND PARKING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301 et seq.; authority to regulate standing or parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(1); liability for parking violations, 625 ILCS 5/11-1305, 5/11-1306. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-146. - Parallel parking; double parking. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within 12 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. Double parking is prohibited. 
(Code 1965, § 21-150) 
Sec. 98-147. - Diagonal parking. 
(a)  The parking of vehicles diagonal to the roadway may be permitted only on the streets at their termini beyond the last cross street intersection and on streets which serve only as service drives, as have been or shall hereafter be designated diagonal parking zones and spaces by placing and maintaining suitable signs and markings. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to park a vehicle diagonally to the edge of the roadway except where such diagonal parking is permitted by signs and markings. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to park a vehicle in any diagonal parking zone except diagonally to the edge of the roadway and within the pavement markings. 
(Code 1965, § 21-151) 
Sec. 98-148. - Abandoned motor vehicles or equipment on private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon any motor vehicle or motored equipment on any private property within the village, or to place for sale signs upon such vehicle or equipment, except where the property is zoned for sale of new or used vehicles or equipment. A motor vehicle or motored equipment is presumed to be abandoned when it is in such a state of disrepair as to be incapable of being driven in its present condition, or which has not been removed or used for more than 30 consecutive days and is apparently deserted. 
(b)  If the motor vehicle or motored equipment is not moved within seven days of such notice, the village shall institute procedures in accordance with the provisions of section 98-236. 
(Code 1965, § 15-44; Ord. No. 2008-07, § 1, 1-24-08) 
Sec. 98-149. - Obstructing traffic prohibited. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than 15 feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic on a two-way street or less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic on a one-way street. 
(Code 1965, § 21-152) 
Sec. 98-150. - Obedience to signs regulating parking. 
    When signs have been erected upon any street indicating that stopping, standing or parking is prohibited during designated hours or prohibited for a longer time than is designated, no person shall park any vehicle on the street in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1965, § 21-153) 
Sec. 98-151. - Parking regulations to facilitate street cleaning. 
    For the purpose of facilitating the cleaning of streets, the Director of Public Works is authorized to erect temporary signs designating the days of the week and hours of the day and the part of street in which the parking of vehicles is prohibited during the periods and at the location designated on the signs, as provided in section 98-150. 
(Code 1965, § 21-154; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 98-152. - Application of parking regulations. 
    The provisions of any ordinance prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles shall apply at all times or at those times therein specified or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic, in compliance with the directions of a Police Officer, or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1965, § 21-155) 
Sec. 98-153. - Vehicle registrant presumed responsible for parking violations. 
    Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any provisions prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to the penalty therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 21-251) 
Sec. 98-154. - Notice on illegally parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking, and there is no person in attendance upon such parked vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a traffic violation notice to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation, any Police Officer, observing such violation, may attach to the vehicle used in such violation a traffic violation notice requiring that the person in whose name such vehicle is registered appear in court on a day certain named in such notice and answer to the charge of such violation. 
(b)  When any vehicle is parked in a private parking lot in violation of section 98-159 and there is no person in attendance upon such parked vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a traffic violation notice to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation, any Police Officer upon a written complaint signed by the owner or proprietor of the lot, or by his authorized agent, that the vehicle is not entitled to the privileges of the parking lot may attach to the vehicle a traffic violation notice as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the vehicle to which the notice is attached, to remove the notice from the vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 21-252) 
Sec. 98-155. - Parking time limits not exclusive. 
    The provisions of any ordinance imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1965, § 21-156) 
Sec. 98-156. - Parking for more than three days. 
    No motor vehicle may remain parked in the same spot on any public street or public alley for more than 72 hours unless special permission is received from the Chief of the Police Department or his designee. 
(Code 1965, § 21-157) 
Sec. 98-157. - Prohibited in specified places. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with directions of a Police Officer or official traffic sign or signal: 
(1)  Within an intersection; 
(2)  On a crosswalk; 
(3)  Upon any bridge, or viaduct, or in any subway and the approaches thereto; 
(4)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone; 
(5)  Within 30 feet of an official traffic signal or stop sign on the approaching side; 
(6)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(7)  At any curb within 15 feet of a fire hydrant, such distance to be measured from that point on the curb perpendicular to the exact location of the fire hydrant; 
(8)  At any place within 20 feet of the entrance to any fire station, and on the side of any street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of the entrance; 
(9)  At any place where the standing of any vehicle will block the use of any driveway; 
(10)  Within any sidewalk area; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  At any place where official traffic signs have been erected prohibiting stopping, standing, or parking; 
(14)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
(15)  Within any designated bus zone, where such zone is marked by signs or pavement markings; 
(16)  In an alley within 20 feet of the inner sidewalk line projected across such alley; 
(17)  Under the lowest portion of any fire escape; 
(18)  Upon a railroad track or between any railroad track and a line parallel with and ten feet distant from the outer rail thereof; 
(19)  Upon any parkway except in case of emergency; 
(20)  Within 20 feet of any alley entrance or exit; 
(21)  In such a manner as to obstruct fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors, windows, roadways, driveways, fire lanes, private hydrants or fire department connections, or in such a manner so as to impede or interfere with fire department operations or egress of occupants in case of fire pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-209; and 
(22)  In any area of a public parking lot posted, "No Parking Except Handicapped Persons," "Reserved Parking," or bearing the international symbol indicating a handicapped parking restriction, unless such person is handicapped or is transporting a handicapped person and unless the motor vehicle displays an identification card in its windshield (which identification card declares the possessor thereof to be a handicapped person and which card has been issued by any of the townships of the state) or a motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to section 3-616 or to a disabled veteran pursuant to section 3-609 of the state vehicle code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.), as amended. 
(23)  There shall be no parking, standing or stopping on the east and west side of Central Avenue, from Howard Street south to Touhy Avenue. 
(24)  There shall be no parking anytime on the east side of Lincoln Avenue between Normal Avenue and Bruce Drive. 
(25)  There shall be no parking from 2:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. on the south side of Greenleaf Street between 7821 and 7831, including 7809 and 7813 Greenleaf Street. 
(26)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle to permit a motor vehicle to be parked along the west side of Washington Street from the southern edge of Courte Drive to a point 72 feet south as described in Attachment A which is incorporated by reference and made a part of this subsection. 
(27)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle owned by a nonresident to be parked along both sides of Franks Avenue between Harts Road to Cherry Avenue, as described in Exhibit A which is incorporated by reference and made a part of this subsection. 
(28)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle to permit a motor vehicle not displaying a Village of Niles vehicle sticker or Niles Visitor Parking Permit to be parked in the Neighborhood of Bunker Hill northeast of Milwaukee Avenue including the streets of Ebinger Drive, Forest View Lane, Riverview Avenue and Rosemary Lane. 
(Code 1965, § 21-170; Ord. No. 1998-44, § 1, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 1, 7-25-00; Ord. No. 2001-39, § 1, 7-24-01; Ord. No. 2001-45, § 1, 9-25-01; Ord. No. 2008-24, § 1, 5-21-08; Ord. No. 2011-03, § 1, 1-25-11; Ord. No. 2012-57, § 1, 9-25-12; Ord. No. 2016-67, § 1, 12-13-16) 
Sec. 98-158. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any trafficway: 
(1)  To display such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  To grease or repair such vehicle except for repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(3)  To sell merchandise from such vehicle except in a duly established market place. 
(Code 1965, § 21-273) 
Sec. 98-159. - Parking in private parking lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not entitled to do so to park a vehicle in a private parking lot which has been established voluntarily or pursuant to the village zoning ordinance to provide for off-street parking facilities for owners, tenants, invitees or employees of the owner or tenants of the lot. The owner of the lot shall post a sign advising that parking is restricted; the size, shape, lettering and location of the sign shall be approved by the Village Clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 21-277) 
Sec. 98-160. - Regulated in alleys. 
(a)  No parking in alleys at any time. No person shall stop or stand any vehicle in any alley for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of such vehicle. 
(1)  No person shall stop, or stand, a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the alley for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(2)  No person shall stop, or stand, a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway or entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1965, § 21-171; Ord. No. 2009-33, § 1, 7-29-09) 
Sec. 98-161. - Authority to prohibit parking adjacent to schools; playgrounds. 
(a)  The Director of Public Works is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property or playground when such parking interferes with traffic or creates a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any school property or playground, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1965, § 21-172; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 98-162. - Authority to prohibit parking on village property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle upon any property owned by the village and used for the transaction of public business where such parking is prohibited by order of the custodian of the property. This section shall not apply to village owned vehicles or to other vehicles whose operation is useful or essential to the proper functioning of the department, board or commission occupying the property. The custodian of the property shall post no parking signs indicating the foregoing prohibition contained in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 21-173) 
Sec. 98-163. - Truck parking restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to stand or park any truck, truck-trailer, tractor-trailer, or truck-tractor on any public way within an area zoned in a residential district having a gross weight when fully loaded, in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds and/or bearing a classification of "D" or higher under the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, except for the purpose of loading or unloading the same, and then only during such time as is reasonably necessary for such activity, and as provided in Sec. 98-165. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to stand or park any truck, truck-trailer, tractor-trailer or truck-tractor within an area zoned as a commercial or industrial district, having a gross weight when fully loaded, in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds and/or bearing a classification of "D" or higher, under the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, except for the purpose of loading or unloading the same, and then only during such time as is reasonably necessary for such activity, and as provided in Sec. 98-165. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to park a detached semi-trailer upon any public way. 
(d)  Any vehicle parked in violation of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance which may be towed by the Village's authorized agent by removing such vehicle to the Village vehicle pound or to any authorized garage. 
(e)  The Director of Public Works is hereby authorized, under this section, to designate, erect and maintain appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 21-190; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 1-24-08; Ord. No. 2018-31, § 1, 6-26-18; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-31, § 1, adopted June 26, 2018, changed the title of § 98-163 from "Truck, limousine and bus parking restricted" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 98-164. - Unlawful moving of vehicles. 
    No person, other than a Police Officer, shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control, into any area where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited or away from a curb or edge of roadway such distance as is unlawful, or start or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change, or move the levers, brake, starting device, gears, or other mechanism, of a parked motor vehicle, to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof, or attempt to do so. 
(Code 1965, § 21-271) 
Sec. 98-165. - Limited parking for loading and unloading on certain streets. 
    It is unlawful to park any vehicle for a period of time longer than three minutes for loading and unloading of passengers or 30 minutes for loading and unloading of property at any place, whether designated as a loading zone or not so designated, on any through street or any street upon which a motor busline is operated, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Code 1965, § 21-191) 
Sec. 98-166. - Stopping; standing; parking of buses and taxicabs. 
(a)  The driver of a bus shall not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place other than at a designated bus stand or bus terminal. 
(b)  The driver of a bus shall not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers other than at a designated bus stop, bus stand, passenger loading zone, or bus terminal except in case of an emergency. 
(c)  The driver of a bus shall enter a bus zone or passenger loading zone on a public street in such a manner that the bus when stopped to load or unload passengers shall be in a position with the right front wheel of such bus not further than 18 inches from the curb and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of other vehicular traffic. 
(d)  The driver of any taxicab shall not stop, stand, or park such vehicle upon any public business or public residential street except: 
(1)  Taxicab stands. 
(2)  For the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(3)  When necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic. 
(4)  In compliance with the directions of a Police Officer or traffic sign or signal. 
(Code 1965, § 21-82; Ord. No. 2009-34, § 1, 7-29-09; Ord. No. 2009-54, § 1, 10-28-09; Ord. No. 2010-33, § 1, 4-27-10; Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 1-26-16) 
Secs. 98-167-98-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SNOW ROUTES 

Sec. 98-176. - Parking limited during snow removal; snow removal requirements. 
(a)  Exempt streets. The following streets are exempted from all snow regulations: 
(1)  Carol Avenue, 7000 to 7100. 
(2)  Carol Court, 7100 to cul-de-sac. 
(3)  Carol Street, 7400 to deadend. 
(4)  Crain Street, 7000 to 7025. 
(5)  Dempster Street, 8200 to 8400. 
(6)  Elizabeth Street, 8250 to 8300. 
(7)  Grand Street, 8800 to 8900. 
(8)  Greenleaf Avenue, 7000 to 7100. 
(9)  Lyons Street, 8000 to 8066. 
(10)  Milwaukee Avenue, 8400 to 8800. 
(11)  National Avenue, 8554 to Carol Street. 
(12)  Niles Avenue, 7100 to 7200. 
(13)  Oak Street, 8400 to 8500. 
(14)  Root Street, 8800 to 8900. 
(15)  Washington Street, 8800 to 8950. 
(16)  Wisner Street, 8800 to 8950. 
(b)  No parking until after snow plowing. No parking shall be permitted on the following streets after a one-inch snowfall until the streets have been plowed: 
(1)  Church Street, Washington to Courtland. 
(2)  Church Street, Maryland to Greenwood. 
(3)  Cleveland Street, Caldwell to Harlem. 
(4)  Courtland Drive, Davis to Church. 
(5)  Cumberland Avenue, Oakton to Church. 
(6)  Davis Street, Cumberland to Greenwood. 
(7)  Greenleaf Avenue, Harlem to Oriole. 
(8)  Harlem Avenue, Touhy to Dempster. 
(9)  Howard Street, Oriole to Nordica. 
(10)  Huber Lane, Maynard to Wendy Way. 
(11)  Keeney Street, Waukegan to Milwaukee. 
(12)  Main Street, Shermer to Washington. 
(13)  Maryland Avenue, Milwaukee to Lyons. 
(14)  Maynard Road, Greenwood to Huber Lane. 
(15)  Monroe Street, Harlem to Cumberland. 
(16)  Mulford Street, Milwaukee to Oleander. 
(17)  Mulford Street, Milwaukee to Harlem. 
(18)  New England Avenue, Cleveland to Oakton. 
(19)  Nordica Avenue, Fargo to 7740 Nordica. 
(20)  Odell Avenue, Mulford to Oakton. 
(21)  Oketo Avenue, Monroe to Dempster. 
(22)  Oleander Avenue, Mulford to Howard. 
(23)  Oriole Avenue, Monroe to Dempster. 
(24)  Ozanam Avenue, Dempster to Park. 
(25)  Park Avenue, Washington to Ozanam. 
(26)  Waukegan Road, Milwaukee to Main. 
(27)  Wendy Way, Huber Lane to Maynard Road. 
(c)  Even and odd parking. Except as to those streets set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, no parking will be permitted after a three-inch snowfall, on the odd-numbered side of the street for a period of 24 hours after the snowfall has ended, or until the odd-numbered side of the street is plowed. No parking will be permitted on the even-numbered side of the street for the next 24 hours, or until the even-numbered side of the street is plowed. Odd-numbered and even-numbered sides of the street refer to house numbers assigned in accordance with section 86-91 et seq., and following of the village streets and sidewalks chapter in this Code. 
(d)  Obstruction of snow removal; penalty. It shall be unlawful for any person and/or for any agent of any person to: 
(1)  Plow or otherwise remove accumulated snow from a private parking lot and deposit the snow on a village street or right-of-way. 
(2)  Plow snow from a private driveway and deposit the snow on a village street in such a manner so as to decrease the driveable width of any such street. 
(3)  Obstruct, harass, prevent or otherwise interfere with any employee of the village engaged in snow removal service or to obstruct, cause damage to or otherwise interfere with any village owned or leased vehicle used in conjunction with snow removal services. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 and, in addition thereto, shall be responsible and make full payment for any damage to village property. Citations for violations of this section may be issued to the owner of the property involved and also to any industry or firm which acts as an agent for any such owner. 
(e)  Construction of section. Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to permit parking on any street where it is otherwise prohibited. 
(Code 1965, § 21-192) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit parking during snow removal, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(13). 
Secs. 98-177-98-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOADING AND UNLOADING 

Sec. 98-186. - Vehicle in passenger curb loading zone or no parking space. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone or prohibited parking space during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone or prohibited parking space are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(Code 1965, § 21-200) 
Sec. 98-187. - Permits to load or unload at an angle. 
    The Village Clerk, with approval of the Chief of Police, is authorized to issue special permits to allow the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permit may be issued to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant such person the privileges as therein stated and authorized therein, provided that such permit shall be either in the possession of the operator or on the vehicle at the time such vehicle is backed against the curb to take on or discharge a load. It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1965, § 21-201) 
Sec. 98-188. - Vehicle in truck loading zone. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a truck loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(b)  The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a truck loading zone for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1965, § 21-202) 
Sec. 98-189. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus zone, bus stand or bus terminal, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated by appropriate signs, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1965, § 21-203) 
Secs. 98-190-98-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING OF RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND BOATS 

Sec. 98-201. - Definitions. 
    Recreational vehicle. Every camping trailer, motor home, mini motor home, travel trailer, truck camper or van camper used primarily for recreational purposes and not used commercially nor owned by a commercial business. The term "recreational shall also include the following: 
(1)  Travel trailer is a vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational or vacation uses; it shall have a body width not exceeding eight feet and a body length not exceeding 26 feet, excluding trailer hitch, tongue and bumper. 
(2)  Pickup coach: A structure designed primarily to be mounted on a pickup or truck chassis with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational or vacation uses. 
(3)  Camper trailer: A vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis or metal welded unit body with the superstructure made in part or in whole of canvas and metal frame. 
(4)  Motorized home: A portable dwelling designed and constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle. 
    Boat means any device used or capable of being used for navigation on water. 
    Boat trailer shall include every vehicle designed or utilized for the transportation of any boat having a gross weight of less than 5,000 pounds, without motive power, designed for being drawn by another vehicle. 
    Owner means a person other than a lien holder having a property interest in or title to a boat or boat trailer or recreational vehicle. The term includes a person entitled to the use or possession of a boat, trailer or recreational vehicle subject to an interest in another person, reserved or created by agreement and securing payment or performance of an obligation. 
(Code 1965, § 221/2-1; Ord. No. 1995-3, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-95) 
Sec. 98-202. - Residential districts-Application of provisions. 
    A recreational vehicle or boat may not be parked on any public way or public property in any residential district. Parking of a recreational vehicle or boat is permitted on private property in a residential district subject to the following conditions and restrictions. 
(Code 1965, § 221/2-2; Ord. No. 1995-3, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-95) 
Sec. 98-203. - Same-General conditions. 
(a)  Recreational vehicles or boats shall not be permitted in any district as accessory buildings. 
(b)  Recreational vehicles or boats not meeting the conditions and restrictions herein contained shall not be stored in any residential district, except that a trailer may be used as a temporary office or storage space incidental to construction of a building development for the period of time such construction is actively undertaken, provided such trailer is located on the same or contiguous lot as the building development. 
(c)  At no time shall such boat or recreational vehicle be occupied or used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes. 
(d)  No recreational vehicle or boat in excess of the bulk restrictions as indicated in section 98-204 of this division shall be parked in any residential district. 
(e)  State license plates, display title and village vehicle sticker, where required, shall be current and conspicuously displayed. 
(f)  The owner shall have and display upon request to any authorized village official proof of ownership of such recreational vehicle or boat. 
(g)  Such recreational vehicle or boat shall be maintained in mobile condition; no major construction or repair of such recreational vehicle or boat shall be carried out in a residential area, unless within an enclosed garage. The term "major construction" means any construction, rebuilding, enlargement, remodeling, refurbishing or repair, the cost of which exceeds 30 percent of the value of such unit before such construction, rebuilding, enlargement, remodeling, refurbishing or repair. The term "major construction" shall not include painting, usual or customary maintenance or repair. 
(h)  The owner of a boat or recreational vehicle shall not park any such boat or recreational vehicle in such manner as to create a dangerous or unsafe condition on the property where parked. Parking in such fashion that the boat or recreational vehicle, whether loaded or not, may readily tip or roll, shall be considered a dangerous and unsafe condition. 
(Code 1965, § 221/2-3; Ord. No. 1995-3, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-95) 
Sec. 98-204. - Same-Bulk restrictions. 
    No recreational vehicle, boat or boat trailer parked in a residential district shall exceed: 
(1)  Ten feet in height as parked, including trailer, cradle or mount, but excluding mast; 
(2)  Twenty-six feet in body length, excluding trailer hitch, tongue and bumper; 
(3)  Eight feet in body width, excluding hardware; 
(4)  A gross weight of 8,000 pounds. 
(Code 1965, § 221/2-4; Ord. No. 1995-3, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-95) 
Sec. 98-205. - Same-Location restrictions. 
    A recreational vehicle, boat or boat trailer parked in a residential district shall be located: 
(1)  In the rear yard to the extent that the same is possible or practicable, taking into consideration existing landscaping and buildings. 
(2)  Not less than three feet from any lot line. 
(3)  Not within any required front yard, front driveway or building setback line. 
(Code 1965, § 221/2-5; Ord. No. 1995-3, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-95) 
Sec. 98-206. - Same-Variations. 
    Any person desiring to obtain a variation from the restrictions of subsections (2) and (3) of section 98-205 shall make application with the Village Clerk on a form to be provided by such clerk and pay a filing fee of $10.00. Such application for a variation shall be heard by the zoning board at such times and after such notice as the zoning board may require. The zoning board shall have the final responsibility of authorizing a variation upon such terms and conditions as it deems reasonable. 
(Code 1965, § 221/2-6) 
Secs. 98-207-98-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WEIGHT AND SIZE LIMITATIONS 

Sec. 98-211. - Weight and size limitations on certain streets. 
    Whenever official signs are erected prohibiting the use of any street or a part of a street by trucks or other commercial vehicles or imposing weight or size limitations upon such vehicles using the street as authorized in this section, no person shall drive a truck or other commercial vehicle upon any such street or a part of a street in violation of any such signs except for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise, and then only by entering such street at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle and proceeding thereon no farther than the nearest intersection thereafter. The word "load" when used on official signs erected by authority of this section shall be defined and understood to mean the weight transmitted to the road by the wheels of a vehicle, being the weight of such vehicle plus the weight of its contents or load, if any. 
(Code 1965, § 21-210) 
Sec. 98-212. - Permits for excess size and weight. 
(a)  When an emergency exists, the Village Clerk, on the approval of the Chief of Police with respect to streets and trafficways under the jurisdiction of the village, may, in his discretion, upon application in writing and good cause being shown therefor, issue a special permit in writing authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the maximum specified in the laws of the state or otherwise not in conformity with the provisions of this chapter upon any street or trafficway under the jurisdiction of the village. 
(b)  The application for any such permit shall specifically describe the vehicle and load to be operated or moved and the particular streets or highways for which the permit to operate is requested, and whether such permit is requested for a single trip or for continuous operation. 
(c)  The Village Clerk, on the approval of the Chief of Police, is authorized to issue or withhold such permit at his discretion; or, if such permit is issued, to limit the number of trips, or to establish seasonal or other time limitations within which the vehicle described may be operated on the streets or trafficways indicated, or otherwise to limit or prescribe conditions of operation of such vehicles, when necessary to ensure against undue damage to the road foundation, surfaces, or structures, and may require such undertaking or other security as may be deemed necessary to compensate for any injury to any roadway or road structure. 
(d)  Whenever the application for such permit is for the transportation of a single article which cannot be divided and which exceeds 24,000 pounds total load on any axle or exceeds 60 feet total length or 102 inches maximum width, the Village Clerk, with the approval of the Chief of Police, may issue a permit only for a single trip for the load so to be transported, providing that the person making such application shall have paid to the Village Clerk a fee of $10.00 for such permit and shall have furnished a bond in the sum of $25,000.00 to the village, conditioned so as to save the village harmless from any claim, loss or damage that may result from the granting of such permit or that may arise from or on account of any work done thereunder, and further conditioned that the permittee shall restore at his own cost, to a condition satisfactory to the Director of Public Works, any pavement, subway, tunnel, sewer, pipe, conduit, or other public utility that may be injured by reason of the transportation of such article under such permit. 
(e)  Every permit issued under the provisions of this section shall be carried in the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by any Police Officer, and no person shall violate any of the terms or conditions of such special permit. 
(Code 1965, § 21-211; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 98-213. - Weighing of trucks by Police Department; fee. 
    The Police Department may weigh trucks upon request to determine if trucks are within applicable weight limits. A fee of $50.00 per vehicle will be charged. 
(Code 1965, § 21-212) 
Secs. 98-214-98-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - IMPOUNDING AND REMOVAL OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 98-236. - Authorization to tow vehicles. 
    The towing of motor vehicles by the village, or a contractor hired by it for such purpose, shall be authorized only by the Village Police Department and only under the circumstances provided in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 21-230) 
Sec. 98-237. - Towing without prior notice. 
    Motor vehicles may be towed without prior notice to the registered owner where, in the opinion of a Village Police Officer at the scene and the concurrence of a superior officer: 
(1)  The motor vehicle creates a traffic, health or safety hazard on public property; 
(2)  The motor vehicle is in violation of a posted snow route regulation; 
(3)  The person legally entitled to possession of the motor vehicle is, although present at the scene, physically or mentally incapable of deciding upon steps to be taken to deal with his property; 
(4)  The motor vehicle has been reported stolen; 
(5)  The motor vehicle has been used in the commission of a crime and its retention is necessary as evidence; 
(6)  The motor vehicle is considered a derelict wherein it is on public property and its major components have been removed or damaged to such extent as to make the vehicle incapable of being driven or useless to repair, and the vehicle bears no registration or a registration that has not been current for more than three months. 
Notice of a car having been towed shall be given as described in section 98-238. 
(Code 1965, § 21-231) 
Sec. 98-238. - Towing with prior notice. 
    Motor vehicles may be towed after notice to the registered owner and the affording of an opportunity for a hearing in the manner described in section 98-240 under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Where the motor vehicle has been abandoned. A motor vehicle parked in a public place or on private property in view of the general public and has not been moved for at least seven days shall be deemed to have been abandoned. 
(2)  A motor vehicle that has been unlawfully parked in excess of 24 hours. 
(Code 1965, § 21-232) 
Sec. 98-239. - Notification of registered owner. 
    Notice shall be forwarded by certified mail to the address of the owner of the motor vehicle as indicated in the most current available state registration information. The notice shall specify that the vehicle has been towed or placed on the list to be towed, as the case may be; that the owner is entitled to recovery of the vehicle and/or a hearing, as the case may be; the charges, if any, to date; and the procedure to be followed by the owner in requesting a hearing, if so desired. In the case of towing without prior notice, as authorized by section 98-237, notice shall be sent as soon as practicable, but in no event later than two business days after the vehicle has been towed. 
(Code 1965, § 21-233) 
Sec. 98-240. - Pre-tow hearing. 
    The owner or person entitled to possession of the motor vehicle shall have seven days after the date of mailing of the notice to request a hearing. This request is to be made in writing to the Chief of Police, or his designee, at the village police building during normal business hours. A hearing date will then be scheduled at the convenience of the requesting party and the Police Department. Towing of the vehicle shall be delayed pending the outcome of this hearing though in no case will the village be required to delay towing more than seven days after a request for a hearing is received. If no such request for hearing is received within the seven-day period, the motor vehicle may be disposed of in accordance with this article and applicable law. 
(Code 1965, § 21-234) 
Sec. 98-241. - Post-tow hearing. 
    The owner or person entitled to possession of the motor vehicle towed without notice, as provided by section 98-237, may request a hearing relative to the propriety of the tow. Such request shall be made in writing to the Chief of Police, or his designee, at the village police building during normal business hours, within 14 days of the mailing date of notification or release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first. A hearing date will then be scheduled at the convenience of the requesting party and the Police Department. 
(Code 1965, § 21-235) 
Sec. 98-242. - Recovery of towed vehicles. 
    The owner or person entitled to possession of the motor vehicle may recover the vehicle through the following three options: 
(1)  He may pay the towing and storage fees due and redeem the vehicle; 
(2)  He may request a hearing relative to the propriety of the tow be conducted prior to redeeming the vehicle; 
(3)  He may request a hearing relative to the propriety of the tow and redeem the vehicle by making a deposit in the amount of the towing and storage fees claimed due. 
Requests for hearings are to be made in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 21-236) 
Sec. 98-243. - Hearings. 
    When requested by the owner or other person legally entitled to possession of the motor vehicle, a hearing shall be conducted by the Village Manager, or his designee, regardless of whether such request is pre-tow or post-tow. The hearing shall be conducted at the village administration building and shall be scheduled during normal business hours either within the business week during which the request for hearing was made or the business week immediately following the request. The Village Manager or his designee may grant a continuance of the hearing date. However, no continuance shall exceed 30 days. 
(Code 1965, § 21-237) 
Sec. 98-244. - Disposal of unclaimed motor vehicles. 
    Disposal of unclaimed motor vehicles shall be done in accordance with the provisions of 625 ILCS 5/11 et seq., or as may hereafter be provided. 
(Code 1965, § 21-238) 
Sec. 98-245. - Towing with consent. 
    The provisions set forth in this article shall not apply in those circumstances in which a motor vehicle is towed upon the request of, or with the consent of the owner or other person legally entitled to possession of the motor vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 21-239) 
Sec. 98-246. - Fees. 
    The fees for towing and storage as authorized by this article shall read as follows: 
(1)  Towing, per vehicle, $85.00. 
(2)  Storage per day, $22.00. 
(Code 1965, § 21-240; Ord. No. 2001-17, § 2, 3-27-01; Ord. No. 2003-29, § 2, 5-27-03) 
Sec. 98-247. - Vehicle immobilization and towing program. 
(a)  The village establishes a vehicle immobilization and towing program for the purpose of facilitating enforcement of the village's vehicular standing, parking, and compliance ordinances. 
(b)  The vehicle immobilization and towing program means the immobilizing of any eligible vehicle upon the public way either by presence of a restraint in a manner to prevent operation of the vehicle or by towing the vehicle to a storage facility. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, an eligible vehicle shall be any vehicle, when the registered owner of the vehicle has accumulated more than five unpaid final determinations of parking, standing, or compliance violation liability and/or more than $1,000.00 dollars owed to the Village of Niles as determined by ordinance of the Village of Niles. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any individual, person or private business to use or employ the vehicle immobilization device to immobilize any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2000-68, §§ 1, 2, 11-28-00; Ord. No. 2009-38, § 1, 8-26-09; Ord. No. 2009-48, § 1, 9-23-09; Ord. No. 2011-38, § 1, 6-28-11) 
Secs. 98-248-98-265. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MASS TRANSIT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 98-266-98-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NILES MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Local mass transit district act, 70 ILCS 3610/1 et seq. 

Sec. 98-276. - Local mass transit district created; purpose; boundaries. 
    A local mass transit district is hereby created by the village for the purpose of acquiring, constructing, owning, operating and maintaining mass transit facilities for public service or subsidizing the operation thereof. The boundaries of the local mass transit district shall be coterminus with the boundaries of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-1) 
Sec. 98-277. - Name of district. 
    Such district shall be known as the Niles Mass Transit District. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-2) 
Sec. 98-278. - Board of trustees-To exercise powers of district; appointment; terms of trustees. 
    The powers of the Niles Mass Transit District shall repose in and be exercised by a board of three trustees who shall be appointed by the President and Board of Trustees of the village. Trustees appointed to the board shall serve for terms of one year. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-3) 
Sec. 98-279. - Same-Qualifications; certification of appointment; compensation and expenses; organization of board; prohibited interests; removal of trustee; personnel. 
(a)  No trustee of the Niles Mass Transit District may be an officer or employee of the village. 
(b)  A trustee shall hold office until his successor has been appointed and has qualified. A certificate of the appointment or reappointment of any trustee shall be filed with the Village Clerk, and such certificate shall be conclusive evidence of the due and proper appointment of such trustee. 
(c)  A trustee shall receive, as compensation for his services, not more than $24.00 for each day devoted to the business of the board and not more than $100.00 a month. He shall also be entitled to the necessary expenses, including traveling expenses, incurred in the discharge of his duties. 
(d)  The powers of the board shall be vested in the trustees thereof in office from time to time. A majority shall constitute a quorum of the board for the purpose of conducting its business and exercising its powers and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the board upon a vote of the majority of the trustees present, unless in any case the bylaws of the board shall require a larger number. The board shall select a chairman and a vice-chairman from among the trustees. 
(e)  No trustee or employee of the Niles Mass Transit Board shall acquire or have any interest direct or indirect in any contract or proposed contract for materials or services to be furnished or used in connection with the operations of the district. 
(f)  For inefficiency or neglect of duty or misconduct in office, a trustee may be removed by the person and body which made the original appointment, but a trustee shall be removed only after he shall have been given a copy of the charges against him at least ten days prior to the hearing thereon and has had an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel. In the event of the removal of any trustee, a record of the proceedings, together with the charges and findings thereon, shall be filed in the office of the Village Clerk. 
(g)  The board shall employ a managing director of the district and may employ a secretary, treasurer, technical experts and such other officers, agents and employees, permanent and temporary, as it may require, and shall fix and determine their qualifications, duties and compensation and the amount of bond to be furnished for such offices and positions. For such legal services as it may require, the board may call upon the chief law officer of the village or may employ and fix the compensation of its own counsel and legal staff. The board may delegate one or more of its agents or employees such powers and duties as it may deem proper. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-4) 
Sec. 98-280. - Same-General powers. 
(a)  The board of trustees of the Niles Mass Transit District may engage in the business of transportation of passengers on scheduled routes and by contract on nonscheduled routes within the village, by whatever means it may decide. Its routes may be extended beyond such territorial limits with the consent of the governing bodies of the municipalities or counties into which such operation is extended. 
(b)  The board of trustees may, for the purposes of the district, acquire by gift, purchase, lease, devise, condemnation, or otherwise, and hold, use, improve, maintain, operate, own, manage or lease as lessor or lessee, such cars, buses, equipment, lands for terminals and other facilities, or any interest therein, including all or any part of the plant, equipment, vehicles, licenses, franchises, patents, property, contracts and agreements of every kind and nature. Real property may be so acquired if it is situated within or partially within the area served by the district or if it is outside the area provided it is necessary for the purposes of the district. 
(c)  The board of trustees may contract with any person or corporation for the operation of transportation facilities or systems established or acquired upon such terms and conditions as the district shall determine. 
(d)  The board of trustees shall have the authority to contract for the purposes of the district with another local mass transit district or any other municipal or private corporation in the transportation business, to lease its equipment for the carriage of passengers beyond the territorial limits of the district, or to subsidize transit operations by a private municipal corporation operating mass transit facilities. 
(e)  The board of trustees shall have the authority to establish, alter and discontinue transportation routes and to establish and amend rate schedules for the transportation of persons thereon which shall, together with any grants, receipts or income from other sources, be sufficient to pay the expenses of the district, the repair, maintenance and the safe and adequate operation of its facilities and transportation system and to fulfill the terms of its debts and obligations. 
(f)  The board of trustees shall have perpetual succession. 
(g)  The board of trustees shall have the authority to apply for, accept and use grants, loans or other financial assistance from any municipal, county, state or federal governmental agency. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-5) 
Sec. 98-281. - Liability. 
    Neither the village, the village president or the members of the village board of trustees or village officers or employees shall be held liable for failure to provide a security or police force or, if a security or police force is provided, for failure to provide adequate police protection or security, failure to prevent the commission of crimes upon passengers by fellow passengers or third persons or for the failure to apprehend criminals. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-5.1) 
Sec. 98-282. - Applicability of state law. 
    The board of trustees of the Niles Mass Transit District shall have all of the powers and be subject to all of the duties and limitations set forth in that portion of the state local mass transit district act (70 ILCS 3610/1 et seq.), as amended, and all of the provisions thereof which are applicable to this division and are not enumerated in this division are hereby incorporated into this division by reference. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-6) 
Secs. 98-283-98-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NORTH SUBURBAN MASS TRANSIT DISTRICT 

Sec. 98-296. - Creation. 
    The village hereby participates in the creation of the North Suburban Mass Transit District. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-7) 
Sec. 98-297. - Appointment to board of trustees. 
    A qualified person who is a resident of the village shall be appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, to serve as a member of the board of trustees of the North Suburban Mass Transit District. The person so appointed shall attend meetings of the board and report the business and affairs of the board to the president. The appointee shall serve without compensation and at the pleasure of the president. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-8) 
Sec. 98-298. - Recording. 
    A certified copy of this division, together with a certified copy of each ordinance adopted by each participating municipality creating the district, and the names of the persons as appointed trustees by each of the participating municipalities creating the district, and the names of the persons as appointed trustees by each of the participating municipalities shall be filed by the clerks of the several participating municipalities with the county clerk for recording as certificates of incorporation. 
(Code 1965, § 191/4-9) 
Secs. 98-299-98-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PARADES 

Sec. 98-321. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade means any march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the village. 
    Parade permit means a permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 21-270(b)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-4. 
Sec. 98-322. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the Chief of Police or other appropriate official or body. 
(b)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1965, § 21-270(c)) 
Sec. 98-323. - Application. 
(a)  Filing. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the Chief of Police. 
(b)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the Chief of Police not less than ten days nor more than 30 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(c)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information:
