No blocking of any kind shall be used to adjust the pipe to grade except when used with embedment concrete. Bedding shall be required for all sewer construction, except ductile iron pipe, and shall be of a minimum thickness equal to one-fourth of the outside diameter of the sewer pipe but shall not be less than four inches. 
(Code 1965, § 26-29) 
Sec. 102-67. - Cleanout access. 
    All sanitary sewer systems in residential structures shall have a six-inch full cleanout on the exterior of the buildings. 
Sec. 102-68. - Use of old building sewers. 
(a)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings or with major remodeling only when they are found, on examination and test by the village, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(b)  It shall be the obligation of the owner, builder or developer to provide the village with documentation that demonstrates the old sewer can meet the requirements of this article. 
(c)  It shall be at the sole option of the village, that based on the information presented, to require the owner, developer or builder to either replace or reline the sanitary sewer for the building up to and including the point of connection with the sanitary sewer main. 
(Ord. 2009-47, § 1, 9-23-09) 
Secs. 102-69-102-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SEWER SERVICE CHARGES 

Sec. 102-81. - Amount. 
(a)  The sewer service charge is for the service, operation and maintenance of the Villages' waste and storm water collection system. 
(b)  Sewer service charge unit costs. The unit costs for the sewer service charge are referenced in Appendix D Fee Schedule of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 26-50; Ord. NO. 2014-25, § 1, 4-22-14) 
Sec. 102-82. - Billing practice. 
(a)  Sewer service charge billing period. Sewer service charges shall be billed by the Village on the same bill as the water usage bill. 
(b)  Payment of sewer service charges. Those persons billed by the Village for the sewer service charges shall pay such charges within 20 days after the billing date. 
(Code 1965, § 26-51; Ord. No. 2014-25, § 1, 4-22-14) 
Sec. 102-83. - Right of entry; safety; identification. 
(a)  Right of entry. The approving authority or other duly authorized employees of the municipality, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, or testing, all in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Safety. While performing the necessary work on private premises referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the duly authorized municipal employees shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the owner or the occupant. 
(c)  Identification; right to enter easements. The approving authority or duly authorized employees of the municipality, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the municipality holds and easement for the purpose of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement, all subject to the terms, if any, of such easement. 
(Code 1965, § 26-52) 
Secs. 102-84, 102-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 102-86. - Applicability. 
    A stormwater management plan (plan) is required for all developments that propose over 7,500 square feet of new or redeveloped impervious area or that will disturb over 15,000 square feet in aggregate. Developments that are below these thresholds are still subject to all other applicable village ordinances, including the grading ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-87. - Plan requirements. 
    The plan requires the review and approval of the village. The plan must provide sufficient information to convey the intent of the design for construction. As a minimum, the plan must include the following information: 
(1)  Detailed site plans showing the following information: 
a.  Roadways, parkway lots, driveways, sidewalks and other impervious surfaces. 
b.  Pervious area including but not limited to grass and dirt. 
c.  Building structures and fences. 
d.  On-site or adjacent ponds, wetlands channels or floodplains. 
e.  Existing and proposed onsite grade elevations. 
f.  Property line elevations. 
g.  Proposed top-of-curb, pavement, and overflow elevations. 
h.  Rim and invert elevations for all sewer structures. 
i.  Sewer sizes, lengths and minimum slopes. 
j.  Size, and approximate location of village sewer. 
k.  Connection tie-in elevation to the village sewer. 
l  Proposed detention facilities if applicable. 
m.  Highwater elevations and limits of ponding. 
n.  Grading and direction of surface flow. 
(2)  A narrative describing the proposed stormwater management features, their operation and necessary maintenance requirements. 
(3)  Supporting calculations including the Niles Stormwater Management Spreadsheet, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-88. - As-built plans. 
    Prior to the final site inspection, as-built drawings shall be submitted for review and approval by the village. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-89. - Site inspection. 
    Village personnel or its authorized agent will have the right to inspect the portions of the development subject to the plan without prior notice during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-90. - Stormwater runoff management. 
    All developments subject to stormwater management requirements must be designed to manage the 100-year storm event and to provide means to manage and safely direct overflows to the public right-of-way. A minimum of 0.2 feet of freeboard from the high-water level within any detention facility to the overflow to the right-of-way must be provided. An additional 0.2 feet (minimum) freeboard must be provided from the lowest overflow elevation leading to an adjacent property. No more than 400 square feet of impervious surface area can sheet flow to the public right-of-way without detention. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-91. - Control of stormwater discharge rate. 
    Proposed developments that disturb 15,000 square feet or more and is 15 percent impervious or greater must control the rate of stormwater discharge from the property. Rate control will be accomplished by providing stormwater detention with a restrictor device to achieve the target release rate. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-92. - MWRD. 
    If the MWRD requires detention for any proposed development, the MWRD requirements shall govern the design of the detention facilities. All other requirements of the Stormwater Management Ordinance must still be met. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-93. - Release rate: Developments greater than 72,600 square feet. 
    The standard release rate in the 100-year critical duration storm for developments greater than 72,600 square feet is 0.15 cfs per acre. Higher release rates may be allowed as per section 102-95. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-94. - Release rate: Developments less than 72,600 square feet. 
    Developments less than 72,600 square feet in size cannot practicably achieve a release rate of 0.15 cfs per acre without using an approved non-clogging restrictor device. Release rates for developments of 15,000 square feet to 72,600 square feet in size may be determined below as follows: 
(a)  For sites between 15,000 square feet and 21,780 square feet (one-half acre), the maximum allowable release rate is 0.15 cfs, which must be achieved using an approved restrictor device. The required storage is based on 0.15 cfs. 
(b)  For sites between 21,780 square feet (one-half acre) and 43,560 square feet (one acre), the maximum regulated release rate is a linear interpolation between 0.15 cfs and 0.25 cfs, respectively. The required storage is based on the linear interpolation of the two release rates. In this case, an approved restrictor device with a release rate of 0.25 cfs will be installed for sites greater than 32,670 square feet. 
(c)  For sites between 43,560 square feet up to 76,200 square feet (1.67 acres), the maximum allowable release rate is 0.25 cfs, which must be achieved using an approved restrictor device. The required storage is based on 0.25 cfs. 
The above requirements are illustrated in the following chart. 

(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-95. - Niles outlet capacity release rates. 
    Based on engineering studies, the village may determine if certain sewersheds (the area tributary to a sewer outfall) have capacities that exceed the standard release rate of 0.15 cfs per acre. If such conditions are found, the allowable release rates will be published with a map of the corresponding sewersheds. Developments draining to those sewersheds may then use the higher published release rate (if applicable) for calculating the required detention volume and restrictor size. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-96. - Storage volume. 
    The amount of required 100-year storage must be based on the modified rational method. The Village of Niles Detention Calculator Spreadsheet which uses the modified rational method and is available from the Village Engineer. 
(a)  The average rainfall intensity used in the design formula shall be based on 100-year rainfall frequencies set forth in Bulletin 70 "Frequency Distributions and Hydroclimatic Characteristics of Heavy Rainstorms in Illinois" prepared by the Illinois State Water Survey, 1989. 
(b)  The C-values to be used in the calculation shall be based on the following: 
Asphalt Roof, Pavement = 0.95 
Gravel = 0.70 
Vegetated areas = 0.30 
Dry bottom detention basins to HWL = 0.75 
Water = 1.00 
The spreadsheet tool uses the modified rational method to compute the required detention volume in the critical duration 100-year storm. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-97. - Allowable detention facilities. 
    Methods of acceptable detention are dry, wet or wetland bottom detention basins, underground detention vaults, underground oversized pipes, and parking lot detention. Parking Lot detention must not exceed a maximum depth of six inches. Calculations substantiating the proposed detention volume at the high water level (HWL) must be provided. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-98. - Restrictors. 
    Restrictors must be sized in accordance with the maximum release rate and high water level. When using the standard release rate, an approved non-clogging controlled release rate restrictor must be used as shown in chart "Figure 1 Release Rate for Properties less than 1.67 acres." When other control structures are used, the discharge shall be calculated using the orifice equation with the correct discharge coefficient (Cd) as follows: 
Cd= 0.61 for sharp-edged plate bolted to a catch basin. 
Cd = 0.82 for pipes less than 2-feet long grouted into sewer. 
The hydraulic head on a restrictor must be computed from the high water elevation to the invert of a half-trap with restrictor. Conventional restrictors shall be controlled either a single pipe outlet or orifice plate and shall be a minimum three-inch diameter. Pipe restrictors shall consist of a minimum two-foot long pipe. If a three-inch restrictor is insufficient for providing the required rate control, a non-clogging orifice design down to a minimum two and one-half-inch diameter may be submitted for review. In all cases, a custom device (such as a vortex valve) that provides the required rate control may be proposed, subject to review. 
Restrictors must be placed in a structure that allows for direct access for cleanout and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-99. - Plan amendments. 
    Any modification that will affect the performance or the rate or volume of stormwater leaving the property shall be considered an amendment to the plan and shall be reflected in the as-built drawings. Examples of plan modifications that require an amendment and approval prior to construction include but are not limited to: 
(a)  Changes in grading that affect available storage volume or drainage patterns. 
(b)  Changes in size or location of connections to the village sewer. 
(c)  Structural changes to detention facilities that impact storage volume. 
(d)  Changes in material or quantity of sewers. 
Examples of plan modifications that do not require an amendment include: 
(a)  Vertical and horizontal alignment adjustments to sewer and sewer structures that will not affect hydraulic performance and that comply with design standards as listed herein. 
(b)  Changes in onsite sewer bends, fittings and connections. 
(c)  Utility conflict resolutions, as approved in writing by a village inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-100. - Safety. 
    The stormwater management system components shall be designed to protect the safety of any person coming in contact with the system. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 102-101. - Maintenance. 
    Maintenance of stormwater management facilities located on private property shall be the responsibility of the owner of that property. 
(Ord. No. 2011-18, § 1, 3-22-11) 
Secs. 102-102-102-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 102-106. - Management of water facilities. 
    The management of all water facilities of the village is hereby vested in the Director of Public Works, subject to the supervision of the President and Board of Trustees and Village Manager. 
(Code 1965, § 32-1; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-107. - Only director to turn water on. 
    No water of the municipal water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person except by the Director of Public Works or a person authorized by him. 
(Code 1965, § 32-2; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-108. - Application for service. 
    No water shall be turned on for use on or in any premises until a written application therefor has been made and filed with the Finance Director, stating the purpose for which the water is to be used. 
(Code 1965, § 32-3) 
Sec. 102-109. - Application for permit to connect to supply pipe. 
    Application for a permit to connect service pipes with any supply pipe must be made to the department of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-4; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-110. - Deposit required. 
    Before the water will be turned on in any premises supplied by the village, there shall be a deposit with the village as follows: 
(1)  Residence ..... $ 50.00 
(2)  Business house ..... 50.00 
(3)  Industrial plant or country club ..... 50.00 
(Code 1965, § 32-5) 
Sec. 102-111. - Persons indebted to village not to receive water. 
    No water will be furnished to any person who is indebted to the village on account of water consumed, materials furnished or repairs made. 
(Code 1965, § 32-6) 
Sec. 102-112. - Meters required; meter reading. 
    All water furnished to customers shall be supplied through water meters. All meters shall be read not less than once per year. 
(Code 1965, § 32-7) 
Sec. 102-113. - Type; purchase of meters. 
    The water meter to be used shall be of the type approved by the President and Board of Trustees, and the person making application for the installation of a water meter shall purchase the water meter from the village at cost price established by the public works department. The applicant, or his agent or the builder of the house or structure, shall at the time a permit is issued for the construction of a building or structure, deposit with the village the cost price of the meter. 
(Code 1965, § 32-8; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-114. - Meter installation charges. 
(a)  Generally. Any person making application for a permit to construct a commercial or manufacturing building or any other building which shall require a water meter shall pay for the meter of such size as required by the public works and fire departments, and shall also pay the installation costs. 
(b)  Residential buildings less than four units. For residential buildings containing less than four dwelling units, there shall be a charge for the water meter and an installation charge. 
(c)  Residential buildings containing four units or more; business and commercial buildings. For residential buildings containing four units or more and for business and commercial buildings: 
(1)  Such buildings shall be equipped with water meters capable of being read automatically via telephone lines. 
(2)  The water user shall pay the cost of the meter and the cost of installing such meter and all related metering equipment, which costs shall be determined by the Finance Director. 
(Code 1965, § 32-9; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-115. - Installation of meters. 
    The installation of water meters shall be by the public works employees or persons designated by the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-10; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-116. - Location; visibility of meters. 
(a)  All water meters installed in any structure in the village shall be so located so as to permit authorized personnel easy accessibility for reading, maintenance and repair of the water meters. 
(b)  No building permit shall be issued for the erection or construction of any single-family residential structure or multiple-family residential structure, unless the plans accompanying the application for any such permits show compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 32-11) 
Sec. 102-117. - Meter to be near service pipe entrance; flushing; use of lead prohibited. 
    All meters must be placed inside as near as possible where the service pipe enters the building. The person doing the work must flush the pipe thoroughly before connecting the meter. No lead may be used in such meters or in the water system. 
(Code 1965, § 32-12) 
Sec. 102-118. - Installation of meters in basements; parkways. 
    When meters are set in basements they must be placed at least one foot distant from the wall, and must be made secure from frost. Meters shall not be placed in parkways. 
(Code 1965, § 32-13) 
Sec. 102-119. - Meter prohibited where subject to flooding. 
    Water meters must not be set in place where groundwater and surface water can rise and cover it. 
(Code 1965, § 32-14) 
Sec. 102-120. - Joining conducting pipes of meters; shutoff and waste valve required. 
    The conducting pipes of meters shall be joined with square-faced unions or flanges, and a ball valve or gate valve on each side of the meter for repairs and for use in emergencies. The shutoff must be as low as the meter connection. The decision of the Director of Public Works as to the location and type of pipes, valves and fittings shall be final. 
(Code 1965, § 32-15; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-121. - Repairs to meters. 
    All repairs to meters shall be made only by the public works department or a person designated by the public works department and at the expense of the owner or the occupant of the premises. The water may be shut off to allow repairs to be made whenever notice is given that repairs are contemplated. 
(Code 1965, § 32-16; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-122. - Removing; disturbing meters. 
    No person shall be permitted to tamper, test, repair, remove, relocate or in any way interfere with any water meter or electronic components, proportional, indicating or recording device, installed in any building, structure or premises for the control or measurement of the water supply thereto, excepting under the authority granted by the Director of Public Works. The owner of the building, structure or premises for which such meter is installed, or the person in possession, charge or control thereof, shall be held responsible for the cost of replacement or repair of any meter caused by any unauthorized tampering and interference. The water supply to such building, structure or premises shall be cut off, and shall not again be permitted to be turned on until such owner or person shall have paid to the Finance Director the cost and expense of cutting off and turning on such water supply, provided that where such person can show that such tampering was done contrary to his efforts to prevent such tampering, there shall be no such cutting off of the water supply. 
(Code 1965, § 32-17; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-123. - Water rates established. 
    The following shall be the rate for water supplied to each user, payable on the 21st day after the billing date: For all water used, there shall be charged a rate of $8.44 per 1,000 gallons. 
(Code 1965, § 32-18; Ord. No. 1995-22, § 1, 4-25-95; Ord. No. 1996-20, § 1, 4-23-96; Ord. No. 1997-12, § 1, 4-22-97; Ord. No. 1998-14, § 1, 4-28-98; Ord. No. 1999-20, § 1, 4-27-99; Ord. No. 2000-20, § 1, 4-25-00; Ord. No. 2001-24, § 1, 4-24-01; Ord. No. 2002-20, § 1, 4-23-02; Ord. No. 2003-16, § 1, 4-22-03; Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 4-27-04; Ord. No. 2006-25, § 1, 5-23-06; Ord. No. 2007-18, § 1, 5-22-07; Ord. No. 2008-21, § 1, 4-24-08; Ord. No. 2009-17, § 1, 5-27-09; Ord. No. 2010-31, § 1, 4-27-10; Ord. No. 2012-26, § 1, 4-24-12, eff. 6-1-12; Ord. No. 2013-21, § 1, 4-23-13, eff. 6-1-13; Ord. No. 2014-24, § 1, 4-22-14; Ord. No. 2015-27, § 1, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 102-124. - Changes in rates and regulations. 
    The village reserves the right to make such reasonable changes in rates and in conditions established in this article and to establish further rules and regulations from time to time as may be found expeditious or necessary. 
(Code 1965, § 32-19) 
Sec. 102-125. - Rendering of bills; delinquent; delinquency penalty. 
    Bills for water service shall be rendered quarterly; provided, however, that the Finance Director may elect to bill consumers on a monthly basis or as deemed necessary. All bills shall be delinquent 21 days after their rendition, and in the event of failure to pay the bills within the 21-day period, an additional late charge of ten percent shall be added to the bill. 
(Code 1965, § 32-20) 
Sec. 102-126. - Use of deposit to pay delinquent bill. 
    If any person having made a deposit in accordance with section 102-125 fails to pay the water bill, the deposit, if sufficient, shall be used to pay the delinquent water bill in full, or shall be used to pay on account thereof. If the deposit is not sufficient to pay the delinquent water bill in full, the water shall be shut off as provided in section 102-127. The President and Board of Trustees reserve the right to allow or disallow the user of the water to continue such use until the next regular quarter collection date without a further deposit. 
(Code 1965, § 32-21) 
Sec. 102-127. - Discontinuing service if deposit less than delinquent bill; right to hearing. 
(a)  If any person fails or refuses to pay a water bill as rendered by the village within 21 days from the date the bill was rendered, and there is not a sufficient deposit to cover the bill as provided in this subsection, then the Finance Director shall give the person written notice mailed to the last address supplied the village by such person of the delinquency and of the opportunity to be heard as to why the person's water service should not be discontinued as required by section 102-130. There shall be a $20.00 charge for the preparation and mailing of such notice. The $20.00 charge shall be in addition to any and all other remedies at law available to the village for the collection of bills due and owing. 
(b)  Any person issued a water bill who wishes to challenge the amount of such bill shall have the right to a hearing before the Finance Committee. A written request for a hearing must be given to the village, marked to the attention of the Village Manager or Finance Director, within 30 days from the date of the water bill. 
(c)  The Finance Committee has the authority to grant adjustments up to $500. The decision of the Finance Committee shall be made at the conclusion of the hearing and shall be final pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1965, § 32-22; Ord. No. 2013-49, § 1, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 102-128. - Charge when meter defective. 
    If any meter at any time fails to accurately register the quantity of water passing through it, the quantity shall be determined and the charge made based on the average quantity registered during such preceding period of time prior to the date of failure as the Finance Department may direct, in consultation with the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-23; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-129. - No deduction for leakage 
    No deductions will be made from water bills on account of leakage for commercial, industrial or rental properties. Residential (owner occupied) single family properties, not for profit and taxing bodies may be eligible for relief up to $500 subject to the procedures approved by the Niles Finance Committee. 
(Code 1965, § 32-24; Ord. No. 2013-49, § 1, 8-27-13) 
Sec. 102-130. - Discontinuing service for delinquency or violations; reconnecting charge. 
    For violation of any of the provisions of this article or for the nonpayment of water bills, the village reserves the right to turn off the water without notice and to forfeit any payments made, and after the water has been turned off from any service pipe on account of nonpayment of water bills, or violation hereof, the water will not be turned on until all delinquent bills and penalties are paid, together with a $50.00 charge for turning such water off and on. Only the Public Service Director or his designee shall turn off or turn on water service. 
(Code 1965, § 32-25) 
Sec. 102-131. - Unpaid bills declared lien; notice. 
    Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid 60 days after it has been rendered, the Finance Director may file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claims. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the permanent real estate index number, the amount of the unpaid bill together with any and all charges and penalties, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount, as well as for all water served subsequent to the period covered by the bill. If the consumer of water whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the village has notice of this, notice shall be delivered to the owner of the premises, if his address is known to the village, whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of 60 days after it has been rendered. If the owner cannot be found, the notice shall be posted upon the front door of the premises served with the water. 
(Code 1965, § 32-26) 
Sec. 102-132. - Foreclosure of lien. 
    Property subject to a lien for unpaid water charges shall be sold for the nonpayment of such charges, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting the costs, as in the case of a foreclosure of statutory lien. Such foreclosure shall be by a bill in equity in the name of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 32-27) 
Sec. 102-133. - Refund of water deposits. 
    If any person who has made a deposit in accordance with this article shall vacate the premises before the current quarter is ended, and the water used does not amount to the deposit so made, and the village is notified promptly at the time the occupant ceases to use the water, then the village shall rebate to the person who deposited such sum whatever difference there may be. 
(Code 1965, § 32-28) 
Sec. 102-134. - City not liable for damages. 
    All connections and water applied for under this article, and all the water used under the provisions of this article, shall be upon the express condition that the village shall not be liable nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused by reason of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or appurtenances connected with the system or pumping station, or any part or portion of the pumping station, or for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of machinery, or by reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals or the presence of radon or lead in the water supply. 
(Code 1965, § 32-29) 
Sec. 102-135. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-42, § 1, adopted July 12, 2011, repealed § 102-135, which pertained to foreign sewer fee reimbursement and derived from Ord. No. 2002-19, § 1, 4-23-02; Ord. No. 2010-20, § 1, 3-24-10. 
Sec. 102-136. - Civil penalties. 
    Any person that violates any provision of this article, and for non-payment of water bills, shall be liable to a civil penalty not to exceed $100.00 for the violation and an additional civil penalty not to exceed $100.00 per day for each day the violation continues. Such penalties may be ordered and administered by administrative adjudication or by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2002-30, § 1, 5-28-02) 
Sec. 102-137. - Discontinuing service for debts owed to the village; reconnecting charge. 
(a)  For the nonpayment of any bill, fine, fee or payment to the Village of Niles, the village reserves the right to turn off the water service furnished by the village with notice and hearing. After the water has been turned off from any service pipe on account of nonpayment of the above, the water will not be turned on until all bills fines, fees or payments are paid, together with a $50.00 charge for turning such water off and on. Only the Public Service Director or his designee shall turn off or turn on water service. After the notice and hearing provision as set forth in (b) a final decision for water shut off will be made by the mayor. 
(b)  The program shall be administered in the following manner: 
(1)  A notice of an impending water shut-off and a right to a hearing to challenge the validity of the notice by disproving liability for unpaid bill, fine, fee or payment to the Village of Niles. A list of liabilities will be listed on the notice. 
(2)  A hearing on the impending water shut-off shall take place at the next scheduled Niles Administrative Adjudication Hearing. 
(3)  After a final determination of liability is made, notice of that determination shall be immediately given to the debtor. 
(4)  The debtor shall be given a post water shut-off notice of the right to an adjudication hearing to challenge the validity of the water shut-off. 
(Ord. No 2007-49, § 1, 10-23-07) 
Secs. 102-138-102-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER SERVICE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 102-146. - Water control map. 
(a)  Adopted. The President and Board of Trustees hereby adopt a water control map for the village indicating and setting forth the complete water system. 
(b)  Cost of copies. Copies of the map may be obtained from the public works department at a cost of $10.00 per copy. 
(Code 1965, § 32-30; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-147. - Connections to village water mains required where accessible; expenses. 
    In order to provide for the general health, safety and welfare of the residents of the village, the corporate authorities have caused to be installed certain water mains within the village. Where such a water main exists in a particular area and is accessible for use by the owner of any lot, parcel of land or premises in the area, the owner shall connect to the system, at his own expense, and shall pay necessary and prescribed fees and charges therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 32-31) 
Sec. 102-148. - Type of faucets; hydrants; taps; hose. 
    All faucets, taps, fire sprinklers and hydrants connected with service pipes must be of the type approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-32; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-149. - Right of entry to examine pipes; fixtures. 
    Authorized representatives of the village shall have the authority to request access at all hours of the day between 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to all parts of every building in which water is delivered, to examine the pipes and fixtures, and to ascertain if there is any unnecessary waste of water or to read the water meter when not readable from the exterior of the premises. If such access is refused, the supply of water may be cut off in accordance with the procedures for delinquent water bills. 
(Code 1965, § 32-33) 
Sec. 102-150. - Conformity by plumbing. 
    The water shall not be turned on into the supply pipe of any new building, or building in which the plumbing and drainage systems have been altered, until such plumbing and drainage systems shall conform in all respects to the applicable ordinances of the village, and until the applicant shall have paid the water charges due. Plumbers will be allowed 24 hours to test the work. At the end of such time they shall turn off the water and for all purposes are strictly prohibited from turning the water into any service pipe except upon a permit so to do from the department of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-34; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-151. - Duty to maintain service pipe and fixtures. 
    All persons taking water shall keep the service pipes and all the fixtures connected therewith in good repair, and protected from frost, at their own expense, and must prevent all unnecessary waste of water; provided, however, that a reasonable time, not to exceed 24 hours, shall be allowed the parties having defective pipes to repair or cause the same to be repaired. 
(Code 1965, § 32-35) 
Sec. 102-152. - Owner's responsibility for repair of water lines from buffalo box to building; repair by village. 
(a)  It shall hereafter be the sole responsibility of each property owner wherein the lot or parcel of real estate has a water line running to it, to repair at its own cost and expense, any leaks, breaks, or malfunctions in the water line from the buffalo box serving on the lot or parcel of real estate to the house, building or structure located on the lot or parcel of real estate. 
(b)  Upon notice given to the real property owner that a water line is in need of repair, the property owner shall forthwith proceed to repair and/or replace the water line as expeditiously as possible in order to avoid a loss of water from the defective water line over an extended period of time. 
(c)  In such case that the water line repairs are not made as required in an expeditious manner, then the department of public works is hereby authorized and directed to go upon the property to repair the defective water line. The owner of the real property shall be responsible for the cost of such repairs, and the cost shall be billed and payable as provided for water usage. 
(Code 1965, § 32-36; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-153. - Obstructing; damaging water facilities. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any B-Box, hydrant or valve, or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street, alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the water system, nor pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article, thing or hinderance whatsoever within 15 feet of the same or so as to in any manner hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire department in reaching the same. It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water system, reservoir, or pumping station, or any part thereof, or to injure, deface, remove or displace any water main, hydrant, service pipe, B-Box, public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the water system, or pumping station, or to cause, suffer or permit any of such things to be done. 
(Code 1965, § 32-37) 
Sec. 102-154. - Tapping fees. 
    The fees for water taps shall be as follows: 
(1)  One-inch tap ..... $ 110.00 
(2)  One and one-half-inch tap ..... 215.00 
(3)  Two-inch tap ..... 245.00 
(Code 1965, § 32-38) 
Sec. 102-155. - Water connection inspection fees. 
    Any person performing any building or construction work for which a permit is required under the provisions of this article, shall, prior to the issuance of such permit, pay to the Village Clerk the following water supply system inspection fees: 
(1)  Residential: Flat rate ..... $ 35.00 
(2)  Commercial and industrial: 
(mains, in feet)

(3)  Multifamily building: 
Two to six units ..... 45.00 
Over six units ..... 45.00 
plus $5.00 per unit in excess of six units 
(4)  Swimming pools, etc.: Swimming pool and other installation requiring inspection, minimum ..... 20.00 
(Code 1965, § 32-39) 
Sec. 102-156. - Unauthorized use of water. 
    No person not duly authorized shall turn the water on at any fire hydrant or service cock, or use water therefrom when so turned on. 
(Code 1965, § 32-40) 
Sec. 102-157. - Using water from hydrants or lines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from any water hydrant or from any water line, unless there is attached thereto a water meter, and until an application is made so to do. 
(b)  Before any permit shall be issued, the applicant shall file with the Village Clerk a surety or cash bond in the sum of $1,500.00, conditioned that the water line or water hydrant shall not be damaged, but shall remain in the same condition as when it was used, and further to guarantee the payment for all water used from the water hydrant or water line, to which there is no meter attached. 
(c)  Any person using a water hydrant or water line except village officials or employees, shall pay for water used by metering the water hydrant or water line, or the amount used shall be estimated by the Director of Public Works and payment therefor shall be made in accordance with the rates established by this article. 
(d)  No permit shall be issued under the provisions of this section until a permit fee of $50.00 shall be paid to the Finance Director to cover the costs of the supervision of installing the meter, disconnecting the meter and inspecting the fire hydrant to determine whether or not any damage has been done thereto. 
(e)  Any bond posted as provided by this section shall not be released until the Director of Public Works has notified the Finance Director that there is no damage to the hydrant, and the meter has been returned to the public works department in working condition. 
(Code 1965, § 32-41; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-158. - Using water for construction purposes. 
    Persons desiring to use water for building or construction purposes shall make application therefor in writing and file the application in the office of the Finance Director on a form prescribed for that purpose. Upon a permit being granted, which permit shall be issued in writing and signed by the Director of Public Works, the service pipe shall be carried at the expense of the applicant to the inside of the curbline, where a service cock and meter shall be placed, with pipe leading to the surface, and a faucet placed at the end of the surface. When the building or construction work is completed, the faucet and meter shall be removed and the water shut off, unless permanent connection is made. Charge for the use and connection of meters shall be as prescribed by the President and Board of Trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 32-42; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-159. - Discontinuing service to contractors. 
    Water furnished contractors for new construction shall be shut off if the water is being wasted by the contractors. 
(Code 1965, § 32-43) 
Sec. 102-160. - Supplying water to others; permit required to work on plumbing. 
    No water consumer may supply water to other families or allow them to take it, except for use on the premises and for the purposes specified in the application, nor after water is introduced into any building or upon any premises shall any person make or employ any other person to make any tap or connection with the work upon the premises for alterations, repairs, extensions or attachments without a written permit therefor to be issued by the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-44; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-161. - Single connections servicing multiple consumers. 
    In all cases where one service connection or yard hydrant supplies two or more separate consumers, premises, tenements, business houses, or a block occupied by several parties, one meter only will be placed at the service connection for either or all of the consumers, and the water usage as registered by the meter shall be charged to and be payable by the owner of the premises or building. 
(Code 1965, § 32-45) 
Sec. 102-162. - Separate B-Box required for separate premises; cross connecting premises. 
    No owner or plumber shall be permitted to conduct water pipes into any two distinct premises or tenements unless a separate and distinct B-Box shall be placed on the outside of such premises along the sidewalk opposite the premises, nor shall any pipe be allowed to cross lots or buildings to adjoining premises. 
(Code 1965, § 32-46) 
Sec. 102-163. - Supervision of street work. 
    All necessary street work contemplated by this article shall be done under the supervision of the Director of Public Works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-47; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-164. - Excavations and tunneling under roads. 
    All excavations and back filling necessitated by the making of a water tap must be done by the applicant, and when it becomes necessary to tunnel underneath a state road or any road, all permits necessary for such tunneling shall be secured by the applicant. Such applicant shall provide a $25,000.00 bond, with a surety approved by the Village Manager. Such bond shall guarantee that all work shall be completed in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1965, § 32-48) 
Sec. 102-165. - Material specifications for water mains and fire hydrants. 
(a)  Materials for installing water mains shall be ductile iron pipe, class 52, conforming to the American Water Works Association AWWA C-151. Ductile iron pipe shall be cement-lined in accordance with AWWA C-104. Fittings shall be ductile iron or cast iron in accordance with AWWA C-110. Pipe joints shall be push-on in accordance with AWWA C-111. 
(b)  Fire hydrants shall conform to section 45 of "Standard Specifications for Water & Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, May, 1986 Edition," and AWWA C-502. Hydrants shall be breakaway type with six-inch flanged inlet connection, five-inch minimum valve opening with two, four-inch pumper connections, open left, with national standard threads. Hydrant type shall be approved by the department of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-49; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-166. - Sterilization of mains. 
(a)  All water mains thereafter constructed within public ways or easements for transmission of the public water supply and having an internal diameter of two inches or more, shall be cleaned and sterilized as provided in this section before such mains shall be placed in service, and before any service connections shall be made thereto. 
(b)  Following construction and pressure testing of the main, it shall be flushed thoroughly for a period of not less than one hour, using sufficient water to produce a velocity of not less than four feet per second. 
(c)  The steps to be taken to sterilize water pipes described in this section shall be as follows: 
(1)  Following the flushing, the main shall be sterilized by or under the supervision of an experienced chlorination specialist licensed as a professional engineer by the state. Sterilization shall be accomplished by introducing water and chlorine gas into the main at a uniform rate in sufficient quantities to produce a concentration of 50 parts of chlorine per million parts of water. 
(2)  The point of application of the chlorine shall be at the beginning of the main, or valved section thereof, and through a corporation cock inserted in the horizontal axis of the main. The end-most hydrant or valve on the section under treatment shall be partially opened to permit the flow of chlorinated water through the main, and to prevent the pressure from exceeding 20 pounds per square inch. The feeding of chlorine and water into the main shall continue until the water at the far end of the main contains a residual chlorine content of not less than 40 parts per million. 
(3)  The chlorinated water shall remain in contact with the interior of the main for at least 24 hours, during which period the valves and hydrants shall be operated at least once to ensure chlorine contact of their various parts. 
(4)  After the chlorine contact period the main shall be flushed through the end-most hydrant at a rate to produce a velocity through the main of not less than 21/2 feet per second. Flushing shall be continued until the residual chlorine content of the water in the pipe is reduced to two or three parts per million. After the flushing is completed, samples of water shall be taken from the main in sterile bottles on two different days and transported to a laboratory certified by the state for bacteriological analysis testing. 
(5)  The main shall not be placed in service nor service connections thereto made until a satisfactory bacteriological report is filed with the Village Clerk. If an unsatisfactory report is received, the entire sterilization process shall be repeated. 
(6)  Chlorination of all water mains within the village may be done by the water department or a third person under the direct supervision of the superintendent of public works and in all events, the cost of such chlorination shall be paid by the person for whose benefit the installation of water pipes has been made. 
(Code 1965, § 32-50) 
Sec. 102-167. - Material for water service pipe. 
    Wherever water service is required, the person requesting the service shall use only type K copper pipe as described in the Copper and Brass Research Association's specifications. 
(Code 1965, § 32-51) 
Sec. 102-168. - Flared fittings required from main to meter. 
    Whenever a person shall require water service, only flared fittings from the village water main to the village water meter shall be used. 
(Code 1965, § 32-52) 
Sec. 102-169. - Flared fittings or soldered joints required in buildings. 
    Wherever a person shall install water service inside a building, flared fittings or soldered joints are permissible; no lead solder is permitted. If soldered joints are used, solder and flux are to be used as recommended by the Copper and Brass Research Association. 
(Code 1965, § 32-53) 
Sec. 102-170. - Water service to be insulated. 
    All water service on outside walls of buildings must be insulated. The water service shall not be permitted to be recessed in outside wall by means of a chase or a slot. 
(Code 1965, § 32-54) 
Sec. 102-171. - Duty to install B-Boxes. 
    Any person requiring water service shall install B-Boxes brought to grade and marked on the sidewalk or curb. 
(Code 1965, § 32-55) 
Sec. 102-172. - Type of B-Boxes. 
    The only B-Boxes for house services which may be installed within the village shall be the Mueller H-10302 box with Minneapolis pattern base, and the curb stops shall be Mueller H-15154 with Minneapolis pattern top. 
(Code 1965, § 32-56) 
Sec. 102-173. - Duty to mark service boxes. 
    All subdividers or persons developing property for residential use within the village shall mark all service boxes on new or old concrete. 
(Code 1965, § 32-57) 
Sec. 102-174. - Minimum size water tap. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use a water tap of less than one inch when tapping any water main or water line within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 32-58) 
Sec. 102-175. - Gate valves or ball valves required. 
    Gate valves or ball valves shall be used on each side of the water meter in all water meter installations or replacements. 
(Code 1965, § 32-59) 
Sec. 102-176. - Valve basins required; location; installation. 
(a)  Any building or structure erected or constructed in the village after September 25, 2001, having a water service of two inches or larger, shall have installed in connection with such construction, a valve basin minimum of 48-inch diameter or approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(b)  The valve basin required to be installed under the provisions of this section shall be located in the parkway adjacent to the premises upon which the building or structure is erected or constructed. 
(c)  The installation of the valve basin required to be installed under the terms of this section shall be supervised by the Director of Public Works. 
(d)  No person shall erect or construct any building or structure within the village, where such building or structure has a water service of the size of two inches or larger, without installing a valve basin in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1965, § 32-60; Ord. No. 2001-48, §§ 1, 2, 9-25-01; Ord. No. 2004-43, § 2, 10-26-04; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-177. - Location; size of service cocks and ferrules. 
    All service cocks or ferrules must be inserted at or near the street main, and in no case nearer than 12 inches from the bell of the pipe. The ferrule inserted in distributing pipe and service pipes shall be the size specified in the permit and order. 
(Code 1965, § 32-61) 
Sec. 102-178. - Private hydrants; maint- enance; accessibility. 
(a)  No private hydrant shall be located on a public street or public sidewalk. 
(b)  All private hydrants shall be inspected and tested by the property owner not less than once every 12 months. Such inspections shall be kept on file at the primary location of the subject property and readily available at the Village's request. 
(c)  All private hydrants shall be kept clear of debris and vegetation by the owner of the hydrant. 
(Code 1965, § 32-60; Ord. No. 2015-78, § 1, 10-27-15) 
Sec. 102-179. - Use of fire department hydrant wrenches. 
    No member of the fire department shall let out or permit any person not connected with the fire department to take the wrenches furnished the department to be used in case of fire, or permit the wrenches to be taken from the usual place where the wrenches are kept, except for purposes strictly connected with the fire department, or as they accompany fire department vehicles on occasions of fire. 
(Code 1965, § 32-63) 
Sec. 102-180. - Village's right to shut off water in mains. 
    The village reserves the right to shut off water at any time in the mains for the purpose of repairing, cleaning, making connections with or extensions to same, or for the concentrating of water in any part of the village in case of fire; and for restricting the use of the water in case of deficiency in supply. 
(Code 1965, § 32-64) 
Sec. 102-181. - Use of groundwater as a potable water supply prohibited. 
(a)  [Prohibited use.] The use or attempt to use as a potable water supply groundwater from within the corporate limits of the village by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, and unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and terms listed shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    Potable water means any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or prepared foods. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $500.00 for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 2001-10, § 1, 2-27-01) 
Secs. 102-182-102-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LAWN SPRINKLERS 

Sec. 102-191. - Right to suspend lawn sprinkling. 
    The right is reserved to suspend the use of lawn fountains and hose for sprinkling lawns and gardens whenever, in the opinion of the village President, public emergencies require it. 
(Code 1965, § 32-65) 
Sec. 102-192. - Use of water for sprinkling limited. 
    No sprinkling is permitted between the hours of 12:00 noon to 6:00 p.m., nor on consecutive days from May 15 through September 15 of each year. New lawns (less than 3 months old) may be exempted from this provision. New/replacement sprinkler systems shall be equipped with a WaterSense labeled irrigation controller and shall be in compliance with Section 2.5(g) of the Illinois Plumbing License Law [225 ILCS 320]. 
(Code 1965, § 32-66; Ord. No. 2015-64, § 1, 9-22-15) 
Sec. 102-193. - Permit to install required. 
    No person shall install a lawn sprinkler system without first having obtained a permit therefor, signed by the department of public works upon approval of the application. 
(Code 1965, § 32-67; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-194. - Application for permit. 
    Application for a permit required by this division shall be in writing in the form prescribed by the department of public works. Such application shall contain such information, drawing and plans as shall be required by the department of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 32-68; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-195. - Drawings and plans. 
    All drawings and plans for the installation of any lawn sprinkler system shall first be presented to the department of public works for examination and approval. All plans and drawings shall be drawn to a scale on paper or cloth, in ink, or by some process that will not fade or obliterate. 
(Code 1965, § 32-69; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-196. - Materials. 
    Lawn sprinkler pipe sizing must meet existing requirements and specifications. Approved backflow and backsiphonage devices shall be used to prevent water contamination. 
(Code 1965, § 32-70) 
Sec. 102-197. - Fees. 
    The residential permit fee for a lawn sprinkler system shall be the sum of $25.00. The commercial permit fee for a lawn sprinkler system shall be the sum of $50.00. The control valve fee shall be the sum of $1.00 for each control valve, for both residential and commercial permits. 
(Code 1965, § 32-71) 
Sec. 102-198. - Inspection and approval. 
    The department of public works shall have the right and authority to inspect the installation of the lawn sprinkler system for final approval or disapproval. 
(Code 1965, § 32-72; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-199. - Authority to delay installation. 
    If the department of public works shall find, after inspection, that the installation of the sprinkler system does not meet the requirements of this division, it shall direct that the installation of the sprinkler system be delayed until all requirements are met. 
(Code 1965, § 32-73; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-200. - Metering of new water service. 
    All new water service in the village must be metered in the manner provided elsewhere in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 32-74) 
Secs. 102-201-102-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Sec. 102-211. - Potable water prohibited from use in flushing of sanitary sewers. 
    Potable water shall not be used for flushing sanitary sewers. 
(Code 1965, § 32-75) 
Sec. 102-212. - New construction and repair and/or replacement of fixtures-Flow rates. 
    In all new construction and in all repair and/or replacement of the following types of fixtures and trim, only fixtures and trim not exceeding the following flow rates and/or water usage shall be installed: 
(1)  Water closets, tank type, gallons per flush ..... 3.5 
(2)  Water closets, flushometer type, gallons per flush ..... 3.0 
(3)  Urinals, flushometer type, gallons per flush ..... 3.0 
(4)  Shower heads, gallons per minute ..... 3.0 
(5)  Lavatory, sink faucets, gallons per minute ..... 3.0 
The foregoing ratings are based on a pressure at the fixtures of 40 to 50 psi. 
(Code 1965, § 32-76) 
Sec. 102-213. - Same-Faucets of public restroom lavatories. 
    Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Code, in all new construction and in all repair and/or replacement of fixtures, faucets of lavatories located in restrooms for public use shall be of the metering or self-closing type. 
(Code 1965, § 32-77) 
Sec. 102-214. - Same-Automobile laundries or carwashes. 
    In all new construction or repair and/or replacement of fixtures in automobile laundries or carwashes, such carwash installations shall be equipped with a water recycling system. 
(Code 1965, § 32-78) 
Secs. 102-215-102-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL PROGRAM 

Sec. 102-221. - Statement of purpose. 
    That, if in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code or in the judgment of the code enforcement department, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the code enforcement department will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code and all applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices as required by the Illinois Plumbing Code and local regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-222. - Alternative water supplies restricted. 
    That no person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the village enters the supply or distribution system of said municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the Director of Public Works and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-223. - Enforcement. 
    That it shall be the duty of the code enforcement department to cause surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two years or as often as the code enforcement department shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. The purpose of this survey is to compile and update an inventory of devices. The survey must consist of a pencil and paper collection of information conducted by telephone, mail or personal visit to the manager or owner of a specific property. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-224. - Inspection rights. 
    That the approved cross-connection control device inspector shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of Niles for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross-connections, and that the code enforcement department shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of Niles for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross-connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the code enforcement department any information which they may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the code enforcement department, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-225. - Discontinuance of service. 
    That the Director of Public Works is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this division is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as they may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this ordinance and until a reconnection fee of $50.00 is paid to the village. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the Director of Public Works is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of the cause of disconnection. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-226. - Repairs to water system. 
    That the consumer responsible for backsiphoned material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross-connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of clean-up of the potable water supply system. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-227. - Cross connection control-General policy. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of these rules and regulations is: 
(1)  To protect the public water supply system from contamination or pollution by isolating within the customer's water system contaminants or pollutants which could backflow through the service connection into the public water supply system. 
(2)  To promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections, actual or potential, between the public or consumer's potable water system and non-potable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems containing substances of unknown or questionable safety. 
(3)  To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross connection control which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the public and consumer's potable water systems. 
(b)  Application. These rules and regulations shall apply to all premises served by the public potable water supply system of the village constructed after the effective date of this division, or premises currently existing and undergoing substantial improvement or renovation of the plumbing system after the effective date of this division. 
(c)  Policy. The owner or official custodian shall be responsible for protection of the public water supply system from contamination due to backflow or back-siphonage of contaminants through the customer's water service connection. If in the judgment of the code enforcement department, an approved backflow prevention device at each service connection to the premises is required, the consumer shall immediately install such approved device or devices at their own expense. Failure, refusal or inability on the part of the consumer to install such devices or devices immediately shall constitute grounds for discontinuing water service to the premises until such device or devices have been installed. The consumer shall retain records of installation, maintenance, testing and repair as required in section 102-235 below for period of at least five years. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-228. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of these regulations: 
    Fixed proper air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the water discharge point and the flood level rim of the receptacle. 
    Agency means the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Agency regulations shall refer to 35 Ill. Adm. Code 653. 
    Approved means backflow prevention devices or methods approved by the Research Foundation for Cross Connection Control of the University of Southern California, American Water Works Association, American National Standards Institute or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation. 
    Auxiliary water system means any water source or system on or available to the premises other than the public water supply system and includes the water supplied by the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from a source such as wells, lakes or streams, or process fluids, or used water. These waters may be polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or system over which the water purveyor does not have control. 
    Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the intended source of the potable water supply. 
    Backflow prevention device means any device, method, or type of construction intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All devices used for backflow prevention in Illinois must meet the standards of the Illinois Plumbing Code and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Back siphonage means a type of backflow in a pipe or plumbing device in which used, contaminated, or polluted water flows back from a receptacle, or other source into a negative pressure in such pipe or plumbing device. 
    Code enforcement department means the Village of Niles, Cook County, Illinois, Code Enforcement Department or their authorized representative(s), including, but not limited to licensed plumbing inspectors. 
    Consumer or customer means the owner, official custodian or person in control of any premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system. 
    Consumer's water system means any water system located on the customer's premises. A building plumbing system is considered to be a customer's water system. 
    Contamination means an impairment of the quality of the water by entrance of any substance to a degree which could create a health hazard. 
    Cross connection means any physical connection or arrangement between two otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the other a substance of unknown or questionable safety or quality, whereby there may be a flow from one system into the other. 
    Direct cross connection means a cross connection formed when a water system is physically joined to a source of unknown or unsafe substance. Indirect cross connection means a cross-connection through which an unknown substance can be forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe potable water system. 
    Cross connection control device means any approved device, method, or type of construction intended to prevent backflow into the waterworks system or other potable water supply system. The term "backflow prevention device" shall be included in the definition of cross connection control device. All devices used for backflow prevention in Illinois must meet the standards of the Illinois Plumbing Code and the agency. 
    Cross connection control device inspector shall mean any person approved by the agency who is responsible for inspecting cross connection control devices. 
    Department of public safety means any public or private organization established for the protection of public or private property from fire. 
    Double check valve assembly means an assembly composed of single, independently acting check valves approved under ASSE Standard 1015. A double check valve assembly must include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing the water tightness of each check valve. 
    Health hazard means any condition, device or practice in a water system or its operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well being of consumers. The word "severe" as used to qualify "health hazard" means a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in death or significant reduction in the quality of life. 
    Illinois Plumbing Code means 77 Ill. Adm. Code 890. 
    Inspection means a plumbing inspection to examine carefully and critically all materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of a plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the Illinois Plumbing Code, 77I11. Adm. Code 890. 
    Non-potable water means water not safe for drinking, personal, or culinary use as determined by the requirements of 35 Ill. Adm. Code 604. 
    Plumbing means the actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension of a plumbing system by any person. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including without limitation lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to, within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping, from discharge of pumping units to and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a building drain and a sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work or assemble from the point of connection of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system five feet beyond the foundation walls. 
    Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
    Potable water means water which meets the requirements of 35 I11. Adm. Code 604 for drinking, culinary and domestic purposes. 
    Potential cross connection means a fixture or appurtenance with threaded hose connection, tapered spout, or other connection which would facilitate extension of the water supply line beyond its legal termination point. 
    Premises means a lot or a part of a lot, a building or a part of a building, or any parcel or tract of land. 
    Process fluid(s) means any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, pollution, or system hazard if introduced into the public or a consumer's potable water system. This includes but is not limited to: 
(1)  Polluted or contaminated waters; 
(2)  Process waters; 
(3)  Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; 
(4)  Cooling waters; 
(5)  Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes, streams, or irrigation systems; 
(6)  Chemicals in solution or suspension; 
(7)  Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other processes, or for fire fighting purposes; 
    Public water supply means all mains, pipes and structures through which water is obtained and distributed to the public, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing water for drinking or general domestic use and which serve at least 15 service connections or which regularly serve at least 25 persons at least 360 days per year. A public water supply is either a "community water supply" or a "non-community water supply". 
    Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device means a device containing a minimum of two independently acting check valves together with an automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the two check valves and approved under ASSE Standard 1013. During normal flow and at the cessation or normal flow, the pressure between these two checks shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall operate to maintain the pressure between the check valves at less than the supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly located test cocks. 
    Service connection means the opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at the water main through which water is supplied to the user. 
    Survey means the collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping system regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and must include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of all cross connection control devices and methods located within that customer's piping system. The survey must be in written form, and should not be an actual plumbing inspection. 
    System hazard means a condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply system or a consumer's potable water system. 
    Used water means any water supplied by a public water supply system to a consumer's water system after it has passed through the service connection and is no longer under the control of the water supply official custodian. 
    Village means the Village of Niles, Cook County, Illinois. 
    Water fund means the monies or revenues of every kind arising by the operation of this article or any other ordinance relating to the waterworks system. 
    Water supply system means any water source, supply, or system, including all pipes, fittings, and control valves, as well as the water so supplied. The term "water supply system" shall not include the waterworks system however. 
    Waterworks system means all the system of pipes, hydrants, boxes, cocks, taps, meters, connections, reservoirs, tanks, engines, property and all appurtenances thereto, whereby water is or may be supplied to the public or to private parties within the village, operated, controlled or owned by the village. 
    Water purveyor means the owner or official custodian of a public water system. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-229. - Water system. 
(a)  The water system shall be considered as made up of two parts: the public water supply system and the consumer's water system. 
(b)  The public water supply system shall consist of the source facilities and the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities of the potable water system under the control of the Director of Public Works to the point where the consumer's water system begins. 
(c)  The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to the public water supply distribution system. 
(d)  The public water supply distribution system shall include the network of conduits used to deliver water from the sources to the consumer's water system. 
(e)  The consumer's water system shall include all parts of the facilities beyond the service connection used to convey water from the public water supply distribution system to points of use. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-230. - Cross connection prohibited. 
(a)  Connections between potable water systems and other systems or equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable quality are prohibited except when and where approved cross connection control devices or methods are installed, tested and maintained to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis. 
(b)  (1) No physical connection shall be permitted between the potable portion of a supply and any other water supply not of equal or better bacteriological and chemical quality as determined by inspection and analysis and approved by the Director of Public Works and by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
(2)  There shall be no arrangement or connection by which an unsafe substance may enter a supply. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97; Ord. No. 2018-57, § 1, 9-25-18) 
Sec. 102-231. - Survey and investigations. 
(a)  The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the approved cross connection control device inspector for the inspection of the presence or absence of cross connections within the consumer's premises, and testing, repair and maintenance of cross connection control devices within the consumer's premises. 
(b)  On request by the code enforcement department, the consumer shall furnish information regarding the piping system or systems or water use within the customer's premises. The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the code enforcement department for the verification of information submitted by the inspection consumer to the public water supply custodian regarding cross connection inspection results. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to arrange periodic surveys of water use practices on his premises to determine whether there are actual or potential cross connections to their water system through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow into their or the public potable water system. All cross connection control or other plumbing inspections must be conducted in accordance with state statutes. 
(d)  It is the responsibility of the water consumer to prevent backflow into the public water system by ensuring that: 
(1)  All cross connections are removed or approved cross connection control devices are installed for control of backflow and back siphonage. 
(2)  Cross connection control devices shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
(3)  Cross connection control devices shall be inspected at least annually by a person approved by the agency as a cross connection control device inspector (CCCDI). The inspection of mechanical devices shall include physical testing in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
(4)  Testing and records. 
a.  Each device shall be tested at least annually or more frequently if recommended by the manufacturer. 
b.  Records submitted to the community public water supply shall be available for inspection by agency personnel in accordance with state statutes. 
c.  Each device shall have a tag attached listing the date of most recent test, name of CCCDI, and type and date of repairs. 
d.  A maintenance log shall be maintained and include: 
1.  Date of each test; 
2.  Name and approval number of person performing the test; 
3.  Test results; 
4.  Repairs or servicing required; 
5.  Repairs and date completed; and 
6.  Servicing performed and date completed. 
(Ord. No. 1997-22, § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 102-232. - Where protection is required. 
(a)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each service line to a consumer's water system serving premises, where in the judgment of the code enforcement department or Director of Public Works, actual or potential hazards to the public water supply system exist. 
(b)  An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each service line to a consumer's water system serving premises where the following conditions exist:
